componenttext: And there are a lot of newer, what we call the NS product family, which are unified, which we’ve released fairly recently. So we shouldn't get too hung up on whatever that codename is used, VCX, is that what you said? But so…

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill Shope from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Bill Shope from Credit Suisse.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think there’ll always be a mid-tier and a high-end, but I do think you hit on a very important point. We, for sure, are seeing customers that would've bought a mid-tier product just saying, “Okay, now that SIEM has this degree of scalabilit
componenttext: Well, I do think there’ll always be a mid-tier and a high-end, but I do think you hit on a very important point. We, for sure, are seeing customers that would've bought a mid-tier product just saying, “Okay, now that SIEM has this degree of scalability” -- because this new SIEM is unique in that it scales up like every other did, but it also scales out. So you could scale these things out fairly inexpensively and by sometimes by taking that approach at adding a low-tier, say, SATA drives in it and using software like FAST, it can compete very, very effectively with mid-tier. So you are right, it does -- and that is one of the reasons for SIEM's, one of the reasons for SIEM’s high growth this quarter. So there will be some blurring. But that being said, I still think you’ll still see the two, these two distinct mid-tiers for the long-term. And I do expect that the mid-tier has the ability, especially as we get into the lower mid-tier, where the higher growth is today, that we're not a strong player in yet, but will be. I think you will see the mid-tier for the long haul grow faster than the high end.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question today comes from Katy Huberty from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our last question today comes from Katy Huberty from Morgan Stanley.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: David, on linearity, do you think that is a theme for this year, meaning more linear quarters, lower DSOs and free cash flow closer to the $1 billion range you reported for March? Is that sustainable through the rest of this year?
componenttext: David, on linearity, do you think that is a theme for this year, meaning more linear quarters, lower DSOs and free cash flow closer to the $1 billion range you reported for March? Is that sustainable through the rest of this year?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Multi-part question. Linearity, Q1, I think a little bit better than expected because some more of the pent-up demand we spoke about we saw earlier in the quarter, and you're absolutely right, that's reflected in our DSOs down of four 40 [ph] days. If we
componenttext: Multi-part question. Linearity, Q1, I think a little bit better than expected because some more of the pent-up demand we spoke about we saw earlier in the quarter, and you're absolutely right, that's reflected in our DSOs down of four 40 [ph] days. If we’re correct on our assumptions about pent-up demand really being a Q4 Q1 phenomena, then I think we'll go back to our quarters that are slightly more normal from a linearity point of view. Obviously better than we saw last year, but kind of more comparable to what we saw in 2008. From a free cash-flow point of view, bear in mind that Q1 is always our strongest quarter, Q1 and Q4 are always our strongest quarters, because you're collecting off the biggest receivable base. So, obviously, we're very pleased with what we've done, but we’re not promising billion-dollar cash-flow quarters going forward at this point in time. But we are very confident that we’ll continue to show significant difference, positive difference, between free cash flow and non-GAAP net income for the year.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in closing, first of all, thank you all for joining us. We are very confident and do believe we have a compelling vision and strategy, one that’s not only right for 2010 but well behind. I think we’re in great shape with our products and solutio
componenttext:
Well, in closing, first of all, thank you all for joining us. We are very confident and do believe we have a compelling vision and strategy, one that’s not only right for 2010 but well behind. I think we’re in great shape with our products and solutions and the support that underpin this vision and strategy. We have a world-class partner ecosystem. Very importantly, we have the leadership and a deep belief throughout our 43,500-people-plus around the world that we can and will win. 
And just as a side note, our premier customer event we call EMC World happens to be in Boston. It starts on May 10. And we will use this opportunity to be giving our customers updates on our strategy and vision of how we take them to the private cloud and all the great features and new products that the R&D teams have been working on. So this is their time to share this with our customers, and of course, as we share with our customers, we’ll share it with all of you. And again, thank you very much for being with us today, and we’ll be talking to you.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome, and thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Now I'll turn the meeting over to Mr. Tony Takazawa. Sir, you may begin.
componenttext: Welcome, and thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Now I'll turn the meeting over to Mr. Tony Takazawa. Sir, you may begin.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Julia. Good morning. Welcome to EMC's call to discuss our financial results for the first quarter of 2010. Today we are joined by Joe Tucci, EMC Chairman and CEO; and David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few co
componenttext:
Thanks, Julia. Good morning. Welcome to EMC's call to discuss our financial results for the first quarter of 2010. Today we are joined by Joe Tucci, EMC Chairman and CEO; and David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results that we released this morning. He will highlight some of EMC’s activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for 2010. Joe will then spend some time discussing his view of what is happening in the market, EMC’s execution of the strategy and how EMC is positioned. After the prepared remarks, we will then open up the lines to take your questions.
I would like to point out that we will be referring to non-GAAP numbers in today's presentation unless otherwise indicated. The reconciliation of our non-GAAP comments to our GAAP results can be found in the disclosure today in our press release, supplemental schedules and the slides that accompany our presentation. All these are available for download within the Investor Relations section of emc.com. As always, we have provided detailed financial tables in our news release and on our corporate website. These include a lot of financial detail, so we do encourage you to take a look at them. The call this morning will contain forward-looking statements and information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ, can be found in EMC's filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Lastly, I will note that an archive of today's presentation will be available following the call.
With that, it is now my pleasure to introduce David Goulden. David?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm pleased to report that EMC started the year with very solid results in Q1, with revenues of $3.9 billion, up 23% from Q1 '09, non-GAAP EPS of $0.26, up 63% and free cash flow of $1.1 bill
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'm pleased to report that EMC started the year with very solid results in Q1, with revenues of $3.9 billion, up 23% from Q1 '09, non-GAAP EPS of $0.26, up 63% and free cash flow of $1.1 billion, also up 63%. These results speak to the strength of our leadership position in some of the most important areas of IT and to the power of our operational model. We clearly executed on our triple play. We gained market share, we invested for the future and we improved profitability. We're confident that we'll continue to execute in all three of these areas going forward.
Within these numbers, each of our two businesses have excellent results. Our EMC Information Infrastructure business had a great quarter, with $3.3 billion in revenue, up 22% year-on-year, and $0.21 non-GAAP EPS, almost double our EPS from last Q1. VMware also had a great quarter, contributing $632 million of revenue, up 34% year-on-year, and $0.05 of non-GAAP EPS to EMC. Customers are increasingly recognizing that VMware is the strategic layer on which to build their next-generation cloud data centers.
I'll start off this morning by making some comments about the Q1 spending environment, why EMC is thriving, and then I'll discuss some details from our Q1 results. 
There are three major factors that contributed to our excellent revenue performance this quarter. First of all, based upon what we saw in the marketplace, we think IT spending looks to be on track with what we've been expecting, up around 3% to 5% this year. In addition, customer activity and commentary is consistent with a view that our addressable market will be up around 6% to 8% this year. A second factor this quarter was the continuation of some pent-up demand that we saw in Q4. For EMC's Information Infrastructure business, this strength was concentrated in the U.S. storage business, especially in financial services. And while it's difficult to quantify, it was certainly a positive. As a result of these two factors, we think growth in IT spending in our target marketplace in 2010 will end up at the higher end of our projected ranges. 
Third and most important, we expect to gain a significant amount of share this year, and it seems pretty clear we're off to a good start in this regard. EMC grew faster than our target market for a number of reasons, including our expanding role as a trusted partner with customers, our leading technology in several of the hottest areas of IT today, our proven support and service that back up this technology and our compelling vision and ability to execute on this vision. As a result, we are increasingly the best guide for customer's journey for private cloud, and we believe this competitive advantage is a major factor enabling us to show strong growth and gain share. And it positions us well to continue to gain share going forward.
Given this unique combination of strategic market and technology advantages, we now anticipate 2010 consolidated revenues of $16.5 billion, up 18%, non-GAAP operating margins of 20% to 21% and non-GAAP EPS of $1.18, up 31% from last year.
Now let's take a closer look at some of the financial highlights from the first quarter. As I mentioned, EMC Information Infrastructure revenues were $3.3 million, up 22% year-on-year, non-GAAP earnings per share for EMC II was $0.21, up 91% from last year. Free cash flow was a very strong $819 million, up 66%. Within these overall numbers, strong demand for our Information Infrastructure products generated revenues of $2.2 billion, up 27% from last year, while Information Infrastructure Services were $1.1 billion, up 13%. The fact that products were so much better than services is an encouraging sign that customers are moving forward with their infrastructure investments.
EMC Information Infrastructure operating performance for the quarter was also very strong. Non-GAAP gross margins were 53.4%, and non-GAAP operating margins were 17.8% in Q1. The substantial year-on-year improvement stemmed from higher volumes, our better prospects and the measures we’ve taken to lower and streamline our cost structure.
Looking to the revenue results from each of the businesses within Information Infrastructure, Q1 Information Storage revenues were $2.9 billion, up 24%. As always, information growth continued to be a key driver. We also saw our customers beginning new projects in their existing traditional infrastructures. Added to both these was continued growth in the number of customers that are moving to virtual data center infrastructures. All three of these drivers benefited us in the quarter, as EMC is a trusted partner not only for customers’ requirements today, but also going forward as they embark on their own journeys to a private cloud.
In the high end, Symmetrix product revenues were up 28% year-on-year. Our V-Max transition is essentially complete. Customers are eager to benefit from its more efficient, flexible and cost-effective technology, and we're clearly gaining share. Today's applications require architecture that scales with the business needs. In Q1, one of the largest software companies in the world chose V-Max for its ability to scale capacity and performance and to support critical online applications. The combination of proven reliability, along with cost-effective storage tiering utilizing Fibre Channel, Solid State and SATA Drives, provided this customer with the best value.
Now turning to the mid-tier. Over the last few years, we've seen a shift in the way customers utilize mid-tier storage. The rapidly changing business environment in this tier increased the required adaptability of multi-protocol systems. And growing virtualized server environments intensify the need for these dynamic storage capabilities. As a result, customers are increasingly looking for mid-tier storage that’s capable of supporting multiple information types and communication protocols. We have been in lockstep with customers throughout this transition. For years we've been the acknowledged leader in the mid-tier for these capabilities, and we began to combine some of them when we introduced our market-leading unified products in 2006.
While we haven't previously disclosed our overall mid-tier revenues, today we're expanding our reporting to help you track our progress here. In Q1, our mid-tier storage product revenues were $800 million and grew a very robust 32% year-on-year. This amounts to a $3.2 billion annualized run rate from our mid-tier product revenues alone. This annualized number is quite conservative, as it does not include support, updates or other services revenues, and is being annualized based on our seasonally smallest quarter.
We gained share in the mid-tier due to the breadth and depth of our portfolio and the world-class service and support to back it up. Let me give you a couple of examples from Q1 of how we’re winning in this space. A large medical services company was looking for unified storage, replication, disaster recovery, backup and recovery, deduplication and path managements. We won this multimillion-dollar deal against NetApp on the strength of our mid-tier portfolio, as well as our replication and recovery capabilities within the customer’s clustered VMware environment.
Another win was a global online content services provider who selected EMC over NetApp for a couple of reasons: EMC’s superior raw-to-usable efficiency resulting in lower total cost of ownership and compelling deduplication and VMware integration. 
Our relationship with Dell strengthened in the quarter, and we were pleased to announce an expansion of our partnership to include additional mid-tier products. Channel partners, including Dell, are extremely important to our ongoing success in the mid-tier, and we’re very focused on expanding these partnerships. Our efforts here have really paid off, as EMC was recently named 2010 CRN [ChannelWeb] Channel Champion. Channels were a big contributor to our mid-tier business, at approximately 75% of our mid-tier product revenues in Q1.
It should also be noted that our mid-tier revenues are more weighted toward the high end of the mid-tier markets. We’re excited about the opportunity to expand our footprint into the faster-growing low end of the mid-tier, and are mobilizing the people, investing in the products and engaging the partners to make this happen.
Our success in the high end and mid-tier is driven by our ability to satisfy customers' needs today no matter where they are on their journey to the private cloud. EMC has been leading the charge of most of the important new technologies in information infrastructure today. These include virtualization data centers, SSDs with automated storage tiering and next-generation backup and recovery.
As our biggest, most immediate and most important growth opportunity, the evolution to fully virtualized data centers is where we're focusing the majority of our efforts. Fundamental to virtualized data centers is the creation and integration of virtual servers and virtual storage infrastructures. Clearly, we are far and away the leader on the service side with VMware. In addition, our unique vision around the virtualization of the Information Storage infrastructure is resonating with the industry, and you can expect to hear more from us soon on how we're going to make this happen. 
We also continued to lead the charge in virtualization affinity across our product set in both directions. In other words, we are unique in being able to see and manage from storage to virtual machine and from virtual machine to storage, and the connections continue to grow. These capabilities are key to new ways of thinking about data center design, and no company is well positioned as EMC to help customers.
Our Fully Automated Storage Tiering software, known as FAST, completed its first quarter availability in Q1, including double-digit penetration rates in the high end. Customers clearly see the value proposition of having the right data in the right place at the right time. And turning this advanced capability into a feature across our full solution set further extends our competitive advantage, as customers prefer to buy from a partner with a comprehensive solution as opposed to buying point products.
Our Backup Recovery Systems business performed ahead of our high expectations. In fact, Data Domain and Avamar each accelerated over 100% growth in the quarter. The synergy between these two is key to the acceleration here, and these businesses are certainly growing faster than any other deduplication technology in the markets. It's great to see this business systematically capitalizing upon opportunities worldwide, both within EMC's existing accounts and with net new customers as well.
In other storage areas, our online backup solution, Mozy, continued its strategy in the quarter to build its customer base via service providers, adding Comcast to an already long list of partners. Iomega continued to thrive in the unrelenting demand from customers wanting plug-and-play storage for all their media types. In addition, we are seeing increased demand from small and medium businesses that want easy-to-use network storage.
In sum, EMC storage business in the quarter outperformed our expectations due to our ability to provide leading-edge technology in a comprehensive solution that is supported by our world-class services organization. There is no vendor with a broad and innovative technology solutions desk, the depth of experience and a proven track record to provide information infrastructures that can safely and securely transition customers' data centers at their own pace to private clouds.
Our RSA Security revenues in Q1 were $161 million, up 13% year-on-year, as information-centric security remains a key customer priority. There were several noteworthy events in RSA this quarter, including RSA's annual Marquis security conference and the acquisition of Archer. Delegates’ attendance at the RSA conference was up 25% from last year, attesting to the growing importance of IT security. The addition of Archer's governance, risk and compliance technology, complements our existing DLP and enVision SIEM tools to create one security management platform. The resulting level of visibility shines a welcome security and compliance spotlight into both physical and virtualized environments. 
In addition, in Q1, RSA Archer, VMware and Intel introduced a proof of concepts for compliance, security and control down to the most fundamental layers of multi-tenant virtualized infrastructure. This is an important early step to help accelerate the growth of external clouds. With the addition of Archer, RSA is now the leader in every area in which it competes: authentication, IT GRC, DLP, SIEM and web fraud detection.
Revenues from our Web Content Management and Archiving division in Q1 were $178 million, up 2% in Q1 '09.  We saw increased customer activity with new license growth up 8%, a higher number of big deals done in Q4 and a strong pipeline exiting Q1. Our xCP composition platform for case and management, which is unique in the industry, is garnering a lot of customer interest. In fact, a major European national health system, has standardized upon xCP for its health records. 
A sharper focus on partnerships is also expanding CMA's growth opportunities in 2010. These include our recently announced partnership with FatWire to improve web content management, as well as a new relationship with SAP to provide a number of SAP-focused ECM solutions, the first of which we plan to announce in the next few weeks.
EMC's global services business once again showed strong results for the quarter, with revenues up 13% over last year's Q1. Our professional and technical services are doing well, and our consulting business continues to outperform, benefiting from customers’ transitions from virtual data center architectures. In fact, EMC consulting expertise was key to winning the first phase of a long-term collaboration with a Fortune 100 defense contractor to accelerate the transformation of their data centers to a service-oriented private cloud model. Such an undertaking requires deep expertise in cloud strategy and architecture, as well as the infrastructure products that have been purpose-built for such environments. That is why they chose EMC.
Our partnership with Cisco continues to gain momentum. In Q1, our VCE [Virtual Computing Environment] coalition was up and running. Its focus on helping customers their move to cloud infrastructures has really struck a chord, and interest has been outstanding. Customers are already in production with Vblocks and we’ll soon be rolling out a lower-end version of the Vblock. Over the next few months, you will see exciting announcements from both systems integrators and service providers leveraging the work of this coalition of best-of-breed technology companies.
Now, turning to a few highlights from our consolidated results, including both our Information Infrastructure and Virtual Infrastructure businesses. As I mentioned, the EMC Information Infrastructure business had revenues of $3.3 billion, non-GAAP operating margins of 17.8% and contributed non-GAAP EPS of $0.21 and free cash flow of $819 million. The VMware Virtual Infrastructure business had revenues of $632 million, non-GAAP operating margins of 28.1% and contributed non-GAAP EPS of $0.05 and free cash flow of $291 million. Together, our two businesses had total Q1 consolidated revenues of approximately $3.9 billion, up 23% year-on-year, non-GAAP operating margins of 19.5% and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.26. Free cash flow was $1.1 billion, $561 million higher than Q1 non-GAAP net income.
These consolidated results represent the combined power of virtual infrastructure and information infrastructure. Together, we're moving forward under a shared vision and strategic direction. Additionally, through complementary efforts, we're increasing affinity between the virtual and information infrastructures. This strategic alignment positions us well to execute our triple play to gain market share, to invest in the future and to improve profitability. As you can see from our revised 2010 revenue growth guidance of 18%, we intend to grow substantially faster than our target market and gain share. 
Second, we're investing for the future. We continue to plan to expand our R&D spend by 20% over last year, and we are further adding to our sales capability worldwide, particularly in the emerging markets and the commercial and SMB markets. And we now plan to implement a broad-based annual compensation review to reward and retain our workforce, which is been outstanding throughout what has been a very challenging period. 
Third, these increased investments notwithstanding, we expect to further improve profitability. We now expect consolidated non-GAAP operating margin for 2010 to reach between 20% and 21%, representing a substantial increase over the levels seen for the past several years.
Now a few housekeeping items. Currency added 240 basis points to the year-on-year revenue growth on a consolidated basis. The Q1 non-GAAP tax rate was 22%, higher than expected, as a renewal of the U.S. R&D tax credit has not yet been passed. We still expect our full-year non-GAAP tax rate to be around 20%, as we project that the tax rate will occur later this year, possibly as late as the fourth quarter. Q1 consolidated operating cash flow was $1.3 billion, up 53%. The improvements that generated this strong result include deferred revenues, which were $4 billion, inventory trims, which were 8x and DSOs which were 40 days.
Due to improvements in our stock price, we now expect our fully-diluted share count for the year to be around $2.15 billion. The difference from the $2.12 billion we disclosed in January is primarily due to the impact of our convertible debt. 
We ended Q1 with $10.2 billion in cash and investments. Of this, a total of $6.2 billion was held in the U.S., with the remainder overseas. In the quarter, we used $176 million of our cash to buy back 10 million shares of EMC stock and spent approximately $290 million on acquisitions. 
The program we announced last month to maintain our position in the VMware, at an approximately 80% majority ownership, underscores the importance of VMware's role in EMC’s strategic direction. We believe maintaining EMC’s ownership in VMware at this level enables us to continue to achieve our original objectives for publicly offering the stock and also maximize value for EMC shareholders over the long-term. To this goal, EMC purchased approximately $100 million of VMware stock in Q1.
Now looking at our best-of-breed technology and services portfolio, our long-standing presence in data centers worldwide and the customer trust we have earned, we believe there is no company better positioned to guide customers along their journey to the private cloud, and there is no doubt that's exactly where customers are heading. 
As this recent survey shows, almost every single CIO spending prior to this year is either on technology that puts customers on the path to the private cloud or is a benefit of having a private cloud. The first step to building a private cloud is server virtualization. And capturing the full benefits of server virtualization requires a vast automation of management capabilities designed for these environments. This is where VMware stands alone. Customers are embracing the new security paradigms that are necessary for private cloud infrastructures to proliferate. As we saw in the quarter, EMC, RSA and VMware are working hard, together with partners like Intel on approaches to information-centric security to accelerate the adoption of private cloud infrastructures. 
Customer interest in cloud computing is really picking up. At EMC, our strategy to bridge internal private clouds and external public clouds is spot-on. The ability to virtualize storage infrastructure enables the necessary new remote computing models required for private clouds. EMC has introduced several innovative new offerings in this space, and in the very near future will introduce virtual storage technology that will enable customers to use distance as an asset rather than see it as a constraint. 
The need for desktop virtualization is gaining momentum. A virtualized foundation like vSphere on the back-end enables the scalability and seamlessness of use that are critical to a successful enterprise rollout of VDI. On priorities like labor optimization, efficiency and green computing, all these are byproducts of operating a private cloud infrastructure. 
What all this indicates is that customers are quickly discovering that to keep their competitive edge, they need to do things differently. They need to transform their aging traditional infrastructures into the more cost-effective agile new models for IT that are now possible. EMC and VMware together are leading the charge in making these new computer models a reality. No other company has the proven or market-leading technology services and support that we do. No other company is as squarely aligned to these priorities, and no other company has the vision and ability to execute on this vision. 
I'll now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, David. I'd like to begin by welcoming everyone to today's conference call. As always, thank you very much for your interest in EMC. Overall, I was very pleased with our Q1 results. In fact, this Q1 was the best first quarter in EMC's histo
componenttext:
Well, thanks, David. I'd like to begin by welcoming everyone to today's conference call. As always, thank you very much for your interest in EMC. 
Overall, I was very pleased with our Q1 results. In fact, this Q1 was the best first quarter in EMC's history. We had record Q1 revenues, record Q1 net income and record Q1 free cash flow. And I might add, these results marked the second consecutive quarter in which we announced record quarterly results, proof that our strategy, coupled with our focus and strength in storage virtualization, security and information and content management is resonating very well with our customers.
Clearly, at an apples-to-apples, year-on-year growth rate of 20% this Q1, we are growing significantly faster than the markets we serve. In other words, we are taking share. And as always, what propels any company in any industry is excellence in execution. To that end, I would like to thank the more than 43,500 people of EMC and VMware across the globe for their dedication to our customers, for their skill, hard work and teamwork they exhibit every day. Congratulations to all of you on these strong results.
As David has indicated, in Q1, IT spending patterns were so much stronger than normal, as customers caught up with some pent-up demand from last year's cutbacks. Other positives, that customers have firm IT budgets in place, and they are investing in IT to gain productivity, both to help contain costs and to enhance revenues. As an example, we saw this global strength in our flagship Symmetrix product line. 
In addition, we had good visibility and predictability throughout quarter and experienced a good flow for calendarization of orders, much better than we experienced in the first half of 2009. And while we remain cautious about the pace of recovery, we are optimistic and have confidence in our ability to exceed our goals for this year, as is evidenced in our enhanced 2010 guidance that David just shared with you. What gives us this confidence in our ability to continue to grow and take share is our focus on four multi-billion dollar markets, all of which, or currently are, and will continue to exhibit extremely rapid double-digit growth for many years to come. And each one has the potential to be a billion-dollar-plus revenue opportunity for EMC.
Our first and largest opportunity is to help CIOs transform their data centers into private clouds. The key attribute of a private cloud that this will give CIOs the ability to truly offer their internal and external customers IT-as-a-service. IT-as-a-service is an IT environment where application workloads are truly policy- and service-level driven. IT-as-a-service is an IT environment that is far more automated, flexible and dynamic than today's data center environment. IT-as-a-service is an IT environment that advances security, availability and control to a higher level. And IT-as-a-service is an IT environment that will deliver significantly lower costs.
Our second billion-dollar-plus opportunity is to help service providers and telcos build out their public clouds using virtualization, storage, security and information management technologies. We will bring the same private cloud attributes and technologies to our service provider and telco partners as they build out their public clouds. This will allow them to attract application workloads from our enterprise and commercial customers. And by adding a suite of applications, they will be able to have full IT service offerings to attack markets such as SMB and public sector. Additionally, EMC will offer our service partners several applications so choices like PC backup and Storage as a Service.
Our third multi-billion-dollar opportunity is for EMC to be the clear leader in next-generation backup recovery and archive solutions. As a proof point of the opportunity here, the actual Q1 results from just the Data Domain and Avamar product services already represents $1.0 billion in revenue on an annualized run-rate basis. This is especially impressive when you consider that these products represent new growth areas for EMC. And for the record, we do expect Q2, Q3 and Q4 results for Data Domain and Avamar solutions to show sequential improvement.  And to top things off in this category, we have other offerings like NetWorker for backup, the SourceOne product family for compliant archiving and our family of Disk libraries.
Our fourth massive opportunity is around virtualizing client devices. We will bring to this market the benefits of virtualization and centralized management, the protection of centralized storage and enhanced information management, with a new and better way to secure information while lowering total costs. In short, we will help our customers embrace and get the maximum value from the rapid advances in choices that are now happening in client devices, while lowering their total TCO. This deep client market, while quite small right now, is extremely active as numerous customers are engaged in proof of concepts. Additionally, we see early adopters experiencing solid results. These are clear signs, to steal a phrase, that this is going to be big.
Collectively, in these four mega-growth opportunities, we have the vision, the leading technologies in virtualization, in security, in storage for block, file and object data and for the next generation of backup recovery and archive solutions. We have the people and the expertise to help customers and service providers make this transition. We have the partner ecosystem in place to succeed. And very importantly, we have the trust and permission of our customers to play in these markets.
We are convinced that continuing our focus on these four growth markets, along with continued investments in innovative technology and in exceptional people, we can maintain our long-term double-digit revenue growth rate. 
Thanks again for joining us today. I'll now turn it over to Tony to moderate the Q&A portion of today's call.

componenttext: Understanding that you guys are giving a new, what you call mid-tier breakdown of revenue, I’d like to dig into that a little bit deeper, as you're not disclosing CLARiiON growth. If I look at Data Domain within that, and you cited 100% growth, $800 million of revenue, that would -- backing that out would imply kind of organic growth of about 6%, by my math. So I guess first of all, can you help me, am I thinking about that correctly? Or maybe even more importantly, could you give us what the CLARiiON growth was in the quarter?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me clarify that for you. So first of all, I think the way to look at things would be on an apples-to-apples basis. I'll give you that data point. So if you took our mid-tier product revenues at around $800 million -- bear in mind, this is product
componenttext: Yes, let me clarify that for you. So first of all, I think the way to look at things would be on an apples-to-apples basis. I'll give you that data point. So if you took our mid-tier product revenues at around $800 million -- bear in mind, this is product-only, for my clarification. The apples-to-apples growth rate is 20%. So the reported growth rate was 32%. But if you included Data Domain as if we’d owned it a year ago, the apples-to-apples growth rate is 20%, so that's really the kind of comparable data point you should be looking at.

componenttextpreview: We’re not going to break that out, because really what's happening is because of all the convergence in the mid-tier, focusing upon individual products is now kind of less relevant. And that’s why we want to focus upon the total business and show you
componenttext: We’re not going to break that out, because really what's happening is because of all the convergence in the mid-tier, focusing upon individual products is now kind of less relevant. And that’s why we want to focus upon the total business and show you how that is progressing over time. Also, as we pointed out, channel partners are so important here as well, hence we gave it the 75% data point in terms of channel partner contribution to mid-tier revenues.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just put a little color on that. I mean, first of all, we’re kind of following the classic Gartner context for what makes up a mid-tier storage firm, price range and size.  And what we’re doing now, as we go to market, we're basically going to
componenttext: Let me just put a little color on that. I mean, first of all, we’re kind of following the classic Gartner context for what makes up a mid-tier storage firm, price range and size.  And what we’re doing now, as we go to market, we're basically going to market with a more unified message. So, for instance, a lot what would've been CLARiiON now has a CLARiiON in back of a Solaris as a unified platform. What would've been sometimes a CLARiiON data library, disc library, we might now throw over to Data Domain.  So you really got to look at these things collectively. And that’s why we’re giving you a fair number. So in other words, we have an exact same set of assets in 2009 as we did in first quarter -- first quarter 2009 as we have in 2010, and the apples-to-apples growth is 20%. But it's really -- the way we go to market, to look at one product is just not a good way to look at the market. And this is the way we're going to go forward. And this unified message and the fact that we have this unique ability to have this next-generation backup and archiving included in our offerings is truly a mid-tier category, and that's how we’re going to report, and that is the 20%.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: David, I want to dig into your prepared remarks. Earlier on you mentioned that you still saw more pent-up demand in this quarter. I believe U.S. and financials, or the specific verticals you highlighted, you were seeing a lot of that. Do you have any gaug
componenttext: David, I want to dig into your prepared remarks. Earlier on you mentioned that you still saw more pent-up demand in this quarter. I believe U.S. and financials, or the specific verticals you highlighted, you were seeing a lot of that. Do you have any gauge or insight as to how long do you think that still can last before you move into sort of "normal purchasing patterns," not catch-up mode?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I also refer you back to what you heard from VMware last night, because they also commented upon the fact they saw pent-up demand in the quarter. And as I mentioned for the Information Infrastructures business, we saw it mainly in the U.S. storage sector,
componenttext: I also refer you back to what you heard from VMware last night, because they also commented upon the fact they saw pent-up demand in the quarter. And as I mentioned for the Information Infrastructures business, we saw it mainly in the U.S. storage sector, we saw it in financial services, obviously, where that was a weak compare with Q1 in the year-ago and we saw it in the form of more large deals than you would typically expect in a Q1. We really are not anticipating a lot of that pent-up demand kind of running forward into the rest of the year. If you kind of look at how we guided, obviously our $16.5 billion guidance is a very strong revenue number. It's an 18% revenue growth, but if you kind of pull it apart, you'll see that because of pent-up demand, we're expecting Q1 to be higher than a usual percentage of the total. So we're expecting to move to a more seasonal pattern kind of after Q1, which would mean essentially that you wouldn't see quite as big a jump. In fact, Q2 might be near or flattish compared to Q1, and then expect a more seasonal progression from that point going forward.

componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we are, and it's very good news, we are absolutely collapsing platforms. So we’re going -- our big message is unified, and we have a strong family there. You'll see the second wave of Emphasys beyond, I'm not going to use any code names
componenttext: Well, certainly, we are, and it's very good news, we are absolutely collapsing platforms. So we’re going -- our big message is unified, and we have a strong family there. You'll see the second wave of Emphasys beyond, I'm not going to use any code names, but the second wave of Emphasys will be -- the mid-tier market is even growing faster where we're not a major player today, and that’s in the smaller systems. And you’ll see a lot of work on that probably in the early, very early next year. So we're very excited. But this is category, this how we compete against others in the industry. They're trying to pull together a suite of products that covers this landscape, and of course, we have, I think, an extraordinary position in the next-generation backup recovery.

componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the deferred revenue. You had a nice spike up there. Can you kind of give us some things that are driving that?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, you see that coming from two sides of the business.  You saw a nice build-up in deferred revenue on both the VMware side and the EMC Information Infrastructure side. In both cases, it's basically, may be due to prepaid software maintenance cont
componenttext: Yes, Mark, you see that coming from two sides of the business.  You saw a nice build-up in deferred revenue on both the VMware side and the EMC Information Infrastructure side. In both cases, it's basically, may be due to prepaid software maintenance contracts. So customers basically prepaying software maintenance with their software licenses, which is always a good sign.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Benjamin Reitzes from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Benjamin Reitzes from Barclays Capital.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit more about your cash usage, and where -- first of all, how you're going to balance acquisitions versus the various repurchases? It seems like there is a pretty good strategy of obviously keeping your VMware stake at 80%. How im
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit more about your cash usage, and where -- first of all, how you're going to balance acquisitions versus the various repurchases? It seems like there is a pretty good strategy of obviously keeping your VMware stake at 80%. How important is that? And what does that mean for purchases of VMware versus purchases of EMC and then how you balance acquisitions for the rest of the year? Thanks.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Ben, that’s -- it could be a long answer, but just to get highlights, obviously, we are going to continue. VMware is part of the EMC family. We are -- you can see the private cloud when you heard their conference call yesterday and their thing. I
componenttext: Well, Ben, that’s -- it could be a long answer, but just to get highlights, obviously, we are going to continue. VMware is part of the EMC family. We are -- you can see the private cloud when you heard their conference call yesterday and their thing. I mean, the strategy for both companies is they’re turning to their public cloud strategies, is making sure we get to the service provider. Public cloud community strategy is to watch and participate and have the best technology as this growing business for the Virtual Desktop and virtual client emerges. So those are all common strategies. So it's important that we work them together. Obviously, we continue to let, to work VMware in a very open fashion so that others can continue to play. And that will continue to be the case. And, of course, EMC on the back of that, which is good for today's environments and good for tomorrow's cloud environments, the next-generation backup recovery that we add. So keeping that stake is incredibly important, and that's exactly what we're going to do. Secondly, as we have those four great -- probably one of the first times in my life that I had four opportunities this big hitting me at once. So our best, I believe, our best return on value for customers is to make sure we take the right moves and continue to invest in technology through our own R&D. So how we were a little -- it's going to ramp up, we are going to share increase our R&D this year to 20%. We are going to continue to buy companies, both in VMware and in EMC. And that'll be the primary focus for the cash and to get great returns for the shareholders. And we continue to focus on what David calls the triple play. We want to hit -- in the short term, we want to hit, we want to make sure that we continue to grow and take share. We want to make sure that we continue to invest for the long-term and capitalizing opportunities. So we want to do all three.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Maynard Um from UBS.
componenttext: Maynard Um from UBS.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about components in the quarter, if there are any shortages? If so, what components? Because I see inventory was down only modestly, and I’m just wondering if that's a buffer and if that's still a sign that things are still tight. And
componenttext: Can you just talk about components in the quarter, if there are any shortages? If so, what components? Because I see inventory was down only modestly, and I’m just wondering if that's a buffer and if that's still a sign that things are still tight. And if I could just follow up on that, can you just provide any color on whether you're expecting component tightness to ease in the back half and if that's reflected in your 20% to 21% out-margin guidance for the year?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, this might surprise you, but we are fine this quarter in terms of our supply chain. We did not see that tightness that you referred to. We didn't see that that hard and did not impact us at all. We don’t expect it to impact us going forward. So we
componenttext: Well, this might surprise you, but we are fine this quarter in terms of our supply chain. We did not see that tightness that you referred to. We didn't see that that hard and did not impact us at all. We don’t expect it to impact us going forward. So we think we’re fine.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you expect it to ease going into the back half of the year that might help you on the margins, and is that reflected in your guidance?
componenttext: Do you expect it to ease going into the back half of the year that might help you on the margins, and is that reflected in your guidance?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think what obviously happens is when you get a tightness, everybody’s ramping up, and these are the suppliers we use, and if that happens, there is some opportunity there. But I expect with my statement we did not see -- this tightness that you referr
componenttext: I think what obviously happens is when you get a tightness, everybody’s ramping up, and these are the suppliers we use, and if that happens, there is some opportunity there. But I expect with my statement we did not see -- this tightness that you referred to did not impact us this quarter. We had all the parts we needed, and our suppliers were very responsive.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian Marshall with Broadpoint.
componenttext: Brian Marshall with Broadpoint.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It looks like your incremental and gross margins on your Information Storage business have been trending nicely over the past several years, and especially the last four quarters. I guess the question is, going forward, do you expect those trends to conti
componenttext: It looks like your incremental and gross margins on your Information Storage business have been trending nicely over the past several years, and especially the last four quarters. I guess the question is, going forward, do you expect those trends to continue at these high levels? And if so, or if not, is there a reason why we shouldn't expect to see a six handle on our overall corporate gross margins at some point down the road?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, obviously if you look at our Information Storage or Information Infrastructure business, margins have progressed very nicely. You saw we did 53.4% in the last quarter. And as I mentioned, there's been a few drivers. Obviously, volume helps. Mi
componenttext: Yes, Brian, obviously if you look at our Information Storage or Information Infrastructure business, margins have progressed very nicely. You saw we did 53.4% in the last quarter. And as I mentioned, there's been a few drivers. Obviously, volume helps. Mixed shift helped. And, obviously, our V-Max transition has been helpful for us. And that is something that is basically -- that piece of it is now complete. But as we go through the rest of this year, we expect to still be able to improve on the gross margins we delivered in Q1.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: David Bailey, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: David Bailey, Goldman Sachs.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked a lot about share gains. And so you can you give a little bit more detail about what the competitive environment’s like right now?
componenttext: You talked a lot about share gains. And so you can you give a little bit more detail about what the competitive environment’s like right now?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's very competitive out there. I don't think much has changed. It’s -- we're still seeing the same competitors we've seen for the last couple of years. And I do believe that you saw tremendous strength in Symmetrix. The move to the x86 technology and
componenttext: It's very competitive out there. I don't think much has changed. It’s -- we're still seeing the same competitors we've seen for the last couple of years. And I do believe that you saw tremendous strength in Symmetrix. The move to the x86 technology and V-Max, the fact that we have the Flash and the FAST technology out now is resonating very well with customers. So we're competing very well there. You saw our mid-tier results. Unified is absolutely the way to go, and then, of course, I think we are uniquely positioned in this next-generation archive. I think we’re -- and if you look at our security business, the unique focuses we have there on IPV and on security and event management and on data loss prevention, are hot areas. I think as we go through this case, XEP type of approach in our content management business, that's going to play extremely well. So again, competition is the same, competition is intense. But the teams have done a really good job distinguishing our products, and we have a good go-to-market organization and we’re now investing heavily in marketing. Jeremy Burton just joined us as CMO and we're going to make sure that we can -- we need to do a better job on that front. So I don't know if that answered your question, but it’s kind of how we see the landscape.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin Hunt, Hapoalim Securities.
componenttext: Kevin Hunt, Hapoalim Securities.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on the Symmetrix business, which you just mentioned there, Joe. And specifically, if I'm not mistaken, [indiscernible] business was down about 10% last quarter, year-over-year, and accelerated pretty substantially.
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on the Symmetrix business, which you just mentioned there, Joe. And specifically, if I'm not mistaken, [indiscernible] business was down about 10% last quarter, year-over-year, and accelerated pretty substantially. So if you did a [ph] correct that or maybe say what the sequential growth was, and then maybe just give a little more color of what's driving that. And then, finally, IBM mentioned in their call their mainframe cycle kicking in the second half. Any impact that might have on you guys on the Symmetrix?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, mainframe cycles always good for us, so on Symmetrix it's still --we’re still a major player there. But I think the big story is V-Max, the adoption and the opportunity that V-Max gives us. And, of course, the two big things with V-Max is the fact
componenttext: Well, mainframe cycles always good for us, so on Symmetrix it's still --we’re still a major player there. But I think the big story is V-Max, the adoption and the opportunity that V-Max gives us. And, of course, the two big things with V-Max is the fact, the way we’ve planned this from the beginning to really optimize the use of flash drives and then our FAST technology, which tiers storage automatically. So whether it puts it on dramatically different cost structure, whether it puts it on a flash drive, say a 15K Fibre Channel drive or a two terabyte SATA drive or two terabyte SATA drive, de-duped.  I mean, these are very different cost profiles on the customer, and therefore our customer can set a policy and let us just move the data automatically. And, of course, as we have thousands of customers that now have over a petabyte of data, this automation is what has to happen. I mean, that's what kind of one of the basic tenets of even of private cloud. It’s becoming -- so that you got to trust the automation to help you get the productivity and that trust is there in Symmetrix. And I think that's the big reason it did well. And also, to be fair, Symmetrix did benefit from some of the pent-up demand from last year's hiatus, so to speak.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Kevin, just to clarify, the numbers that you asked about. Basically, Symmetrix was up sequentially 7% from Q4, which obviously reflects a very strong result. Typically, you would expect a sequential decline from Q4. And as we explained the on last ca
componenttext: And, Kevin, just to clarify, the numbers that you asked about. Basically, Symmetrix was up sequentially 7% from Q4, which obviously reflects a very strong result. Typically, you would expect a sequential decline from Q4. And as we explained the on last call for Q4, the Q4 results were down 14% year-on-year, which actually was the best year-on-year comparison we had in 2009 for Symmetrix.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Toni Sacconaghi from Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Toni Sacconaghi from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment on gross margins in the quarter relative to your expectations. Looked like there were a lot of really positive forces. V-Max went up, you had exceptionally strong performance from both VMware and dedup [deduplication]
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment on gross margins in the quarter relative to your expectations. Looked like there were a lot of really positive forces. V-Max went up, you had exceptionally strong performance from both VMware and dedup [deduplication] which are higher margin. So I actually would have thought maybe gross margins on a sequential basis could have done a little bit better. Can you comment on whether gross margins, given those considerations, were in line with your expectations and what you saw both in the pricing environment, and any reinvestments that you would've made?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Toni, you're right in terms of what some of the positives were. A better mix from some of the dedup products, including Avamar and V-Max, has certainly helped. Obviously, sequentially, volumes are in total down, so you have to factor that in. The are
componenttext: Yes, Toni, you're right in terms of what some of the positives were. A better mix from some of the dedup products, including Avamar and V-Max, has certainly helped. Obviously, sequentially, volumes are in total down, so you have to factor that in. The area that you're probably -- is a little different from what you may have expected is, if you look at the services component of gross margin, which you can get to either with the stand-alone results or by pulling out VMware, what you’ll see is a fairly large decline sequentially in the services gross margin for a few factors. One is we are building up our Consulting and Professional Services business. That has a lower margin mix and that was a high percentage of the business. And also on the services side, bear in mind we reinstated the 5% salary cuts this quarter. We had some fringe adjustments and a couple of other things happening to the services side. So the services gross margin sequentially was a little bit down more than it would've been or more than it was, for example, from the last Q4 to Q1. So that’s perhaps the difference between what you're expecting and your margin model.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And pricing was in line with your expectations across the marketplace?
componenttext: And pricing was in line with your expectations across the marketplace?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at the pricing trends and we look at the sequential and the year-on-year declines, we’d say we saw a pretty normal pricing environment. Now given the comments that Joe made, notwithstanding the comments that Joe made about it still bei
componenttext: Yes, when we look at the pricing trends and we look at the sequential and the year-on-year declines, we’d say we saw a pretty normal pricing environment. Now given the comments that Joe made, notwithstanding the comments that Joe made about it still being tough out there, but in terms of the impact of prices, pretty much in line with our expectations.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010

componenttext: Daniel Ives from FBR.

componenttext: How do closure rates in general compare to historical trends? And just anecdotally, is there anything that you saw that surprised you in talking to customers across the board throughout the quarter in terms of changing behavior? Thanks.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think – well, as David said, we saw a little bit better-than-normal calendarization. So obviously I would say we booked more earlier than we had certainly for the last four or five quarters. Some of that is because of the recovery. Some of that is
componenttext: No, I think – well, as David said, we saw a little bit better-than-normal calendarization. So obviously I would say we booked more earlier than we had certainly for the last four or five quarters. Some of that is because of the recovery. Some of that is because of the advances we had in the product families, like V-Max kind of hit its stride now. But so the closure rates were a little better than they normally were, so sales cycles were a little shorter

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian Freed at Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Brian Freed at Morgan Keegan.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at competitors and as they move toward integrated products, you often see it take a long time to do software integration. You guys talked a lot about unified platforms, yet you have a lot of distinct personalities within your Storage infrastru
componenttext: If you look at competitors and as they move toward integrated products, you often see it take a long time to do software integration. You guys talked a lot about unified platforms, yet you have a lot of distinct personalities within your Storage infrastructure. Does virtualization allow you to unify them without a big overhead of software integration?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The bigger is the Intel multi-core. And it takes time to rework your products, but it gives you the ability, now, with multi-core, in reworking some of your products into a more thread-like approach, so to speak. That helps a lot, and you're right, there
componenttext: The bigger is the Intel multi-core. And it takes time to rework your products, but it gives you the ability, now, with multi-core, in reworking some of your products into a more thread-like approach, so to speak. That helps a lot, and you're right, there are products that we are putting natively under VMware, and that overhead now is drastically reduced and gives us opportunity. So it's a combination of multi-core and virtualization. But mostly the native use of multi-core that we're doing.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010

componenttext: It's well-known that the new VCX will be out in Q2, so could you see customers stall in the mid-range in anticipation of the refreshed product? And if not, then why not?

componenttext: I probably shouldn't say this, but that's not true. VCX will not be out. First of all, I’m not going to say that that’s the name of the product. We have not named it yet, but certainly, the blogosphere has named it. I kind of like the name, by the way, but it will not be out in Q2.

componenttext: So you don’t see customers stalls in the mid-range?
