headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to EMC's call to discuss our financial results for the second quarter of 2010. Today, we are joined by Joe Tucci, EMC Chairman and CEO; and David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comm
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to EMC's call to discuss our financial results for the second quarter of 2010. Today, we are joined by Joe Tucci, EMC Chairman and CEO; and David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results we have released this morning. He will highlight some of EMC's activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for 2010. Joe will then spend some time discussing his view of what is happening in the market, EMC's execution of the strategy and how EMC is positioned to help customers on The Journey to the Private Cloud. After the prepared remarks, we will then open up the lines to take your questions.  
I would like to point out that we will be referring to non-GAAP numbers in today's presentation unless otherwise indicated. The reconciliation of our non-GAAP comments to our GAAP results can be found in the disclosure today in our press release, supplemental schedules and the slides that accompany our presentation. All of these are available for download within the Investor Relations section of emc.com.
As always, we have provided detailed financial tables in our news release and on our corporate website. These include a lot of financial detail, so we do encourage you to take a look at them. The call this morning will contain forward-looking statements and information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ can be found in EMC's filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. And lastly, I will note that an archive of today's presentation will be available following the call. 
With that, it's now my pleasure to introduce David Goulden. David?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another good quarter due to strong demand for our market-leading solutions, our solid business model and great execution by the team. There a
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another good quarter due to strong demand for our market-leading solutions, our solid business model and great execution by the team. There are many highlights this quarter including record future revenues of over $4 billion, up 24%, and record Q2 non-GAAP net income of $596 million, up 66%. Non-GAAP EPS of $0.28, up a robust 56%. Our Storage business was up 21%. VMware revenue, 48% over last year. Free cash flow was $1.6 billion for the first half, up 47%, and non-GAAP operating margin of 20.7% improved 120 bps sequentially.
Once again, we achieved our triple play. We gained market share, invested for the future and improved profitability. Within our consolidated revenue, which is up 24%, we saw excellent growth storage, as I mentioned, of 21% year-on-year. Security revenue grew 18%. Our Information Intelligence Group revenue was roughly flat and VMware revenue grew an impressive 48%.
Now let's take a closer look at some of the details in these business units. Within Storage in the high end, Symmetrix part revenues were up 32% year-on-year, as customers are embracing the capabilities of a high-end solution. As the most powerful and scalable storage solution on the market today, VMAX clearly addresses customer's needs as they build-out their Private Cloud infrastructures.
Our Fully Automated Storage Tiering software known as FAST, is driving higher rates of SSD and ATA-base storage in these systems, resulting in huge performance and cost improvements for our customers.
As anticipated, following the introduction of FAST, we've seen penetration rates continue to rise in terms of SSD capacity per system, percentage of systems shipped with SSD and the proportion of systems being shipped with FAST. The combination of SSD and ATA drives with FAST software yield a solution with performance, scalability and cost effectiveness that's unmatched by our competitors.
Our VPLEX platform, which we announced in May, is a net new opportunity and it's proving to be a unique differentiator that is resonating with customers. Its technology is very complementary to Tiered Storage, as the combination of tiering with the mobility from VPLEX creates entirely new usage models that's on our deal Virtual Storage infrastructure for the Private Cloud. As we see the virtualization, where apps are consolidated onto one server and then could be mobilized over many servers, Virtual Storage creates an elastic pool of storage wherein which you can tier data and with VPLEX, move data across arrays within and between data centers.
Our technology lead also extends to our mid-tier storage offerings. As you will recall, last quarter, we expanded our disclosure to give you better insight into our progress in the mid-tier overall, taking into account the mix shift occurring among the our mid-tier products. The many use cases of multiple technologies available in the mid-tier have driven customers to demand ease of use and simplicity, as well as the right technology for the rights job. 
The strength and breadth of our Technology portfolio help to satisfy these customer requirements better than anyone else. Our approach is to continue to invest in our market leading block file and object storage products while converging technologies and products where it makes sense for simplicity and efficiency. This ongoing strategy resulted in mid-tier product growth in Q2, increasing to 33% year-on-year. Sequential growth was 12%. This is very good growth, especially given the fact that majority of mid-tier revenue currently comes from the high end of the mid-tier markets. 
In addition to being the overall leader in mid-tier storage, EMC continues to be the leader in the more mature Fibre Channel-only mid-tier markets. While the Fibre Channel market is very important, we're also seeing higher growth opportunities in other areas of the mid-tier. Some of this growth is in the form of a mix shift from traditional Fibre-only products to next-generation products like our very successful dedupe products and the fast-growing unified, multi-protocol NS Celerra offerings we introduced a few years ago.
For example, what might have been a traditionally been a CLARiiON Disk Library sale might now be a Data Domain dedupe deal. Now as the mid-tier market continues to evolve, we enlocks that with customers making the transition to next-generation solutions. What really sets our mid-tier solutions apart is our technology edge, coupled with simplicity and efficiency and this is driving our growth across the mid-tier.
EMC is considerably more efficient from a capacity standpoint versus competitive solutions, and we guarantee it. EMC enables better scalability as customers wanted to add capacity while retaining high performance and high storage utilization levels. EMC is optimized for virtual environments in ways that make a noticeable difference to the customers resulting in EMC being the clear storage vendor choice for virtualized environments. Much of this preference is due to the efforts we've made to have the best integration with VMware virtual environments. For example, EMC is the only storage band that fully support the four VMware storage APIs for vCenter Site Recovery Manager, Data Protection, Multi- passing and the just-introduced Array Integration API.
EMC puts more effort and resources into this tight integration and customers can tell the difference. Today, EMC has far and away to launch installed base in VMware environments. And according to a Spending Intention Survey recently conducted by major independent analyst firm, VMware customers are more than twice as likely to choose EMC to storage than any other vendor.
As you know, software functionality is increasingly the key to competitive differentiation in the mid-tier. And this quarter, we'll be shipping exciting, new, next-gen software technologies the further extend the capabilities of our market-leading CLARiiON and Celerra platforms. Since announcing these technologies at EMC World in May, customer anticipation has been very high, as they offer set of functionalities that no other vendor can match. We're releasing a major step toward in management with Unisphere with an advanced and easy-to-use interface to manage both Celerra and CLARiiON. We're building on our unique FAST technology in the mid-tier with FAST v2, which delivers several on performance analysis and data relocation. We're providing customers with a new capability called FAST Cache, enabling customers to utilize solid-state storage that increase cache size adverse requirements. And we're introducing lock compression for primary storage which yields an average of 50% improvement in storage consumption.
So to summarize our position in the mid-tier, first of all, EMC is already the technology leader in the traditional mid-tier stand in that environments. Secondly, EMC is also leading in some of the most important new technologies such as dedupe Unified Storage and Virtualization Infinity. And third, EMC continues to add major next-generation software functions that further extend our technological lead.
When you put it altogether, EMC is the only company that's positioned across the mid-tier. Our competitive edge continues to grow and as a result, it's pretty clear that EMC should be able to continue to gain share in the mid-tier.
Before moving on, I know there's been a lot of interest in our strategy around our unified product family. Let me clarify this a bit for you. For a number of years, we've offered multi-protocol storage on one hardware platform, namely SAN, both Fibre Channel and iSCSI and NAS in a box. And this multi-protocol Celerra, this multi-protocol NS Celerra has been one of our fastest-growing products ever since. 
As I already said, in a few weeks, we're releasing single management interface, Unisphere, for our block and file functionalities. What we're maintaining is our market leading SAN and NAS technologies have been optimized for the different data requirements customers have because one size does not fit all when it comes to this requirements.
In essence, NS Celerra now has best-of-breed, file-and-block functionality with advance next-generation software, including a single management interface, FAST Cache, dedupe and compression on one common high-performance hardware platform. This combination presents the most cost-effective, most reliable and easy-to-use unified solution while retaining the native functionalities that customers value. I might also add that we've recently integrated Atmos with Celerra, adding object capabilities to our flagship unified storage platform.
And as I mentioned earlier, our success in the mid-tier has come principally from the higher end of the market. We plan to extend our success in the mid-tier to the faster-growing lower end of the market with a new product family, featuring EMC's market-leading technologies, our prices will be very competitive in this space. As such, we're also investing in the right people, the right partners to aggressively market this new family, which we expect to formally introduce very early next year.
Our Backup Recovery Systems business had another stellar quarter and continue to overachieve against plan in Q2. When we acquired Data Domain a year ago, we had a pretty good idea of the power that could be unleashed by combining their data deduplication technology with Avamar and our extensive customer reach, and in Q2, revenue from Avamar and Data Domain continue to grow from the billion-dollar revenue run rate we reported last quarter. 
There is great demand for this simple and efficient next-generation backup technology because it addresses one of the biggest pain points in the data center. We acquired over 350 new Data Domain customers in Q2 alone and more than 200 new Avamar customers.
Our BRS division continues to make strides against competitors with the release earlier this week of several new capabilities, including a new midrange system that leverages Nehalem technology to drive high levels of performance and capacity, a deduplication expansion option for EMC Disk Library for mainframe, an increased scalability of the EMC Disk Library series. In short, this division is performing very well and the acquisition of Data Domain completed a year ago this Friday has already shown itself to be one of our best ever.
Clearly, we are gaining share in storage, and the reasons for this is straightforward. Customers are not only seeking out larger trusted vendors with established track records, but they want a partner with a clear roadmap, innovative products and a breadth of capabilities for taking full advantage of cloud efficiencies going forward. EMC fits the bill in both areas.
Our RSA Security revenue growth accelerates in Q2 to 18% year-on-year, coming in at $173 million. We saw strength across the board in security. R/3 is thriving, and we're benefiting from the combination of its audit capabilities with our security information and event management and data loss prevention technologies. More than ever, deal discussions taking place at the CIO and CISO level together as customers seek security that is built in rather than bolted on. Our data-centric approach is especially resonant with customers, as security is an enabler for broad adoption of cloud infrastructures. Accordingly, what we continue to invest and leverage our unique position and take advantage of the immense opportunity to secure these next-gen infrastructures.
Our Information Intelligence Group, formerly known as Content Management and Archiving reported revenues of $178 million, relatively flat from last year's Q2. Our xCP Composition Platform and our eDiscovery Solutions are resonating well with customers.
VMware revenue within EMC grew 48% year-on-year to $673 million. This Q2 record revenue was driven by strength across geographies, products and customer segments from SMB up through the enterprise. Virtualization of the server infrastructure is the first step towards cloud computing, and it's clear that customers are laying the foundation for their cloud architectures with VMware. This is not surprising given the gains and flexibility, efficiency and cost savings that cloud architectures offer, and the fact that VMware technology is several generations ahead of competitors.
Our four business years together represent a combined power of information and virtual infrastructures. The same fundamental shift in IT is driving the success of each. And together, we continue to move forward under shared vision and strategic direction that fully capture the opportunity to bounce over the next several years as customers embark on a journey to Private Cloud. Our VCE coalition is addressing its mission to accelerate the proliferation of cloud infrastructures. Customers eager to start realizing the benefits, reduce cost and improve business' agility. They're looking to VCE as a means to get there because it provides a way to significantly reduce risks, costs and time to value with ready-to-deploy could infrastructures.
A recent survey by Data Monitor and UBS indicates that the VCE coalition is far and away the preferred solution for data center modernization.
Our Consulting business also continues to thrive by guiding customers' transition to virtual data center architectures as EMC is a trusted advisor within the enterprise that enables customers to report with confidence.
As the only player offering virtual server and virtual storage infrastructures, coupled with advanced IT Security and Compliance and Information Intelligence, EMC is squarely focused on helping customers make this transition to next-generation  Private and Public Clouds.
Let me now give you a bit more color about what else happened in the quarter looking at our Geos. All our geographies contributed to year-over-year revenue growth in the quarter, with revenue up 28% in North America, 18% in EMEA, 20% in APJ and 22% in Latin America. In North America, we did see some weakness in federal governments that was more than offset by growth international services, GME and the commercial markets. 
Our international mix stood at 47% in Q2 with the largest portion of foreign revenue coming from Europe. Within Europe, there was a weakness in Spain, Portugal and Greece. And this was more than offset by strength in the UK, France, Northern Europe, Eastern Europe and Russia. Our growth in APJ was led by strength in India and China. Our focus on the BRIC + 13 Emerging Markets is yielding good growth again, with future revenue growth of over 30%.
So as you can see, EMC is a global company with operation in dozens of countries. Internationally, we do some business in dollars and some in local currencies. Some local currency business is hedged and some is not. And in some markets, we have local pricing plans and not another's. Given these and other factors, non-dollar currency effect, obviously, a complex internal equation and pretty much impossible to calculate for an X-deal prospective. So given your interest in this topic, I will try to net out the impact for your modeling purposes. While currency was neutral to our results in Q2, based on where rates were at June 30, we expect the currency will now be a one-point headwind for the full year 2010.
Now let's take a look at some of the income statement and balance sheet items. In Q2, EMC reported non-GAAP gross margin of 60.1%. Non-GAAP operating margin of 20.7% and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.28. Free cash flow for last 12 months was $3.1 billion, up over 20% from the comparable period and about $800 million higher than trailing 12-month non-GAAP net income. The excellent growth across these metrics demonstrates the improvements we've made to our business model over the last couple years are yielding the results we expected.
The Q2 non-GAAP tax rate was 24%. We now expect our full year non-GAAP tax rate to be close to 21%. This increase is due to higher expected contribution of profits from the U.S. due to currency, as well as some other factors. We do still expect the U.S. R&D tax rate take effect later this year.
DSOs came at 45 days compared to 52 for second quarter of 2009, inventory turns were 8.2 compared to 7.8 a year ago and deferred revenue is up nearly $100 million from last quarter.
We ended the quarter with $10.8 billion of cash. Of this, a total of $6.2 billion was held in the U.S. with the remainder overseas. We spent $341 million in the quarter buying 18.6 million shares of EMC stock, almost twice our Q1 level, bringing us up to over $500 million on EMC share repurchases so far this year. We still expect to spend $1 billion on EMC stock by the end of the year. In addition, EMC spent $99 million buying VMware shares, and VMware spent $130 million buying back VMware shares. Our VMware business is a key enabler that's making our cloud vision a reality.
While customers transition to Cloud is underway, the majority of the journey lies ahead of us, which is why we see the purchases of EMC and VMware as excellent investments.
As we look through the second half of 2010, our expectations to economic growth in IT spending for the full year really haven't changed that much. IT spending still looks to be up around 3% to 5% with our addressable market stronger, up around 6% to 8%. At the beginning of the year, we said we expect the economic recovery will be moderate with some bumps in the road, and that is what we're seeing. There are a few factors we didn't specifically anticipate such  the relative weakness of the euro and pound, our higher-projected tax rates and more cautious government spending in the U.S. and Europe. And we're obviously managing the impact of these very closely. However, in spite these challenges based upon the level of customer interest in our strategy and solutions, combined with the strength of our business including Storage and VMware, we now expect that we will exceed our previous outlook of $16.5 billion of revenue and $1.18 in non-GAAP EPS in 2010. 
Our Q2 results indicate that we are on the right track strategically in executing well on our triple play. We see no reason why we cannot continue to maintain this triple play over the long term. When thinking about this, it is worth noting that since we saw the expanding EMC's addressable markets in 2004, EMC's growth is impressive, with annual average revenue growth of 12% and annual average non-GAAP EPS growth of 19%. This is excellent performance over a six-year period, which included the '08 and '09 recession.
But today, our strategy is clear. The business model and operating model are in place. Our investments continue to pay off, and the Private Cloud opportunity is very big. EMC has never been better positioned for success than it is right now. And as a result, we believe we can continue to deliver double-digit revenue and double-digit earning growth for the next several years. 
I will now turn the call over to Joe, who'll provide some more color on what we're seeing in 2010 and explain why we're confident about double-digit growth going forward. Joe?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. I'd like to begin by adding my welcome to all of you who are attending today's conference call. Thanks for joining us. Overall, I was very pleased with our performance in Q2. We posted solid year-over-year and sequential growth numbers, w
componenttext:
Thanks, David. I'd like to begin by adding my welcome to all of you who are attending today's conference call. Thanks for joining us. 
Overall, I was very pleased with our performance in Q2. We posted solid year-over-year and sequential growth numbers, while establishing EMC and VMware as a thought leader in the next major wave of computing, mainly the transformation of IT to IT as a service, commonly called cloud computing.
This success would not have been possible without the hard work and dedication of the more than 45,000 people of EMC and VMware around the world. I'd like to thank them for their leadership and congratulate them on their accomplishments. I believe the top question on your mind has to be around the pockets of uncertainty that seem to pop up around the world and their effect on the global economy, and more specifically, how this will manifest itself in IT spending going forward.
As we have said before, EMC expected and planned for a recovery in 2010, but we always believed it would be choppy. So perhaps the best way to look at IT spending trends is by geography. U.S. market continues to be good with good prospects. Our customers here are investing in information technologies to increase their levels of productivity, while managing risk with a maniacal focus on maintaining stellar compliance with their policies, best practices and laws in land while insuring proper governance and oversight. 
Turning to the international markets, in Europe, we are seeing moderate growth in IT spend. Except in southern Europe where we're definitely seeing a slowdown in IT purchases. In Latin America, the Middle East, Africa, China, Southeast Asia and in selected Eastern European countries, IT spending is robust and is exhibiting very solid double-digit growth. And lastly, in Japan, we are seeing that spending is now improving a bit. 
And as David has already said, we were not affected by currency rates in Q2, but we most likely will be in the second half of this year. I want to make it clear, however, that with only 47% of our revenues coming from international markets, I truly believe we have ample opportunity for solid international growth despite likely currency fluctuations. We at EMC believe that international revenues should make up well over 50% of our total revenues and we're squarely focused on and investing in this growth opportunity for EMC.
Of importance, the global markets through virtualization, storage, data protection and data security, markets were consolidating EMC as the leader. We'll continue to grow faster in the IT market as a whole. And again, where it adds confidence to this growth statement is the thought leadership, innovations, and a strong product roadmap we have in the next new wave of IT cloud computing.
It is our firm belief that cloud computing will happen in both enterprise IT shops as customers transform the IT data centers into Private Clouds, as well as in the service-provided community, we will build out an extensive number of very large Public Clouds. These transformations will give CIOs the capabilities to offer their customers, whether they are internal customers or external customers, the massive benefits of IT as a service, namely the ability to run applications more flexibly at a lower cost while ensuring that the intended policies and service levels are adhered to.
To assure we capitalize on this massive broad opportunity, consolidated EMC's is focusing our technology and go-to market resources on providing our customers with the path, a measured journey to the Private Cloud. First and foremost, VMware is out advancing its leading virtualization technologies into a full-fledged next-generation data center cloud operating system with innovative and integrated management automation and orchestration software. Last week's introduction of  vSphere 4.1 is a major deliverable towards that goal. VM also uniquely automates both existing applications, as well as reaching out to the new wave development communities that tend to develop application in the framework context, a powerful benefit to customers as they journey through the Private Cloud. VMware also has the significant technology playing in bringing their virtualization technology to client devices, allowing for the provisioning of an individual, a user, rather than provision in constantly-changing sea of new devices that seem to come out as almost daily.
On the information side, EMC is focused on storing, managing, protecting and securing the incredible amount of new digital information that this world continues to create, with price performance levels that the future cloud world will demand. IDC, in a recent white paper, estimated that the amount of digital information that is created will grow a remarkable 44x between 2009 and 2020. 
EMC is heavily investing in innovative information technologies like VMAX, a new category storage that scales both up and out, offering unmatched cross-performance, functionality and reliability. Technologies like unified storage for converge fiber channel, SAN, NAS, and iSCSl environment, again, featuring leading functionality for mid-tier storage platforms. We are investing in game changing cloud technologies like VPLEX, our virtual storage product. VPLEX provides new capabilities like active/active data over distance and information federation across cloud data centers.
Since most of new information that is being created is object-phased, EMC is investing heavily on specialized cloud storage for this important category of information storage software called Atmos. We are investing in technologies like FAST, or Fully Automated Storage Tiering, that moves data automatically and in concert with the policy and service levels our customers choose between flash drives, fiber channel drives, SATA drives and SATA drives where the data is deduplicated and compressed. FAST is insured, innovative technology that assures ultra high performance when called for, will also optimize the total system for the lowest cost.
We are investing in technologies for data protection. Changing the backup paradigm from slow, unpredictable backup to tape to backup to disk with best-in-class data deduplication and compression technologies to offer customers speed of recovery, reliability recovery and low cost. We are investing in technologies that secure the data itself and access to the data while assuring stellar GRC metrics. 
A quick preview of things to come later this year. We will release the capability to encrypt data-at-rest on the array itself. That's fully integrated with RSA's key management software that is both cost effective and has very high performance. And lastly, we are investing heavily in our customers to gain value from their information -- to help our customers gain value from their information. Greenplum, our most recent acquisition, provides organizations of real time insight from vast amounts of data. Greenplum's unique massively-parallel, scale-out architecture provides the ability to handle big data and delivers information intelligence in real time. 
We will also continue to extend our Documentum software portfolio to help our customers better leverage information that is vital to their business. With our new Documentum xCP [xCelerated Composition Platform] platform, we are enabling companies to move from traditional and complex enterprise content management applications to far more flexible case management applications. In short, xCP dramatically reduces the amount of custom code that is typically required, thus saving customers time and money. 
Another important piece of our cloud strategy is the deep partnership and alliances that we have built with other leading IT companies. Partners like Cisco via our VCE [Virtual Computing Environment] coalition. And I am happy to report that under the leadership of Michael Capellas, VCE's reception by our customers has been nothing short of remarkable, and Vblock sales are well ahead of plan.
I'm also pleased to report that our partnership with Dell is back on track and is very strategic to both companies. Our Q2 mid-tier storage revenues were roughly flat year-on-year with Dell, and we fully expect to have year-on-year mid-tier growth with them in the second half. Our partnerships with system integrators such as Accenture, CSC, Capgemini, Wipro, TCS [Tata Consultancy Services] and Deloitte and others continue to grow strategically and tactically. And lastly, on the service provider front, we are building a number of very deep alliances, and we will be talking to you soon about our initiatives and plans here.
In summary, EMC is executing very well today's IT market. We have a strong product and technology portfolio and the go-to-market prowess to create the opportunities that the next wave of IT, cloud computing will offer. Thus, I reaffirm our belief that we can achieve double-digit growth rates over the long term. 
Let me now turn it back to Tony to moderate the Q&A portion of today's call.

componenttext: Just as a follow-up, VMAX seemed very strong in the quarter. Was that sort of the core driver for the strength in gross margin within the core business group, or were there some other drivers that we should be thinking about?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Within the Storage business, we saw a nice sequential growth in gross margin. On the product side, we had some good mix impact. If you look, obviously sequentially, actually VMAX is relatively flat, but we did see good growth in the DD products and a
componenttext: No. Within the Storage business, we saw a nice sequential growth in gross margin. On the product side, we had some good mix impact. If you look, obviously sequentially, actually VMAX is relatively flat, but we did see good growth in the DD products and a couple other things that's driving higher margins. Obviously, volume helped us with gross margins on the product side. And on the services side, we actually saw a nice pick-up in our professional services margin due to high utilization. And on the customer services side, revenue increased and we continue to keep our cost base relatively flat as we improve the efficiency of that business. So good improvements across the board deeply sequentially in the core business and margins.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Aaron Rakers of Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Aaron Rakers of Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is also on the margin, though more so on the operating margin side. If I look back historically guys, for the second half relative to the first half of the year, it looks like ex 2009, you were able to drive about 200 to maybe even 300 basis p
componenttext: My question is also on the margin, though more so on the operating margin side. If I look back historically guys, for the second half relative to the first half of the year, it looks like ex 2009, you were able to drive about 200 to maybe even 300 basis points of operating margin expansion. Yesterday, we saw VMware raise their operating margin target for the full year. You guys today talk about lowering or tempering your R&D growth for the full year. So I'm curious why 20% to 21% can't actually be moved higher here given those puts and takes?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just handle a point you mentioned about R&D. It's a very minor change. Internally, it's less than $15 million. So it doesn't really move the needle on margins. We still have internal plans to hire up to the 20% level, but we're just not quite on tr
componenttext: Let me just handle a point you mentioned about R&D. It's a very minor change. Internally, it's less than $15 million. So it doesn't really move the needle on margins. We still have internal plans to hire up to the 20% level, but we're just not quite on track against that right now.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just add a little color here. We have not cut back R&D budgets. Our R&D teams are still encouraged to find the best people, very high quality people and staff up. Obviously, they're being very picky. They're hiring a little slower than actually I w
componenttext: Let me just add a little color here. We have not cut back R&D budgets. Our R&D teams are still encouraged to find the best people, very high quality people and staff up. Obviously, they're being very picky. They're hiring a little slower than actually I would like, but we are not cutting back R&D budget. This is just kind of a reality. Right, David?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Right. In that way, that's a very small factor in the overall margin performance. I think what you're going to recognize is the 2010 is not really a normal year. I'm trying to apply normalcy [ph] to 2010. I think it's going to get us into a little bit of
componenttext: Right. In that way, that's a very small factor in the overall margin performance. I think what you're going to recognize is the 2010 is not really a normal year. I'm trying to apply normalcy [ph] to 2010. I think it's going to get us into a little bit of trouble. What I mean by that is clearly, we mentioned in Q1, we saw the impact of some positive budget flush, which we've done a little bit better than we expected in Q2. But I told you there was some factors in the second half that going to impact those kind of normal year-on-year compares, and we've got some significant currency headwinds in the second half, which is going to always impact our top line. Most of the things that drive the margin improvement historically from a first half to second half account volume rates [ph]. If you're going to tie back to that, we still feel comfortable in the 20% to 21% range. Obviously, we'd like to come in towards the higher end of that. But we're not making increase at this point in time.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian Marshall, Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: Brian Marshall, Gleacher & Company.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the second half outlook, due to some of the potential product transitions that might be occurring down the road in the mid-range, do you think it's likely that VMAX will actually outgrow the mid-range in unified products in the second half
componenttext: With regard to the second half outlook, due to some of the potential product transitions that might be occurring down the road in the mid-range, do you think it's likely that VMAX will actually outgrow the mid-range in unified products in the second half of the year?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: VMAX, because it's a new category and I keep referring to traditionally all high-end systems, which is still true today with the exception of VMAX, scale up. VMAX, we can now add what we call engines, which are servers, to have it just scale out. And when
componenttext: VMAX, because it's a new category and I keep referring to traditionally all high-end systems, which is still true today with the exception of VMAX, scale up. VMAX, we can now add what we call engines, which are servers, to have it just scale out. And when we do that to add a server and put a whole tier of SATA drives or dedupes, or in the future even dedupe SATA drives there, it makes it very effective to consolidate a lot of mid-tier platform. So some of our growth is coming out of the higher end of mid-tier as we consolidate mid-tier platforms. So while VMAX, you can think of it as a high-end platform, it certainly is. It is definitely, definitely have an impact on the mid-tier as we consolidate there.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And as a quick follow-up, I would assume that, that would have a positive margin impact as well?
componenttext: And as a quick follow-up, I would assume that, that would have a positive margin impact as well?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As we've said many times, ironically, they're both good. I mean, if we grow mid-tier, we get good margins. With the growth at high end, we get good margins. So they're not as substantially different as they were at one time years ago.
componenttext: As we've said many times, ironically, they're both good. I mean, if we grow mid-tier, we get good margins. With the growth at high end, we get good margins. So they're not as substantially different as they were at one time years ago.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ben Reitzes of Barclays.
componenttext: Ben Reitzes of Barclays.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you guys talk about velocity of business throughout the quarter and into next, and what you think about second have seasonality given currency? I guess it's about $150 million of a currency hit you guys are talking about for the second half that you a
componenttext: Can you guys talk about velocity of business throughout the quarter and into next, and what you think about second have seasonality given currency? I guess it's about $150 million of a currency hit you guys are talking about for the second half that you absorb. So what does that do to seasonality that you expect as we go into the third and fourth quarter, and how you exited the second quarter?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ben. You got the map on the currency impact from where we thought we were back in April. Obviously, on an absolute basis year-on-year, the currency impact is bigger than that. But compared to where we thought we were back in April, the currency chang
componenttext: Yes, Ben. You got the map on the currency impact from where we thought we were back in April. Obviously, on an absolute basis year-on-year, the currency impact is bigger than that. But compared to where we thought we were back in April, the currency change is about $150 million because we thought for the full year we'd be roughly flat back then. So that is a factor. During the quarter in Q2, we're back to regularly normal seasonality. We mentioned that we saw some earlier seasonality in Q1 because of some kind of spillover. But I think what we saw in Q2 was a more normal demand environment. I mean, I think we really put our overachievement down the fact that people just got an appetite for all our products and services because they're just satisfying customers paying points as well. So I think those are kind of the obvious [ph] key facts. I think one of the biggest differences that you mentioned before from where we were in April was about currency headwinds.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then heading into the back half, what do you think that you have enough momentum with the new product that's coming and new software and the VMAX and what not to have normal seasonality in the back half?
componenttext: And then heading into the back half, what do you think that you have enough momentum with the new product that's coming and new software and the VMAX and what not to have normal seasonality in the back half?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that if you just look at our guidance, I mean, we came out of the first half obviously better than expected. When we look ahead, we're very confident about what we're seeing in the second half in terms of customer acceptance for our products
componenttext: Well, I think that if you just look at our guidance, I mean, we came out of the first half obviously better than expected. When we look ahead, we're very confident about what we're seeing in the second half in terms of customer acceptance for our products and services. And in fact, we've raised our guidance. We said that we're going to beat what we talked about in April. So we're more confident now than we were in April, especially when you normalize for some of the headwinds.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark Kelleher of Brigantine Advisors.
componenttext: Mark Kelleher of Brigantine Advisors.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to focus on the federal government vertical. There are some big initiatives there to move IT out into the cloud. That seems like it should be right in your mill house. Can you tell us what you're seeing there? You said there was some weakness lifte
componenttext: I want to focus on the federal government vertical. There are some big initiatives there to move IT out into the cloud. That seems like it should be right in your mill house. Can you tell us what you're seeing there? You said there was some weakness lifted, dynamic and visibility in the federal government?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, unfortunately, Mark, it's both. If you talk to the powers to be in IT and federal government, they are very sold on the cloud. And I truly believe they realize the capability that collectively, EMC and VMware bring to the party and that's good news.
componenttext: Well, unfortunately, Mark, it's both. If you talk to the powers to be in IT and federal government, they are very sold on the cloud. And I truly believe they realize the capability that collectively, EMC and VMware bring to the party and that's good news. On the other side, you also saw that they kind of tried to put a bit of a freeze on IT spending. So we saw a little bit of weakness in Q2, and as David said, governments around the world as they try to kind of rein in their spending a bit. So we kind of have one good run from column A and one kind of negative trend from column B, and I actually think they're both true. So I do think the government will make a massive play that's much more efficient way and much more flexible way to do IT into the cloud, and we'll benefit from that. And on the other side, as the government cuts back on its day-to-day spending,  you get hurt by that side.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Normal seasonality for the government into Q3?
componenttext: Normal seasonality for the government into Q3?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: If I was guessing, and it is a guess right now because we'll see how Q3 unfolds. But obviously, I probably at Q3, even though it's the government fiscal end and it's usually strong, I think it'll be a little softer than normal. Although you'll see some up
componenttext: If I was guessing, and it is a guess right now because we'll see how Q3 unfolds. But obviously, I probably at Q3, even though it's the government fiscal end and it's usually strong, I think it'll be a little softer than normal. Although you'll see some uptick, obviously, from Q2 but probably not as big as normal.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ittai Kidron of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Ittai Kidron of Oppenheimer.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us some more color on the mid-tier? You mentioned 33% year-over-year growth, but if you take out the Backup and Recovery, Avamar and Data Domain, what was the growth of the other businesses, CLARiiON, specifically, and Celerra?
componenttext: Can you give us some more color on the mid-tier? You mentioned 33% year-over-year growth, but if you take out the Backup and Recovery, Avamar and Data Domain, what was the growth of the other businesses, CLARiiON, specifically, and Celerra?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't have a break out into the product lines, but let me tell you that if you added in the revenues from Data Domain a year ago, the growth actually increased a little bit from Q1. Remember, we said the apples-to-apples growth in Q1 was 20%. The compa
componenttext: We don't have a break out into the product lines, but let me tell you that if you added in the revenues from Data Domain a year ago, the growth actually increased a little bit from Q1. Remember, we said the apples-to-apples growth in Q1 was 20%. The comparable apples-to-apples growth in Q2 is 21%. So then, of course, within that, as we mentioned, we got different transitions going on within the products. It doesn't makes sense to break out numbers to the individual products themselves.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on that. In your discussions with your customers, given that there's this expectation of a new platform, are you seeing any customers delaying or sitting on the sidelines and waiting for the new platform to come along? Any purchasing deci
componenttext: Just a follow-up on that. In your discussions with your customers, given that there's this expectation of a new platform, are you seeing any customers delaying or sitting on the sidelines and waiting for the new platform to come along? Any purchasing decisions delayed because of this?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me say two things. I mean, the number that David gave you, that little bit over 21% growth year-on-year, is the way to look at it because as David said, our sales force is good and has a lot of sway with customers. And for sure, we would've sold some
componenttext: Let me say two things. I mean, the number that David gave you, that little bit over 21% growth year-on-year, is the way to look at it because as David said, our sales force is good and has a lot of sway with customers. And for sure, we would've sold some more of our own devices like CLARiiON Disk Libraries, which now, we're forcing and it's setting our sales force to ship the Data Domain product. So the best way to look a this is, apples-to-apples, is assuming we own Data Domain a year ago, and we obviously do own them today, that difference in growth all in mid-tier, which is maybe in the product only is over 21%. So it's very solid growth, and it's real growth. The second question you're asking is you want more color, I think, on what our plans are for our mid-tier refresh. We have started and worked incredibly successfully when we announced -- before we announced VPLEX, what we did is put out a big piece of the software to bake it in to our then DMX-4 line, so that you're not announcing all new software and all new hardware at the same time. We basically like that model so much, and customers adopted it so much, we're doing the same thing now. So what you just saw and David took you through, FAST Cache, Flash, Unisphere, several other -- pretty good laundry list of products, that is the new operating system that will be on the refresh hardware products. We told you, David just told you that our new low end will be introduced in Q1, alright. We also told you that the fastest growing piece of mid-tier by far, and I mean by far, is the low end. So we are very optimistic about this new low end and the impact it's going to have. So last piece you want to know is when are we going to introduce the high end of mid-tier. I got to have some surprises in life, so I'm not going to give you that one, but again, software first. We told you when we're going to do the low end. And I like our position in the mid-tier, and I think it's going to continue to get stronger and stronger.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Richard Gardner of Citigroup.
componenttext: Richard Gardner of Citigroup.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, last quarter you were willing to give us actually a point number for the mid-range revenue. I was wondering if you'd be willing to give that number again this quarter?
componenttext: Dave, last quarter you were willing to give us actually a point number for the mid-range revenue. I was wondering if you'd be willing to give that number again this quarter?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, I told you it was up 12%, so you can figure that out.
componenttext: Rich, I told you it was up 12%, so you can figure that out.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I wanted to follow up on an earlier question regarding operating margins. I know that you said you're not ready to take up your operating margin guidance from the 20% to 21% level for the current year, but it does seem like you can make a pretty
componenttext: And then I wanted to follow up on an earlier question regarding operating margins. I know that you said you're not ready to take up your operating margin guidance from the 20% to 21% level for the current year, but it does seem like you can make a pretty compelling case for a continued rise in information storage margins. Thanks to increasing software mix and hardware cost improvements over time. And I'm just wondering if philosophically that's the right way to think about things longer term, or whether you will choose to actively manage long-term operating margins to the 20% to 21% level and invest most of that back at the top line growth?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, I think I've kind of given you a couple of key hints on that, but let me make it clear. I mean, first of all, we should be very pleased that we have operating margins to where we are today. For a long period of time, we've been trying to get operati
componenttext: Rich, I think I've kind of given you a couple of key hints on that, but let me make it clear. I mean, first of all, we should be very pleased that we have operating margins to where we are today. For a long period of time, we've been trying to get operating margin north of 20%. We are there today, and I think that's excellent progress and obviously is a result of what we've done in terms of mix and cost management and a whole bunch of good things across the business. Also, I've talked to you about our triple play where we want to have a balance between gaining market share, investing for the future and improving profitability. And we said over the long term, we will be focused on being able to deliver all three of those. There will be some balance between any one over a period of time. But over time, we plan to deliver all three. So we do have an eye upon expanding operating margins over time. But also we talked about a significant investment in cloud software repositioning so we can position ourselves throughout the public and private clouds, so we will have a balance between all three. We've committed also over the next few years, we'll give you at least double-digit revenue and double-digit earnings growth. So I think we've given you a number of indicators to say that we are focus upon all three. We're certainly not going backwards, and we will, over time, be able to expand our operating margins as well. It's really a balance, and we'll play that balance carefully and we'll communicate to you where we are at any point in time in that balance.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Kaushik Roy of Wedbush.
componenttext: Kaushik Roy of Wedbush.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: One clarification. In the prepared remarks, you mentioned Symmetrix product revenues grew 32% year-over-year, and mid-tier product revenues grew 33% year-over-year. But in the press release, the total products are up only 27% year-over-year. Can help us understand that?

componenttext: I was just looking at the press release to see exactly what you're referring to?

componenttextpreview: The Storage product, it's $2,077,000, which is up 27% year-over-year.
componenttext: The Storage product, it's $2,077,000, which is up 27% year-over-year.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're looking at the schedule attached to the press release. I'm looking at Storage product growth. So there are some other things in there including things like SAN switches, some resold product through our Select line. There are things in the tota
componenttext: Yes, you're looking at the schedule attached to the press release. I'm looking at Storage product growth. So there are some other things in there including things like SAN switches, some resold product through our Select line. There are things in the total Storage product. We gave you the kind of two major parts of it.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: And the mid-tier product revenues is up 33%. Is it apples to apples? That means, does it include Data Domain as if you had Data Domain in Q2?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. The apples to apples, that's slightly over 21%.
componenttext: No. The apples to apples, that's slightly over 21%.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Apples-to-apples growth for mid-tier is 21%. As we mentioned a little bit before, 33% is the reported revenue growth. Now as we said, the real way to kind of judge our performance in how we're doing in the mid-tier is the 21%, which again, we think is goo
componenttext: Apples-to-apples growth for mid-tier is 21%. As we mentioned a little bit before, 33% is the reported revenue growth. Now as we said, the real way to kind of judge our performance in how we're doing in the mid-tier is the 21%, which again, we think is good given our position in the high end of the mid-tier. But also, I think our sequential improvement in the mid-tier of 12% quarter-on-quarter is also a good indicator.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, just to net it out in the mid-tier, we're kind of killing it in the higher end, because you got to also add not only the 21% but part of that reason that VMAX is 32% is we're consolidating mid-tier there, too. So we put that together you could say,
componenttext: Again, just to net it out in the mid-tier, we're kind of killing it in the higher end, because you got to also add not only the 21% but part of that reason that VMAX is 32% is we're consolidating mid-tier there, too. So we put that together you could say, "Wow! You're doing really well in mid-tier and the higher end." Now we really don't have a big play yet in the lower end, which we know are growing faster. So that's the comment that we gave you to date for that, which is really Q1.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.
componenttext: Wamsi Mohan, Bank of America.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about your longer-term enterprise data warehousing strategy, which can be a meaningful adjacent market? It seems like an obvious extension to your current strategy. But I'm curious why you chose to not go after a more established
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about your longer-term enterprise data warehousing strategy, which can be a meaningful adjacent market? It seems like an obvious extension to your current strategy. But I'm curious why you chose to not go after a more established [indiscernible] or Netezza and enter the market, put some scale as opposed to what could take some time with Greenplum to capture a meaningful part of the market?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll do more as it goes up, but let me give you a short piece of our thinking. Traditionally, the data warehouse market looks like last month's, last week's kind of data. And more and more our customers want to look at real time data that's in there comi
componenttext: We'll do more as it goes up, but let me give you a short piece of our thinking. Traditionally, the data warehouse market looks like last month's, last week's kind of data. And more and more our customers want to look at real time data that's in there coming out of their systems right now. And obviously, when you get to a cloud kind of scale, what you want to do -- you work hard to put data into the cloud, you don't want to pick data out of the cloud, specialize it to do a analytics on, right? So basically, the Greenplum technology works extremely well, better than anything else we saw on the market in that kind of environment. But when you're talking about real time, when you're talking about big data, when you're talking about cloud scale data, we think the attributes of Greenplum, and the way it also works in a virtualized environment, is phenomenal. So we went after what we thought was the best technology, and we got plenty of go-to-market prowess around it. And as you said, it's a close affinity to what we do. So we're quite pleased. This plays out for our future strategy.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Louis Miscioscia of Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Louis Miscioscia of Collins Stewart.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can we go back to the macro for a second? I guess we can look at this two different ways. One, last night on VMware's HUB, it did express a lot of concern about Europe. And then second, Joe, when you're talking to C-level executives, what are they telling
componenttext: Can we go back to the macro for a second? I guess we can look at this two different ways. One, last night on VMware's HUB, it did express a lot of concern about Europe. And then second, Joe, when you're talking to C-level executives, what are they telling you about their desire to continue to spend on IT given the concern about the macro economy?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, right now, as I said in my remarks, the biggest thing that executives are interested in is driving their productivity, which you could say on the other side hurts a little bit in terms of the unemployment that's out there. But everybody -- right n
componenttext: I mean, right now, as I said in my remarks, the biggest thing that executives are interested in is driving their productivity, which you could say on the other side hurts a little bit in terms of the unemployment that's out there. But everybody -- right now companies say look, it's an uncertain world. I got to get differentiation out there, and I want to drive my productivity. And they know that probably the only way to do that is to investment in technology, and I think that's one of the things that's benefiting IT as a whole right now. As I said on the other side, the other big macro trend that I mentioned is at the board level, the focus on risk management and compliance is phenomenal. On the macro side, those are two things that we see out there. Normally, you see that globally. Certainly, you see it in the United States and Europe.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that the comments last night where VMware did seem much more cautious on Europe, and maybe your comments and maybe just clarify your views...
componenttext: I think that the comments last night where VMware did seem much more cautious on Europe, and maybe your comments and maybe just clarify your views...

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] We still think Europe will have moderate growth, as I said, with the exception of Southern Europe, where I did say we are seeing definite downturn in their spending.
componenttext: [indiscernible] We still think Europe will have moderate growth, as I said, with the exception of Southern Europe, where I did say we are seeing definite downturn in their spending.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Katy Huberty of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Katy Huberty of Morgan Stanley.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the last question. IBM had noted some deal push outs, large deal push outs in the services business. Did you see any deal slippage at the end of your quarter? And just qualitatively, how would you characterize backlog or the pipeline o
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the last question. IBM had noted some deal push outs, large deal push outs in the services business. Did you see any deal slippage at the end of your quarter? And just qualitatively, how would you characterize backlog or the pipeline of deals going into 3Q?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Katy, you always see some deal push out. Was it material or abnormal in our case? The answer is no. And right now so far Q2, Q3, the customers, I haven't seen a huge change, whether it'd be 20 days whatever it is into, I don't know what day it is, but into Q3, I haven't seen the market changing the customer attitude.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, you talked about your longer-term target to grow revenue double digits and EPS double digits. How are you thinking about acquisition in that target set? And maybe I see the chart in the last seven or eight years, 12% revenue growth. Have you re-run t
componenttext: Joe, you talked about your longer-term target to grow revenue double digits and EPS double digits. How are you thinking about acquisition in that target set? And maybe I see the chart in the last seven or eight years, 12% revenue growth. Have you re-run that for what your organic growth rate is? And if you think about your assumptions going forward, how are you thinking about acquisitions? Historically, you maybe done a larger acquisition, $1 billion-plus every couple of years. Is that the kind of framework we should be thinking about sort of a larger acquisition every couple of years and then smaller ones like Greenplum potentially more frequently?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is yes. But let me just kind of qualify that. I would argue that -- I've always said I'd favor a string of pearls as opposed to a mass of acquisition. And I think from a revenue standpoint, the highest, biggest company we bought at $400 million
componenttext:
The answer is yes. But let me just kind of qualify that. I would argue that -- I've always said I'd favor a string of pearls as opposed to a mass of acquisition. And I think from a revenue standpoint, the highest, biggest company we bought at $400 million in revenue or something thereabouts. So when you talk on a base of $6.5 billion plus, certainly, I don't call that big, okay? But obviously, in dollar value, I would say your correct. That would be a trend that you should think we're going to continue. It's worked really well, and that's what I like. 
So I guess that's the last question. So in closing, we believe we are executing well today. Our strategy for the private and public cloud is right on. We have a product roadmap that is well aimed and downright exciting. We have the go-to-market capability and the alliance partners necessary to bring our innovative products to market. And most importantly, we have 45,000-plus great people who believe in our vision and our future. 
So I thank you for joining us, and we'll be talking to you and hope to see you all soon. Thank you.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: This concludes today's conference call. Thank you for your participation.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
