headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: With me here at Hopkinton we have David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results that we released this morning to highlight some of EMC's activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for
componenttext:
With me here at Hopkinton we have David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results that we released this morning to highlight some of EMC's activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for the rest of 2010. Joe will then spend some time discussing his view of what is happening in the market, EMC's execution of the strategy and how EMC is positioned to help customers on the journey to the cloud. After the prepared remarks, we'll then open up the lines to take your questions.
I would like to point out that we will be referring to non-GAAP numbers in today's presentation, unless otherwise indicated. The reconciliation of our non-GAAP comments to our GAAP results can be found in the disclosure today in our press release, supplemental schedules and the slides that accompany our presentation. All of these are available for download within the Investor Relations section of emc.com. 
As always, we have provided detailed financial tables in our news release and on our corporate website. These include a lot of financial details, so we do encourage you to take a look at them. The call this morning will contain forward-looking statements and information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ can be found in EMC's filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. And lastly, I will note that an archive of today's presentation will be available following the call. 
With that, it's now my pleasure to introduce David Goulden. David?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another great quarter. We achieved record revenues of over $4.2 billion, up 20%, record Q3 non-GAAP net income of $649 million, up 35%, non-GAAP
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another great quarter. We achieved record revenues of over $4.2 billion, up 20%, record Q3 non-GAAP net income of $649 million, up 35%, non-GAAP EPS of $0.30, up 30%, record year-to-date free cash flow of $2.2 billion, up 22% and non-GAAP operating margin up 21.5%, up 80 basis points sequentially.
We continue to execute on our triple play, with strong double-digit growth in storage security and virtualization, it's clear we continue to gain share in these key areas of the markets, areas where we are already the market leader. With the announcements of VMWare View 4.5, storage efficiency technologies like FAST v2 and FAST Cache and the acquisition of Greenplum, it's clear we're investing for the future and more importantly, these investments are bearing fruits. And with non-GAAP gross operating margins of 40 and 80 basis points, respectively quarter-on-quarter, we continue to improve profitability.
We expect to continue this triple play over the long term because how well we position ourselves to capitalize on the fundamental shift to cloud computing. Now let me start by taking a few minutes to discuss what's driving our good results.
The industry generally agrees the shift to cloud architecture is no longer a question of if, but of when. The answer is, it's happening now, albeit at different speeds with different companies. But all companies go through the same three phases to transform their traditional physical infrastructures to true cloud architectures and to take full advantage of the ability to offer IT as a service. 
Phase I is the virtualization of IT-owned applications, which also requires simple, efficient VM integrate storage. Phase II is a virtualization of business-critical applications. This is where SOAs around performance, availability, workload mobility, recoverability and security really matter. Phase III realize the full benefit of cloud by taking advantages of phases one and two, together with IT automation provisioning and chargeback to offer IT infrastructure as a service for the entire enterprise. It's at this phase that you have an elastic cloud that compute networking storage resources and also seamlessly storing on compatible public cloud services where it makes sense.
So let's look at what EMC offers for each one of these phases. The first phase typically tends to involve small deployments. Typically it involves the IT department's virtualizing applications they own and manage. For these implementations, which require virtualization and simple and efficient storage, EMC has VMware's vSphere on our unified storage products. 
With the majority of customers currently at this first phase, our unified storage frontline has grown rapidly, and also benefiting from this trend is the mid-tier as well. Where we really distinguishing ourselves in this space is with efficiency technologies like SSDs, FAST and FAST Cache as well as with high integration with VMware. For example, one well-known online brokerage firm in the quarter selected EMC's unified product in large part because of FAST Cache. Its ability to extraordinary performance to address unexpected workload spikes could not be matched by either of the other two vendors competing for this deal.
In the second phase, where virtualization extends to business-critical applications, SLA become very important. In fact, customers are telling us they want better SLAs after they virtualize. Also, if customer selected to deploy business-critical applications on enterprise storage for high SLAs in the physical world, they're not going to deploy them on mid-tier as they virtualize. 
In the second phase, customers look to technologies from VMware like vCenter AppSpeed and vSphere Storage and Network IO Control to help control performance SLAs at the application storage and network levels. Likewise, they demanded the storage infrastructure extend these capabilities and support these SLAs. For example, EMC's FAST storage I/O control to deliver industry-leading distributed resource scheduling for storage making enterprise apps perform 2.5X better for the same cost. Customers also looked at things like VMAX, VPLEX, reduplication and security to meet these SLA deeper in the infrastructure. In Phase I, a ray-based, not on replicate is suitable for backup. 
But in Phase II, tight integration of high-performance backup like EMCs Avamar with vStorage APIs and with this sensor provides much higher service levels. For example, in Q3, a large manufacturing customer who wanted to reduce space and power consumption in the data center and at the same time, virtualize their servers and desktops selected VMAX. We won another deal at a well-known global cosmetics company. 
In this case, the customer is expanding into VMware implementation and will use active-active VM type [ph] (21:31) with VPLEX to raise availability and federate across data centers at distance. These are great examples of a sophisticated enterprise class technology acquired in this phase and in these cases, it happened to be technology our competitors could not match. In fact, in Phase II implementations, larger competitors tend not to have all necessary best of breed technology and our mid-tier competitors don't have the portfolio to really provide a full solution.
Phase III is when you really get the IT as a service. This involves things like integrated SACs, management up and down from physical to virtual and use as monitoring, all of which EMC offers. Of these e-coalition enables hybrid clouds with Vblocks, our UIM, Unified Infrastructure Manager, office cross to main provisioning change and configuration management. vCloud director often saw provisioning of those machines in a multi-tense environment and VPLEX facilitates seamless data mobility between Private Clouds and external providers. 
Illustrating this, a very large pharmaceutical company this quarter decided it was taking them to long to provision their various machines and turn to EMC. Now on the influence as for your road map, they're moving forward with Vblock, with VMAX, UIM and will use VPLEX with active-active data center architecture.
For these examples demonstrate is that, that does not tend to be anyone typical cloud deal. A Company's infrastructure requirements are as varied as the companies themselves. This is why it's so important to have a broad and deep range of proxy services and as each company develops its cloud infrastructure roadmap, the industry can meet their needs through every phase of the departmental to enterprisewide, from tier zero to the back of an archive.
Now a common question in the investor community is, "Whose storage works best in virtualized environments?" We think the best way to find out is to go ask customers which vendors they trust. As you can see from the results of these surveys, which come from several sources, EMC consistently rises to the top when it comes to providing infrastructure virtualized environments. Now there is one smaller competitor claiming to have a lead in virtualized environments but the fact simply don't bear out. Rather know it tends to be the bigger more established companies with broader offerings that come in behind EMC. Customers realize that the journey through a cloud infrastructure can be complex, requiring a broad range of products and services. As a result, they go with companies like EMC that can provide more.
Public Cloud providers are ultimately building the infrastructure on EMC for a number of reasons: With virtualization being the foundation for public cloud service, VMware is key. With a vast amount of data being stored and managed by Public Cloud providers, scalability is critical. For example, V-Max's X86-Based scale architecture offers us [indiscernible] (24:33) by scale. With both intensities security is critical and the ability to attest to that security is just as important particularly for a public Cloud provider. 
RSA's cloud security solution offers us accountability. And enterprise customers need data mobility for true seamless hybrid cloud and VPLEX enables the advanced federation of resources into an output enterprise. 
This quarter we announced that several service providers are taking advantage of these technologies for offering public cloud services to their clients, and this number continues to ramp. Joe will give you more color on some of these wins in his comments.
The various example I've referenced are just a few of the deals we closed in Q3 with customers looking to start or continue to build out their Cloud infrastructures, both private and public. Our Q3 cloud wins span verticals, including governments, healthcare, media, manufacturing, energy, services and academia and, all of our frontlines across VMware security and storage, including high end and mid-tier block and file.
Now let me give you a sense of what's behind our strong results. Let's look at the numbers in more detail. Revenue in the quarter grew 20% to $4.2 billion in Q3. The increase in [indiscernible] (25:49) customers received from our proxy services is driving improvement to our business, with non-GAAP gross margin of 60.5%, up 40 basis points sequentially. 
This improvement was driven primarily by higher storage spot margins, thanks to the faster growth of our higher-margin storage products. Ongoing operating improvements help drive non-GAAP operating margins of 21.5%, up 80 basis points sequentially, and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.30 up from $0.28 last quarter and from $0.23 a year ago. Free cash flow is strong and year-to-date was $2.2 billion or 22% and $427 million greater than our non-GAAP net income for the same period. 
We ended the quarter with $10.5 billion in cash, of this, a total of $6.2 billion was held in the U.S. which remained overseas. We spent $500 million on acquisitions in the quarter and $283 million buying back 15 million shares of EMC stock, bringing us to $800 million on EMC share repurchases so far this year. We still expect to spend $1 billion on EMC stock by the end of the year. In addition, EMC spent $92 million buying VMware shares and VMware spent $131 million on VMware shares. looking at VMware's pivotal role as the Cloud data Center operating system of the future, we feel strongly these relatively small purchases maintain our ownership level on excellent long-term investments.
Now looking at our geographies. We saw a bounced double-digit growth around the world, with strongest growth in our BRIC + 13 emerging markets. Joe will provide some more color here. The negative impact of currency on a year-on-year revenue growth in Q3 was 60 basis points, assuming rates stay at September 30 levels, there should be no impact on currency on our full year revenue results. Now turning to a few details about our various products and services. Overall storage-related revenues grew 16% with or without acquisition effects. We believe that we continue to gain share in key segments of the storage market. We are the number one storage, due in large part to our technology leadership. And this is what continues to define us today. We are the leader in the most important technologies in infrastructure. 
For example, we were the first to introduce SSD in enterprise storage and the automated curing software to leverages. The ability to marry solid state and spinning drives lead to enormous performance and efficiency improvements. We unveiled this disruptive technology almost three years ago, and we're clearly benefiting from our leadership here in both high end and mid-tier storage systems.
This past quarter, we continue to reap the benefits of our innovation. As our Symmetrix front revenues were up a robust 23%. The VMAX architecture leverages standard X86 processing, it's highly scalable in terms of both performance and capacity and includes advanced advanced, high-value functionality like virtual provisioning and FAST. 
It is this capabilities which are driving our gains, not only in the traditional high-end deployments but also in large consolidation place, Private Cloud infrastructures and increasingly Public Cloud environments. I think that this success in brand tradition of Symmetrix leads many to think just in terms of traditional client storage. And of course we continue to set the pace there. 
However, I would encourage you to think more broadly regarding how this new architecture has been designed to be on a new pursuit [ph] (29:29) for the new information requirements of virtual infrastructures and cloud environments. It's this combination of our existing leadership position and the rapid penetration of these new cloud-focused environments that's driving our strong results.
A great example of this success is a Q3 win at a major global healthcare company. In this deal, VMAX's virtual provisioning and FAST, with the ability to tier to standard drives were key features as this enable the customer to increase utilization, simplify their environment and reduce CapEx and OpEx. In this case, where the customer was deploying VMware, our competitor required three times the amount of hardware to perform equivalently to two VMAX extensions. This is a clear example of how VMAX is winning in large VMware consolidations. In this case, the customer wants a storage system that can support 2,500 virtual machines growing to 6,000.
In fact, VMAX has proved itself to be so cost-effective and flexible that in many instances, customers are consolidating multiple mid-tier storage platforms on to one VMAX. This is happening with both EMC and competitive midtier storage platforms. As a couple of proved points, we swept the floor of a midtier competitive product with the VMAX at the global healthcare customer I just mentioned and also in another win among the world's leading media and entertainment companies. As customers are moving toward the cloud, EMC is best able to help them along every step of the journey and these are just two more examples.
Our midtier Storage business continue to show good growth again in Q3, increasing 22% year-on-year. The software capability we announced last quarter for our CLARiiON and Celerra platforms, Unisphere, FAST v2 and FAST Cache and block compressure from primary storage are being embraced by customers. The standard system shipping with emphasis in the midtier continues to increase, helped in part by the availability of FAST v2
And FAST Cache. 
These features was definitely a factor in several of the deals we won this quarter, including were we bid out a midtier competitor in a well-known West Coast University. In addition, we won a project to remove an encumbent midtier product and we also beat two other vendors at a well-known US-based retailer, based upon the strength of our VMware integration and significantly better capacity utilization.
Another key benefit of the breadth and depth of EMC's business is that we have a leadership position in some of the hottest areas of technology today. These technology products acts as wonderful door openers for EMC. This was the case in a recent government project, where we leveraged data domain relationship to highlight the CLARiiON capabilities in a VMware environment. CLARiiON integration with VMware was the deciding factor in the purchase of several CLARiiON systems as initial footprints in the deployment of a larger [ph] (32:35) scale for several petabytes. That's in addition to the large data domain purchases happening this quarter. This is just one great example of the synergy and success of our model.
Our Backup Recovery Systems business continues to grow at a high pace. We expect BRS is extraordinary growth opportunity to play out for a long time. This will clearly lead toward success with BRS, as the clear leader in the space, but will also drive additional opportunities for EMC to help customers in other ways.
As we announced last week, we've added a new division and a whole new set of opportunities to our portfolio. Greenplum, which we announced in July, is the foundation of our new Data Computing Product division. Its first new product, the EMC Greenplum data computing appliance, offers the industry's best price/performance ratio, 3X more scalability and up to 4X as many database cores than competitive systems and data input speed up to 5X out of our competitors. Our DCA integrates database, compute and storage into an enterprise class, easy-to-implement system that can meet petabyte scale big data requirements. We are very excited to pursue this incremental market opportunity by offering yet another leading edge solution to customers, as they increasingly seek the best analytic tools to derive business values from their massive volumes of data.
Our RSA security revenue growth accelerated in Q3 to 22% year-on-year. Our GRC and SIEM products did well as the customers new way to manage their multitude of discreet security devices. The combination of these capabilities enables customers to have an easy-to-use governance layer that could oversee and manage other security products throughout their environments. 
As security and compliance become increasingly important to all customers, as more infrastructures move towards the cloud, this unique governance and management way is a key differentiator and enabler in the marketplace. This was the reason we want an important security operation center project out of very large financial services customer this quarter. Revenue from our Information Intelligence Group was relatively flat against last year's Q3. The xCP platform continues to be very popular in IEG1 [ph] (34:57) of significant new customers in the quarter.
Clearly the rollout of virtual infrastructures in the buildout of private and public clouds drove the strong growth of VMware in the quarter, up 46%. The experiments [ph](35:11) around VWworld with over 17,000 attendees is a great example of the impact VMware has on the industry. At VMworld we made a number of announcements, including vCloud Director, VMWare View 4.5, vShield and shield and vFabric. 
We also a number of announcements around how other EMC products are being integrated with VMware, including Unified Infrastructure Management version 2, which when deployed with vCloud Director and Vblock, essentially a vCloud in a box. Other announcements included EMC storage infrastructure with secure authentication, which when combined with View 4.5 sets a storage efficiency record of $38 per client, the best in the market due to this high integration of all this various technologies. We also announced a strong RSA VMware cloud security and compliance solution, another industry first that will help ease the security concerns of customers as they move towards the cloud.
Because virtualization is the foundation of cloud computing, a key to success with VMware is bringing the virtual infrastructure and the information infrastructure together. And while we encourage others to work with VMware, we work harder as anyone else to integrate the virtual and information infrastructures. With over 60 different integration points now between EMC and VMware, including support for full the VMware APIs we lead in VMware integration. 
Recognizing the differences, such as high integration makes in performance, a global medical technology company purchased both the CLARiiON and Celerra systems in the quarter. It was a combination of the VM plug-ins Unified architectures and features like FAST and FAST Cache, all for one vendor that drove this deal for us. Our results this quarter and for the last several, are great indicators of the strength of our strategy and business model. The boost in cloud is underway, all of IT is moving in this direction and while customers are moving their spending toward these two architectures at varying speeds, the tidal wave of change is definitely real. 
We are leading in the hottest areas of the move to the cloud and we have the broadest portfolio across all the key customer requirements from virtualization to storage, to security, to information governance. And while we cannot control the economy or IT spending, we believe that we'll certainly continue to grow and gain share due to our leadership position in this rapidly growing opportunity.
So looking at the environments. The opportunity ahead, our unique competitive position and the strength of our strategy and model, we are once again raising our expectations to 2010. We now expect to achieve $16.9 billion in revenue, non-GAAP operating margins of 21% to 22% and non-GAAP EPS of $1.25. These reflects revenue growth of 20% and EPS growth of 39%, very robust growth and even better leverage.
As you can see, strong growth with leverage in investments have been a standard for us since 2004 and with the results and outlook we're reporting today, it's clear we're continuing on this trajectory. But what's most exciting is that the fundamental shift to cloud architecture is only in the early stages and we believe we are better suited than anyone else to capitalize on this trend as it unfolds over the next several years. We fully expect that the triple play of share growth, investment for the future and financial leverage we're delivering this year can be maintained over the long term.
So in summary, our strategy is clear, the business and operating model are in place, our investments continue to pay off and the cloud opportunity is very big. As a result, we expect to continue to deliver double-digit revenue and double-digit earnings growth for the next few years. I will now turn the call over to Joe, who'll provide some more color on the quarter and what we see through the end of the year. Joe?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and a warm welcome to everyone attending today's conference call. As always, thank you for your interest in EMC.As Tony said, I am currently in Beijing and thus, actively participating in today's earnings call from approximately 6,000 mil
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and a warm welcome to everyone attending today's conference call. As always, thank you for your interest in EMC.
As Tony said, I am currently in Beijing and thus, actively participating in today's earnings call from approximately 6,000 miles away from my colleagues, but I trust the marvels of communication technologies will make the mechanics of this call appear seamless.
Overall, I was very pleased with our performance in Q3. In fact, our top line revenue was the best in EMC's history, as we posted solid growth on both the year-on-year and sequential basis. I am also proud to report that we continue to create leverage in our P&L while investing in the future. To this end, in Q3 we added approximately 1,700 professionals to consolidate EMC in the areas of sales, emerging high-growth markets, R&D and VMware. Our goal is to develop more innovative products and maintain strong growth.
And most importantly, we established EMC and VMware as clear thought leaders with substantial momentum in private, public and hybrid cloud computing. We firmly believe cloud computing, which enables IT as a service, is the next big transformational wave that is shaping the Information Technology landscape. Our success in Q3 would not have been possible without the hard work and dedication of the 47,000 people of EMC and VMware around the world. I want to thank them for their leadership and congratulate them on their accomplishments.
I would now like to make a few comments on the global economy and more importantly, our view on IT spending trends. On the economic front, on a consolidated global basis, we continue to see a slow recovery albeit with a few bumps on the road, pretty much in line with what we have been saying all year and looking forward we expect this trend to continue. Closer to home in IT spending terms, we are seeing real strength in rapid growing and emerging geographies. 
Moderate growth in the U.S., Japan, most of Europe, albeit with a bit of choppiness in a few countries and solid growth in countries such as Australia, Canada, Mexico and South Africa. Additionally across all markets, the very good news is that the demand for virtualization, information storage, information protection and information security and governance, areas where EMC/VMware is the leader, are growing considerably faster than the IT average. This as evidenced by the fact that in Q3 we grew on a year-on-year basis 21% in the U.S., 28% in APJ, 22% in constant currency, 14% in Europe, 19% in constant currency and approximately 30% in emerging markets. This bounced geographic growth demonstrates that we are focused on IT markets that are growing much faster than the IT as a start market as a whole, and more importantly we are clearly taking share.
Additionally, we drove this demand as the ever continuing growth of information and the innovative uses of this information by our customers as they drive for higher and higher levels of productivity on meeting the mandate for risk mitigation and adheres to proper governance and compliance policies. With as to our confidence in our future is the thought leadership, innovations and strong product roadmap we have in a new big wave of IT of cloud computing. It's our firm belief that cloud computing will transform enterprise IT shops as the customers migrate their IT data centers into private clouds. This transformation will also happen in the search provider community as they build out an extensive number of very large enterprise class public clouds.
Additionally, the actualization of Private and Public Cloud computing will provide our customers a massive benefit, mainly the ability to run applications more flexibly, with a lot more automation and a significantly lower cost while assuring the attendant policies and service levels are adhered to. But even lower cost and more flexibility can be achieved as customers take advantage of both Private and Public cloud computing by federating or operating their various application loads between their own Private clouds and the Public clouds of their chosen service provider partners. We call this cloud implementation, the hybrid cloud. 
I assure you the vast majority of our R&D budgets, our acquisitions, our go-to-market motions and the buildout of our partner ecosystem, is aimed at leading and winning in this game-changing hybrid cloud opportunity. The importance of having a world-class partner ecosystem cannot be overstated. I firmly believe no one IT company could possibly possess all the active resources to go it alone. And very importantly, every single customer I speak with once, in fact, demands best of breed and choice. To this end, our partnership with Cisco is deepening and our VCE coalition is gaining significant momentum in the market. As proof, I am again pleased to report that our Vblock sales are well ahead of plan.
Our partnership with systems integrators, such as Accenture, CSC, Capgemini, Wipro, TCS, Deloitte and others continues to grow strategically and tactically. And last, on our service provider front, we are building a number of very deep alliances with many of the leading telcos and service providers around the world. 
In Q3 we announced partnerships with the following companies: France Telecom's Orange Business Services, SingTels Alphawest, Saudi Telecom, Cable & Wireless and Terremark. And you can expect many more announcements over the coming weeks and months. In summary, EMC is executing well in today's IT market. 
We have a great product and technology portfolio and a go-to-market prowess to capture the opportunity that the private, public and hybrid cloud computing wave offers. Thus, I reaffirm our belief that we can achieve double-digit growth rates over the long term, and to help you better understand why we are so confident in our future, we will host an investor and analyst day in Q1. I'd now like to turn it back to Tony to moderate today's portion of the Q&A portion of today's call.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Before we open up the lines for your questions, as usual, we ask you to try and limit yourself to one question, including larifications. This will enable us to take as many questions as possible. We thank you, all, for your cooperation in thi
componenttext: Thanks, Joe. Before we open up the lines for your questions, as usual, we ask you to try and limit yourself to one question, including larifications. This will enable us to take as many questions as possible. We thank you, all, for your cooperation in this matter. Operator, can we open up the lines for questions, please.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question Aaron Rakers of Stifel, Nicolaus Investment Advisors.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question Aaron Rakers of Stifel, Nicolaus Investment Advisors.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is going to be around basically the cloud strategy as a whole. You guys lay out obviously a clear picture of where you're going from a strategic perspective. Can you help me understand where clustered mass fits in to your thought process aroun
componenttext: My question is going to be around basically the cloud strategy as a whole. You guys lay out obviously a clear picture of where you're going from a strategic perspective. Can you help me understand where clustered mass fits in to your thought process around cloud or the market that you guys look to address going forward?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically we have a very successful high-end NAS product with Celerra. There's a lot of developments that we are investing in their development activities that we're investing in there with products coming to market. Closer to NAS is really all about how
componenttext: Basically we have a very successful high-end NAS product with Celerra. There's a lot of developments that we are investing in their development activities that we're investing in there with products coming to market. Closer to NAS is really all about how you handle a global name space, we have really solid plans in that area and I feel comfortable with our roadmap. As always, I like to keep some surprises so we don't -- I don't want to tell you exactly when we'll release  new products but I will say we have a very robust product line for 2011.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel Ives of FBR.
componenttext: Daniel Ives of FBR.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you speak to the Federal and the quarter relative to expectations?
componenttext: Can you speak to the Federal and the quarter relative to expectations?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In Federal we saw a good quarter-on-quarter growth in the quarter as expected but relative to the business it wasn't quite as strong, again, as expected. So good sequential growth and pretty much in line with where we expected it to come out.
componenttext: In Federal we saw a good quarter-on-quarter growth in the quarter as expected but relative to the business it wasn't quite as strong, again, as expected. So good sequential growth and pretty much in line with where we expected it to come out.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question, Brian Marshall of Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: Our next question, Brian Marshall of Gleacher & Company.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at, I mean it appears most of your business lines are fully optimized at this point. I guess I'd like to focus on the one that doesn't appear to be, the Information Intelligence Group, the all documentum, I was wondering if we can get an update he
componenttext: Looking at, I mean it appears most of your business lines are fully optimized at this point. I guess I'd like to focus on the one that doesn't appear to be, the Information Intelligence Group, the all documentum, I was wondering if we can get an update here, kind of what you see out there from this business unit and how strategic business going forward relative to the focus on the hybrid cloud?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. First of all, when we think of the hybrid cloud, one that's a phenomenon today is big data and your big data is going to come in a couple of different forms. It's going to come in the structured form and that's obviously where our Gree
componenttext: A couple of things. First of all, when we think of the hybrid cloud, one that's a phenomenon today is big data and your big data is going to come in a couple of different forms. It's going to come in the structured form and that's obviously where our Greenplum and the DCA that we just announced are important. And it's also going to come in the unstructured form, again, which is why Documentum is still a very important part of the overall strategy. Now within the IIG business, there's a couple of things happening underneath the surface, that business is transitioning from a large enterprise license tech business to a smaller application-dependent business so we're moving from the traditional ELA to the kind of smaller xCP application origin rollouts. So underneath the surface you've seen that churn occur and that's why  you're seeing the top line relatively flat but strategically it still has a great role in the crowd strategy.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: David's right. There's a lot of moving pieces there and we are in the transition to our XCP strategy which will make Documentum platform a lot more lively, a lot more SaaS-enabled. And as we get through that transition, we expect we'll see better growth.
componenttext: David's right. There's a lot of moving pieces there and we are in the transition to our XCP strategy which will make Documentum platform a lot more lively, a lot more SaaS-enabled. And as we get through that transition, we expect we'll see better growth.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ittai Kidron from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Ittai Kidron from Oppenheimer.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question for David. With regards to the gross margin in your core EMC business, 55.5% this quarter, I can't even remember the last time you've got such high gross margin and with some of your larger competitors making a lot of acquisitions and trying to
componenttext: A question for David. With regards to the gross margin in your core EMC business, 55.5% this quarter, I can't even remember the last time you've got such high gross margin and with some of your larger competitors making a lot of acquisitions and trying to accumulate a lot of assets after years of non activity in your area. How should we think about gross margins in your core business going into next year? And also VMware provided some initial growth thoughts on 2011 last night, would you care to do the same with regards to your business?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all now, we're not going into 2011 at this point in time other than to reiterate my comments I said earlier that we are looking to execute our triple play over the long term. And so the next we'll be looking at double-digit revenue growth and dou
componenttext: First of all now, we're not going into 2011 at this point in time other than to reiterate my comments I said earlier that we are looking to execute our triple play over the long term. And so the next we'll be looking at double-digit revenue growth and double-digit earnings growth and those are the only kind of a, if you like, statement putting in the ground right now relative to 2011. Relative to gross margin, I mean yes, we have seen a nice expansion in the non-VMware side of the business. As I mentioned during the quarter what we're seeing is a mixed shift towards our higher gross margin product. So we're doing very well with things like our NAS products, like our VMAX, like our DD products and some of our stories, software and that makeshift is you're helping the margins grow sequentially. I would point out to you that gross margins, we equate that as an indicator of, call it, value you're providing to the customer. The more value you're providing per customer, the better gross margins are going to be within the business. So that's what's happening beneath the surface there.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rajesh Ghai of ThinkEquity LLC.
componenttext: Rajesh Ghai of ThinkEquity LLC.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: A number of your large competitors have announced indicated appliances for the cloud. I want to understand what your views were on this competitive activity and whether you believe your Vblock strategy was an adequate response.
componenttext: A number of your large competitors have announced indicated appliances for the cloud. I want to understand what your views were on this competitive activity and whether you believe your Vblock strategy was an adequate response.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think Vblock strategy was a response, I think we started it. Kind of the first integration of taking the Cloud OS VMware, the connectivity and network, the server and the storage in putting it together was pioneered by us. So I don't think we're r
componenttext: I don't think Vblock strategy was a response, I think we started it. Kind of the first integration of taking the Cloud OS VMware, the connectivity and network, the server and the storage in putting it together was pioneered by us. So I don't think we're reacting at all, I think others are reacting to us. We, us in Cisco, we're not giving out numbers yet  but what I told you is true. We said -- what I told you, pretty aggressive compliant to Vblocks and I will repeat what I said, we are well above our plan that we set for ourselves both last quarter and this quarter and for the year. So it's going well.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on 3PAR was acquired by HP in midst of bidding war, how do you guys think probably the HP changes the landscape in high-end storage especially for VMAX, I guess given HB sales and services? And then secondly how do you think the EMC-Dell r
componenttext: Just a question on 3PAR was acquired by HP in midst of bidding war, how do you guys think probably the HP changes the landscape in high-end storage especially for VMAX, I guess given HB sales and services? And then secondly how do you think the EMC-Dell relationship goes further given their keep interest I think on all the storage assets versus reselling CLARiiON?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't really 3PAR changes the landscape at all. We've been -- 3PAR, 10 years we've been competing with it for quite a while. From HP, will they make 3PAR successful, I'm sure they will. But I think what you're going to see there is in large substitution
componenttext: I don't really 3PAR changes the landscape at all. We've been -- 3PAR, 10 years we've been competing with it for quite a while. From HP, will they make 3PAR successful, I'm sure they will. But I think what you're going to see there is in large substitution for their high-end DBAs and for business that they previously funneled through Attach. So I really don't see that changing the landscape at all. As far as the Dell relationship, obviously, we took a step back as Dell went after 3PAR and obviously, cool things off. We are again in discussions to see if we can do something more meaningful and lasting, both companies would like to do that but the key is it's got to be meaningful and it's got to be last thing for me to tell you that it's back on track. So I can't tell you that yet but I can tell you we are in serious discussions and there is intent on both parties to do that, but obviously 3PAR moving from Dell was a step back to the relationship.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question, William Choi of Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question, William Choi of Jefferies & Company.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Quick clarification first. Storage grew 16% you said same up 23%, mid-tier up 22% so what was in storage was below 16%. And then the question is really if you could talk about the low end products, you guys have talked about -- bring that out in Q1, what
componenttext: Quick clarification first. Storage grew 16% you said same up 23%, mid-tier up 22% so what was in storage was below 16%. And then the question is really if you could talk about the low end products, you guys have talked about -- bring that out in Q1, what would be the kind of the margin and revenue ramp profile of this would? I would imagine these things would -- some would have higher software integration to them and related to that, if you could update us on how you're doing with the channel push there, how many partners have you been able to add and what kind of metrics you could talk about?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, I'll start then I'm going to pass it over to Joe for the second part. In total storage, you're right, the Total Storage business was up 16%, same 23%, midtier 22%. Remember that in the Storage business, well first of all, those numbers I gave you fo
componenttext: Bill, I'll start then I'm going to pass it over to Joe for the second part. In total storage, you're right, the Total Storage business was up 16%, same 23%, midtier 22%. Remember that in the Storage business, well first of all, those numbers I gave you for same and midyear are product-only numbers. In the Storage business there's also product and services, maintenance and professional services and also there are a number of other products in there, including some of the third-party products that we sell through like the connector switches and all select line. So that's the difference between the 16%, the 23% % and the 22%. And for updates on midtier I'm going to pass that over to Joe.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously we've said and I'll repeat it that we think we have a very, very competitive, very excited about it, about a low-end product coming in Q1. We'll announce that in early Q1. It is on track, it is in beta now. It is doing very well, and again I'm v
componenttext: Obviously we've said and I'll repeat it that we think we have a very, very competitive, very excited about it, about a low-end product coming in Q1. We'll announce that in early Q1. It is on track, it is in beta now. It is doing very well, and again I'm very excited. So stay tuned, we'll announce that in Q1. It is the fastest-growing market in storage and again we're excited to -- we're very excited about the prospects of entering that market in a big way, in a big, big way.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark Moskowitz of JPMorgan Chase.
componenttext: Mark Moskowitz of JPMorgan Chase.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can give us an update on the back of recovering business in terms of revenue run rate, if you can give kind of -- $1 billion update there. And if you can also talk about the cross-selling opportunities [indiscernible] (57:10) and the
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can give us an update on the back of recovering business in terms of revenue run rate, if you can give kind of -- $1 billion update there. And if you can also talk about the cross-selling opportunities [indiscernible] (57:10) and the heritage domain accounts.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, I got the first part of the question in terms of the run rate, can you repeat the second part, please?
componenttext: Mark, I got the first part of the question in terms of the run rate, can you repeat the second part, please?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other piece was if you can just talk about the cross-selling opportunities within the data domain accounts, in terms of heritage data domain, what type of pull through are you seeing in there?
componenttext: The other piece was if you can just talk about the cross-selling opportunities within the data domain accounts, in terms of heritage data domain, what type of pull through are you seeing in there?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, so on the run rate we mentioned that in the first quarter data domain and all other lines combined can reach the $1 billion run rate, which is ahead of plan. We said we'd get to that level in 2010. We got there in Q1. That continues to increase sequ
componenttext: Mark, so on the run rate we mentioned that in the first quarter data domain and all other lines combined can reach the $1 billion run rate, which is ahead of plan. We said we'd get to that level in 2010. We got there in Q1. That continues to increase sequentially into Q2 and again into Q3. So we're not like going to break that out again once we got beyond our $1 billion run rate, but we are continuing to see sequential growth and obviously the run rates is now higher. In terms of cross selling, some nice opportunities I mentioned, for example, in my prepared comments where we'd cross-sold into a data domain count, a large CLARiiON project that's going to scale up to kind of like type scale, and of course there's good BRS opportunities into the EMC accounts. So the good news is when we look at BRS, a, it's opening new doors for us; and b, we're also able to increase our footprint inside of the year, the EMC accounts. So it's working both ways, it's certainly a win-win from that point of view.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason Ader of William Blair.
componenttext: Jason Ader of William Blair.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question was on the implied sequential growth guidance for the top line for the core business for the information infrastructure, it's around 14%, if my math is right. That seems slightly stronger than seasonal so given your comments on the economy bei
componenttext: My question was on the implied sequential growth guidance for the top line for the core business for the information infrastructure, it's around 14%, if my math is right. That seems slightly stronger than seasonal so given your comments on the economy being sort of in a slow recovery, I was wondering if you can add any color on why you think that's going to be as strong as the implied guidance suggests?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, Jason, are you talking Q3 to Q4 sequential growth seasonality?
componenttext: Actually, Jason, are you talking Q3 to Q4 sequential growth seasonality?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, five-year average is something like 13% and this implies around 14%. So I think that's a little bit better than the kind of historical.
componenttext: Yes, five-year average is something like 13% and this implies around 14%. So I think that's a little bit better than the kind of historical.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason is talking excluding VMware, just to clarify his comments.
componenttext: Jason is talking excluding VMware, just to clarify his comments.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's close, Jason. I mean basically what we're doing is, like we do all the time, we get bottoms of forecast, and we can put a little bit of management, the wisdom, hopefully on those forecasts. And we've been pretty accurate through the year, and this
componenttext: That's close, Jason. I mean basically what we're doing is, like we do all the time, we get bottoms of forecast, and we can put a little bit of management, the wisdom, hopefully on those forecasts. And we've been pretty accurate through the year, and this is where we're coming up, and so we're telling it as we see it. So we don't see the market slowing down. We think there's good opportunity out there for IT and especially in areas we are, virtualization, storage, information protection, information security, those areas are hot. And I suspect they will remain hot for the foreseeable future.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maynard Um of UBS.
componenttext: Maynard Um of UBS.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the three phases to get through cloud, can you just talk about what inning we're in, in Phase I rollouts? And as we move from Phase I to Phase II, do you think we get a pause because of either a hesitancy to move to mission-critical apps or ma
componenttext: In terms of the three phases to get through cloud, can you just talk about what inning we're in, in Phase I rollouts? And as we move from Phase I to Phase II, do you think we get a pause because of either a hesitancy to move to mission-critical apps or maybe because we have to digest before we start doing again or do you think this is a seamless transition between the two phases?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's pretty seamless. Customers are seeing phenomenal reliability. The VMware OS continues to get the highest marks in the industry for stability and high quality in their platform. And of course, with the advent of Halem servers, we've given you
componenttext: I think it's pretty seamless. Customers are seeing phenomenal reliability. The VMware OS continues to get the highest marks in the industry for stability and high quality in their platform. And of course, with the advent of Halem servers, we've given you that six to eight quarters in tremendous power, customers are seeing reliability, the capability and they are definitely, definitely moving to Phase II without a pause. And I think Phase II will be very successful.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, just to pick up on the comment, as I mentioned the requirements and the benefit the customers change from the phase. Phase I is really about consolidation cost reduction. Phase II, customers are looking for cost, they're actually looking to increas
componenttext: Jason, just to pick up on the comment, as I mentioned the requirements and the benefit the customers change from the phase. Phase I is really about consolidation cost reduction. Phase II, customers are looking for cost, they're actually looking to increase their SLAs as they virtualize, which requires a whole turn technology to drive optimization around those SLAs. So it really changes the game very much from a VMware point of view, but also from a storage point of view, the requirements in Phase II is very, very different. That's why I gave you some examples in my script, so that the ability to seamlessly bridge Phase I and Phase II, will set us apart.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: By the way, speaking from first-hand experience, our own IT shop, we have moved a substantial number of our mission-critical apps, as a matter of fact, all of our CRM apps to this world and we're seeing great opportunity, so we are clearly kind of drinkin
componenttext: By the way, speaking from first-hand experience, our own IT shop, we have moved a substantial number of our mission-critical apps, as a matter of fact, all of our CRM apps to this world and we're seeing great opportunity, so we are clearly kind of drinking the Kool-Aid and getting a very good taste.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ben Reitzes of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Ben Reitzes of Barclays Capital.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to focus on a little bit more on the fourth quarter guidance. I mean clearly your guidance Street expectation for the fourth quarter and earnings, I just I was wondering, Joe, you said you did a bottoms up forecast but what is going better than exp
componenttext: I want to focus on a little bit more on the fourth quarter guidance. I mean clearly your guidance Street expectation for the fourth quarter and earnings, I just I was wondering, Joe, you said you did a bottoms up forecast but what is going better than expected and included in that guidance, Symmetrix number look pretty strong, vis-à-vis expectations, what are we missing potentially that had you raise guidance that's better than expected, it seems like a pretty strong outlook?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Clearly on the storage side, the start of the show would be VMAX and our BRS Data Domain and Avamar products. And the other star of the show is our, NAS business. Our Celerra NAS businesses is also growing tremendously faster than our major competitor. So
componenttext: Clearly on the storage side, the start of the show would be VMAX and our BRS Data Domain and Avamar products. And the other star of the show is our, NAS business. Our Celerra NAS businesses is also growing tremendously faster than our major competitor. So those are the stars of the show obviously, information security is incredibly important and you see the growth in our RSA Divisions business. So those are going great and our new entry in the Greenplum is showing a lot of progress and  a good pipeline. That's not going to be a major impact in Q  for obviously because of its size. But still got great growth. So we have several areas that are, I would call, hot. And of course, you mentioned, on the DII side[indiscernible] (1:03:45), but of course VMware continues to -- they raise their guidance also. So pretty good strength across major product lines and then of course in Q1 we're going to enter a new phase with our low end products. So we're in pretty good shape going forward, very good shape going forward.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kaushik Roy of Wedbush Morgan Securities.
componenttext: Kaushik Roy of Wedbush Morgan Securities.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: One other concerns during Q3 was if customers are waiting for the unified CLARiiON and Celerra anticipated next year. Can you comment on what you saw in the CLARiiON product line or what to expect there?
componenttext: One other concerns during Q3 was if customers are waiting for the unified CLARiiON and Celerra anticipated next year. Can you comment on what you saw in the CLARiiON product line or what to expect there?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously I didn't mention CLARiiON as the star, but it's holding its own. What we did do, which customers are loving, is I said as we did with our VMAX platform before, we have released a lot of the key software on the older platforms ahead of the
componenttext: Well, obviously I didn't mention CLARiiON as the star, but it's holding its own. What we did do, which customers are loving, is I said as we did with our VMAX platform before, we have released a lot of the key software on the older platforms ahead of the new announcements. So Unisphere, FAST Cache, Fast v2, new compression technology, are being very well received by customers and that's having an effect. Obviously CLARiiON is also affected by Dell moving onto EqualLogic. CLARiiON had a lot to overcome, our new [indiscernible] (1:05:15) strategy, we think, is back on track and we're looking very forward to the future. So I think it'll continue to not be a star in Q4 but it'll prod along and do okay.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Louis Miscioscia of Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Louis Miscioscia of Collins Stewart.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was going to ask about Europe as to why it was, I guess, growing less than some of the geographies, but also since you mentioned it, that your largest or your competitor in the NAS area, that you're growing faster than them, I think in their Hardware  a
componenttext: I was going to ask about Europe as to why it was, I guess, growing less than some of the geographies, but also since you mentioned it, that your largest or your competitor in the NAS area, that you're growing faster than them, I think in their Hardware  area last quarter, they grew 50% year-over-year last quarter. Maybe you could give us some comparable numbers to also take a look at your numbers within the mid-tier storage area for you?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Think of it like this, I'm not going to give you new numbers but I understand their growth rate. And I said that if you look our Celerra alone, it grew faster and I say that again. So obviously, our NAS is aimed at the higher end. And that's a good space
componenttext: Think of it like this, I'm not going to give you new numbers but I understand their growth rate. And I said that if you look our Celerra alone, it grew faster and I say that again. So obviously, our NAS is aimed at the higher end. And that's a good space to be and we're going to do a lot of expansion there, as I answered to the first question. However, where they're growing extremely fast is an area we're not in which is the low end, which I told we start addressing in early Q1. So that's kind of a macro statement around that.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to pick up on your question about Europe, as Joe mentioned in his comments, if you look at Europe in constant currency, as you grew at 19%, so where we did have currency headwind I mentioned in my script is that 60 basis points for the quarter, basic
componenttext: Just to pick up on your question about Europe, as Joe mentioned in his comments, if you look at Europe in constant currency, as you grew at 19%, so where we did have currency headwind I mentioned in my script is that 60 basis points for the quarter, basically all the headwind was in Europe a 19% constant currency is pretty good growth.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question, Keith Bachman of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our last question, Keith Bachman of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, could you talk a little bit about cash flow and free cash flow as you think about Q4 specifically, what are the objectives that you have and you mentioned '11 double-digit revenue and earnings growth, how should we be thinking about free cash flow,
componenttext: David, could you talk a little bit about cash flow and free cash flow as you think about Q4 specifically, what are the objectives that you have and you mentioned '11 double-digit revenue and earnings growth, how should we be thinking about free cash flow, particularly since it's kind of in a consolidated basis, it slowed down a little bit this quarter in terms of the growth rate?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Keith, a few comments on free cash flow. First of all, I think the one metric that's leaked out that we look at on a quarter-by-quarter basis because of the ebbs and flows and timings of working capital investments even some CapEx build up, so I commented
componenttext: Keith, a few comments on free cash flow. First of all, I think the one metric that's leaked out that we look at on a quarter-by-quarter basis because of the ebbs and flows and timings of working capital investments even some CapEx build up, so I commented that free cash flow for the year so far is up 22%, year-to-date its over $400 million higher than our non-GAAP net income. Looking forward to Q4 and the year, looking forward to 2011, we continue to strive to have our free cash flow be higher than our non-GAAP net income.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So again, thank you for joining us, we very much appreciate it. And in closing, I want to reiterate that we are executing well, our strategy for the private, public and hybrid cloud is solid and gaining traction. We have a product roadmap that is well aim
componenttext: So again, thank you for joining us, we very much appreciate it. And in closing, I want to reiterate that we are executing well, our strategy for the private, public and hybrid cloud is solid and gaining traction. We have a product roadmap that is well aimed and again, very exciting. And we have the go to market and alliance partners necessary to bring these innovative products to market, but most importantly we have 47,000-plus great people in EMC and VMware who believe in our vision and our future. So once again, thank you for joining us and we look forward to seeing you soon. Thank you very much. Bye-bye.
