headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: With me here at Hopkinton we have David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results that we released this morning to highlight some of EMC's activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for
componenttext:
With me here at Hopkinton we have David Goulden, EMC Executive Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results that we released this morning to highlight some of EMC's activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for the rest of 2010. Joe will then spend some time discussing his view of what is happening in the market, EMC's execution of the strategy and how EMC is positioned to help customers on the journey to the cloud. After the prepared remarks, we'll then open up the lines to take your questions.
I would like to point out that we will be referring to non-GAAP numbers in today's presentation, unless otherwise indicated. The reconciliation of our non-GAAP comments to our GAAP results can be found in the disclosure today in our press release, supplemental schedules and the slides that accompany our presentation. All of these are available for download within the Investor Relations section of emc.com. 
As always, we have provided detailed financial tables in our news release and on our corporate website. These include a lot of financial details, so we do encourage you to take a look at them. The call this morning will contain forward-looking statements and information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ can be found in EMC's filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. And lastly, I will note that an archive of today's presentation will be available following the call. 
With that, it's now my pleasure to introduce David Goulden. David?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another great quarter. We achieved record revenues of over $4.2 billion, up 20%, record Q3 non-GAAP net income of $649 million, up 35%, non-GAAP
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another great quarter. We achieved record revenues of over $4.2 billion, up 20%, record Q3 non-GAAP net income of $649 million, up 35%, non-GAAP EPS of $0.30, up 30%, record year-to-date free cash flow of $2.2 billion, up 22% and non-GAAP operating margin up 21.5%, up 80 basis points sequentially.
We continue to execute on our triple play, with strong double-digit growth in storage security and virtualization, it's clear we continue to gain share in these key areas of the markets, areas where we are already the market leader. With the announcements of VMWare View 4.5, storage efficiency technologies like FAST v2 and FAST Cache and the acquisition of Greenplum, it's clear we're investing for the future and more importantly, these investments are bearing fruits. And with non-GAAP gross operating margins of 40 and 80 basis points, respectively quarter-on-quarter, we continue to improve profitability.
We expect to continue this triple play over the long term because how well we position ourselves to capitalize on the fundamental shift to cloud computing. Now let me start by taking a few minutes to discuss what's driving our good results.
The industry generally agrees the shift to cloud architecture is no longer a question of if, but of when. The answer is, it's happening now, albeit at different speeds with different companies. But all companies go through the same three phases to transform their traditional physical infrastructures to true cloud architectures and to take full advantage of the ability to offer IT as a service. 
Phase I is the virtualization of IT-owned applications, which also requires simple, efficient VM integrate storage. Phase II is a virtualization of business-critical applications. This is where SOAs around performance, availability, workload mobility, recoverability and security really matter. Phase III realize the full benefit of cloud by taking advantages of phases one and two, together with IT automation provisioning and chargeback to offer IT infrastructure as a service for the entire enterprise. It's at this phase that you have an elastic cloud of computer networking storage resources and also seamlessly storing on compatible public cloud service where it makes sense.
So let's look at what EMC offers for each one of these phases. The first phase typically tends to involve small deployments. Typically it involves the IT department's virtualizing applications they own and manage. For these implementations, which require virtualization and simple and efficient storage, EMC has VMware's vSphere on our unified storage products. 
With the majority of customers currently at this first phase, our unified storage frontline has grown rapidly, and also benefiting from this trend is the mid-tier as well. Where we really distinguishing ourselves in this phase is with efficiency technologies like SSDs, FAST and FAST Cache as well as with high integration with VMware. For example, one well-known online brokerage firm in the quarter selected EMC's unified product in large part because of FAST Cache. Its ability to extraordinary [ph] performance to address unexpected workload spikes could not be matched by either of the other two vendors competing for this deal.
In the second phase, where virtualization extends to business-critical applications, SLA become very important. In fact, customers are telling us they want better SLAs after they virtualize. Also, if customer selected to deploy business-critical applications on enterprise storage for high SLAs in the physical world, they're not going to deploy them on mid-tier as they virtualize. 
In the second phase, customers look to technologies from VMware like vCenter AppSpeed and vSphere Storage and Network IO Control to help control performance SLAs at the application storage and network levels. Likewise, they demanded the storage infrastructure extend these capabilities and support these SLAs. For example, EMC's FAST works with storage I/O control to deliver industry-leading distributed resource scheduling for storage making enterprise apps perform 2.5X better for the same cost. Customers also looked at things like VMAX, VPLEX, reduplication and security to meet these SLA deeper in the infrastructure. In Phase I, array-based, Snap and replicate is suitable for backup. 
But in Phase II, tight integration of high-performance backup like EMCs Avamar with vStorage APIs and with vSensor provides much higher service levels. For example, in Q3, a large manufacturing customer who wanted to reduce space and power consumption in the data center and at the same time, virtualize their servers and desktops selected VMAX. We won another deal at a well-known global cosmetics company. 
In this case, the customer is expanding into VMware implementation and will use active-active VM type portation [ph] with VPLEX to raise availability and federate across data centers at distance. These are great examples of a sophisticated enterprise class technology acquired in this phase and in these cases, it happened to be technology our competitors could not match. In fact, in Phase II implementations, larger competitors tend not to have all necessary best of breed technology and our mid-tier competitors don't have the portfolio to really provide a full solution.
Phase III is when you really get the IT as a service. This involves things like integrated SACs, management up and down from physical to virtual and use as monitoring, all of which EMC offers. Of these e-coalition enables hybrid clouds with Vblocks, our UIM, Unified Infrastructure Manager, office cross to main provisioning change and configuration management. vCloud director often self provisioning of those machines in a multi-tense environment and VPLEX facilitates seamless data mobility between Private Clouds and external providers. 
Illustrating this, a very large pharmaceutical company this quarter decided it was taking them to long to provision their various machines and turn to EMC. Now on the influence their freer road map, they're moving forward with Vblock, with VMAX, UIM and will use VPLEX with active-active data center architecture.
What these examples demonstrate is that, that does not tend to be any one typical cloud deal. A Company's infrastructure requirements are as varied as the companies themselves. This is why it's so important to have a broad and deep range of proxy services and as each company develops its cloud infrastructure roadmap, the industry can meet their needs through every phase of the departmental to enterprise-wide, from tier zero to the back of an archive.
Now a common question in the investor community is, "Whose storage works best in virtualized environments?" We think the best way to find out is to go ask customers which vendors they trust. As you can see from the results of these surveys, which come from several sources, EMC consistently rises to the top when it comes to providing infrastructure virtualized environments. Now there is one smaller competitor claiming to have a lead in virtualized environments but the fact simply don't bear out. Rather know it tends to be the bigger more established companies with broader offerings that come in behind EMC. Customers realize that the journey through a cloud infrastructure can be complex, requiring a broad range of products and services. As a result, they go with companies like EMC that can provide more.
Public Cloud providers are ultimately building the infrastructure on EMC for a number of reasons: With virtualization being the foundation for public cloud service, VMware is key. With a vast amount of data being stored and managed by Public Cloud providers, scalability is critical. For example, V-Max's X86-Based scale architecture offers us a petabyte scale. With both intensities security is critical and the ability to attest to that security is just as important particularly for a public Cloud provider. 
RSA's cloud security solution offers us accountability. And enterprise customers need data mobility for true seamless hybrid cloud and VPLEX enables the advanced federation of resources into an out of the enterprise. 
This quarter we announced that several service providers are taking advantage of these technologies for offering public cloud services to their clients, and this number continues to ramp. Joe will give you more color on some of these wins in his comments.
The various example I've referenced are just a few of the deals we closed in Q3 with customers looking to start or continue to build out their Cloud infrastructures, both private and public. Our Q3 cloud wins span verticals, including governments, healthcare, media, manufacturing, energy, services and academia and, all of our frontlines across VMware security and storage, including high end and mid-tier block and file.
Now let me give you a sense of what's behind our strong results. Let's look at the numbers in more detail. Revenue in the quarter grew 20% to $4.2 billion in Q3. The increase in value customers received from our proxy services is driving improvement to our business, with non-GAAP gross margin of 60.5%, up 40 basis points sequentially. 
This improvement was driven primarily by higher storage spot margins, thanks to the faster growth of our higher-margin storage products. Ongoing operating improvements help drive non-GAAP operating margins of 21.5%, up 80 basis points sequentially, and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.30 up from $0.28 last quarter and from $0.23 a year ago. Free cash flow is strong and year-to-date was $2.2 billion or 22% and $427 million greater than our non-GAAP net income for the same period. 
We ended the quarter with $10.5 billion in cash, of this, a total of $6.2 billion was held in the U.S. which remained overseas. We spent $500 million on acquisitions in the quarter and $283 million buying back 15 million shares of EMC stock, bringing us to $800 million on EMC share repurchases so far this year. We still expect to spend $1 billion on EMC stock by the end of the year. In addition, EMC spent $92 million buying VMware shares and VMware spent $131 million on VMware shares. Looking at VMware's pivotal role as the Cloud data Center operating system of the future, we feel strongly these relatively small purchases maintain our ownership level on excellent long-term investments.
Now looking at our geographies. We saw a bounced double-digit growth around the world, with strongest growth in our BRIC + 13 emerging markets. Joe will provide some more color here. The negative impact of currency on a year-on-year revenue growth in Q3 was 60 basis points, assuming rates stay at September 30 levels, there should be no impact on currency on our full year revenue results. Now turning to a few details about our various products and services. Overall storage-related revenues grew 16% with or without acquisition effects. We believe that we continue to gain share in key segments of the storage market. We are the number one storage, due in large part to our technology leadership. And this is what continues to define us today. We are the leader in the most important technologies in infrastructure. 
For example, we were the first to introduce SSD in enterprise storage and the automated curing software to leverages. The ability to marry solid state and spinning drives lead to enormous performance and efficiency improvements. We unveiled this disruptive technology almost three years ago, and we're clearly benefiting from our leadership here in both high end and mid-tier storage systems.
This past quarter, we continue to reap the benefits of our innovation. As our Symmetrix spot revenues were up a robust 23%. The VMAX architecture leverages standard X86 processing, it's highly scalable in terms of both performance and capacity and includes advanced, high-value functionality like virtual provisioning and FAST. 
It is these capabilities which are driving our gains, not only in the traditional high-end deployments but also in large consolidation place, Private Cloud infrastructures and increasingly Public Cloud environments. I think that this success in brand tradition of Symmetrix leads many to think just in terms of traditional client storage. And of course we continue to set the pace there. 
However, I would encourage you to think more broadly regarding how this new architecture has been designed to be ideally strategic for the new information requirements of virtual infrastructures and cloud environments. It's this combination of our existing leadership position and the rapid penetration of these new cloud-focused environments that's driving our strong results.
A great example of this success is a Q3 win at a major global healthcare company. In this deal, VMAX's virtual provisioning and FAST, with the ability to tier to standard drives were key features as this enable the customer to increase utilization, simplify their environment and reduce CapEx and OpEx. In this case, where the customer was deploying VMware, our competitor required three times the amount of hardware to perform equivalently to two VMAX engines. This is a clear example of how VMAX is winning in large VMware consolidations. In this case, the customer wants a storage system that can support 2,500 virtual machines growing to 6,000.
In fact, VMAX has proven itself to be so cost-effective and flexible that in many instances, customers are consolidating multiple mid-tier storage platforms on to one VMAX. This is happening with both EMC and competitive midtier storage platforms. As a couple of proved points, we swept the floor of a midtier competitor’s product with the VMAX at the global healthcare customer I just mentioned and also in another win among the world's leading media and entertainment companies. As customers are moving toward the cloud, EMC is best able to help them along every step of the journey and these are just two more examples.
Our midtier Storage business continued to show good growth again in Q3, increasing 22% year-on-year. The software capability we announced last quarter for our CLARiiON and Celerra platforms, Unisphere, FAST v2 and FAST Cache and block compressor from primary storage are being embraced by customers. The standard system shipping with emphasis in the midtier continues to increase, helped in part by the availability of FAST v2 and FAST Cache. 
These features was definitely a factor in several of the deals we won this quarter, including where we bid out a midtier competitor in a well-known West Coast University. In addition, we won a project to remove an incumbents’ midtier product and we also beat two other vendors at a well-known US-based retailer, based upon the strength of our VMware integration and significantly better capacity utilization.
Another key benefit of the breadth and depth of EMC's business is that we have a leadership position in some of the hottest areas of technology today. These technology products acts as wonderful door openers for EMC. This was the case in a recent government project, where we leveraged data domain relationship to highlight the CLARiiON capabilities in a VMware environment. CLARiiON integration with VMware was the deciding factor in the purchase of several CLARiiON systems as initial footprints in the deployment that would eventually scale to several petabytes. That's in addition to the large data domain purchases happening this quarter. This is just one great example of the synergy and success of our model.
Our Backup Recovery Systems business continues to grow at a high pace. We expect BRS is extraordinary growth opportunity to play out for a long time. This will clearly lead toward success with BRS, as the clear leader in the space, but will also drive additional opportunities for EMC to help customers in other ways.
As we announced last week, we've added a new division and a whole new set of opportunities to our portfolio. Greenplum, which we announced in July, is the foundation of our new Data Computing Products division. Its first new product, the EMC Greenplum data computing appliance, offers the industry's best price/performance ratio, 3X more scalability and up to 4X as many database cores than competitive systems and data input speed up to 5X that of our competitors. Our DCA integrates database, compute and storage into an enterprise class, easy-to-implement system that can meet petabyte scale big data requirements. We are very excited to pursue this incremental market opportunity by offering yet another leading edge solution to customers, as they increasingly seek the best analytic tools to derive business values from their massive volumes of data.
Our RSA security revenue growth accelerated in Q3 to 22% year-on-year. Our GRC and SIEM products did well as the customers’ new way to manage their multitude of discreet security devices. The combination of these capabilities enables customers to have an easy-to-use governance layer that could oversee and manage other security products throughout their environments. 
As security and compliance become increasingly important to all customers, as more infrastructures move towards the cloud, this unique governance and management layer is a key differentiator and enabler in the marketplace. This was the reason we want an important security operation center project out of very large financial services customer this quarter. Revenue from our Information Intelligence Group was relatively flat against last year's Q3. The xCP platform continues to be very popular in IEG1 in a number of significant new customers in the quarter.
Clearly the rollout of virtual infrastructures in the build out of private and public clouds drove the strong growth of VMware in the quarter, up 46%. The experiments [ph](35:11) around VMworld with over 17,000 attendees is a great example of the impact VMware has on the industry. At VMworld we made a number of announcements, including vCloud Director, VMWare View 4.5, vShield and vFabric. 
We also a number of announcements around how other EMC products are being integrated with VMware, including Unified Infrastructure Management version 2, which when deployed with vCloud Director and Vblock, scraped off [ph] essentially a vCloud in a box. Other announcements included EMC storage infrastructure with secure authentication, which when combined with View 4.5 sets a storage efficiency record of $38 per client, the best in the market due to this high integration of all this various technologies. We also announced a strong RSA VMware cloud security and compliance solution, another industry first that will help ease the security concerns of customers as they move towards the cloud.
Because virtualization is the foundation of cloud computing, a key to success with VMware is bringing the virtual infrastructure and the information infrastructure together. And while we encourage others to work with VMware, we work hard as anyone else to integrate the virtual and information infrastructures. With over 60 different integration points now between EMC and VMware, including support for all the VMware APIs we lead in VMware integration. 
Recognizing the difference such as high integration makes in performance, a global medical technology company purchased both the CLARiiON and Celerra systems in the quarter. It was a combination of the VM plug-ins Unified architectures and features like FAST and FAST Cache, all for one vendor that drove this deal for us. Our results this quarter and for the last several, are great indicators of the strength of our strategy and business model. The boost in cloud is underway, all of IT is moving in this direction and while customers are moving their spending toward these two architectures at varying speeds, the tidal wave of change is definitely real. 
We are leading in the hottest areas of the move to the cloud and we have the broadest portfolio across all the key customer requirements from virtualization to storage, to security, to information governance. And while we cannot control the economy or IT spending, we believe that we'll certainly continue to grow and gain share due to our leadership position in this rapidly growing opportunity.
So looking at the environments. The opportunity ahead, our unique competitive position and the strength of our strategy and model, we are once again raising our expectations to 2010. We now expect to achieve $16.9 billion in revenue, non-GAAP operating margins of 21% to 22% and non-GAAP EPS of $1.25. This reflects revenue growth of 20% and EPS growth of 39%, very robust growth and even better leverage.
As you can see, strong growth with leverage in investments have been a standard for us since 2004 and with the results and outlook we're reporting today, it's clear we're continuing on this trajectory. But what's most exciting is that the fundamental shift to cloud architecture is only in the early stages and we believe we are better suited than anyone else to capitalize on this trend as it unfolds over the next several years. We fully expect that the triple play of share growth, investment for the future and financial leverage we're delivering this year can be maintained over the long term.
So in summary, our strategy is clear, the business and operating model are in place, our investments continue to pay off and the cloud opportunity is very big. As a result, we expect to continue to deliver double-digit revenue and double-digit earnings growth for the next few years. I will now turn the call over to Joe, who'll provide some more color on the quarter and what we see through the end of the year. Joe?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and a warm welcome to everyone attending today's conference call. As always, thank you for your interest in EMC.As Tony said, I am currently in Beijing and thus, actively participating in today's earnings call from approximately 6,000 mil
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and a warm welcome to everyone attending today's conference call. As always, thank you for your interest in EMC.
As Tony said, I am currently in Beijing and thus, actively participating in today's earnings call from approximately 6,000 miles away from my colleagues, but I trust the marvels of communication technologies will make the mechanics of this call appear seamless.
Overall, I was very pleased with our performance in Q3. In fact, our top line revenue was the best in EMC's history, as we posted solid growth on both the year-on-year and sequential basis. I am also proud to report that we continue to create leverage in our P&L while investing in the future. To this end, in Q3 we added approximately 1,700 professionals to consolidate EMC in the areas of sales, emerging high-growth markets, R&D and VMware. Our goal is to develop more innovative products and maintain strong growth.
And most importantly, we established EMC and VMware as clear thought leaders with substantial momentum in private, public and hybrid cloud computing. We firmly believe cloud computing, which enables IT as a service, is the next big transformational wave that is shaping the Information Technology landscape. Our success in Q3 would not have been possible without the hard work and dedication of the 47,000 people of EMC and VMware around the world. I want to thank them for their leadership and congratulate them on their accomplishments.
I would now like to make a few comments on the global economy and more importantly, our view on IT spending trends. On the economic front, on a consolidated global basis, we continue to see a slow recovery albeit with a few bumps in the road, pretty much in line with what we have been saying all year and looking forward we expect this trend to continue. Closer to home in IT spending terms, we are seeing real strength in rapid growing and emerging geographies. 
Moderate growth in the U.S., Japan, most of Europe, albeit with a bit of choppiness in a few countries, and solid growth in countries such as Australia, Canada, Mexico and South Africa. Additionally across all markets, the very good news is that the demand for virtualization, information storage, information protection and information security and governance, areas where EMC/VMware is the leader, are growing considerably faster than the IT average. This as evidenced by the fact that in Q3 we grew on a year-on-year basis 21% in the U.S., 28% in APJ, 22% in constant currency, 14% in Europe, 19% in constant currency and approximately 30% in emerging markets. This bounced geographic growth demonstrates that we are focused on IT markets that are growing much faster than the IT as our market as a whole, and more importantly we are clearly taking share.
Additionally, we drove this demand as the ever continuing growth of information and the innovative uses of this information by our customers as they drive for higher and higher levels of productivity on meeting the mandate for risk mitigation and adheres to proper governance and compliance policies. What adds to our confidence in our future is the thought leadership, innovations and strong product roadmap we have in a new big wave of IT of cloud computing. It's our firm belief that cloud computing will transform enterprise IT shops as the customers migrate their IT data centers into private clouds. This transformation will also happen in the search provider community as they build out an extensive number of very large enterprise class public clouds.
Additionally, the actualization of Private and Public Cloud computing will provide our customers a massive benefit, mainly the ability to run applications more flexibly, with a lot more automation and a significantly lower cost while assuring the attendant policies and service levels are adhered to. But even lower cost and more flexibility can be achieved as customers take advantage of both Private and Public cloud computing by federating or operating their various application loads between their own Private clouds and the Public clouds of their chosen service provider partners. We call this cloud implementation, the hybrid cloud. 
I assure you the vast majority of our R&D budgets, our acquisitions, our go-to-market motions and the build out of our partner ecosystem, is aimed at leading and winning in this game-changing hybrid cloud opportunity. The importance of having a world-class partner ecosystem cannot be overstated. I firmly believe no one IT company could possibly possess all the IT resources to go it alone. And very importantly, every single customer I speak with once, in fact, demands best of breed and choice. To this end, our partnership with Cisco is deepening and our VCE coalition is gaining significant momentum in the market. As proof, I am again pleased to report that our Vblock sales are well ahead of plan.
Our partnership with systems integrators, such as Accenture, CSC, Capgemini, Wipro, TCS, Deloitte and others continues to grow strategically and tactically. And last, on our service provider front, we are building a number of very deep alliances with many of the leading telcos and service providers around the world. 
In Q3 we announced partnerships with the following companies: France Telecom's Orange Business Services, SingTels Alphawest, Saudi Telecom, Cable & Wireless and Terremark. And you can expect many more announcements over the coming weeks and months. In summary, EMC is executing well in today's IT market. 
We have a great product and technology portfolio and a go-to-market prowess to capture the opportunity that the private, public and hybrid cloud computing wave offers. Thus, I reaffirm our belief that we can achieve double-digit growth rates over the long term, and to help you better understand why we are so confident in our future, we will host an investor and analyst day in Q1. I'd now like to turn it back to Tony to moderate today's portion of the Q&A portion of today's call.

componenttext: Basically we have a very successful high-end NAS product with Celerra. As always, I like to keep some surprises so we don't -- I don't want to tell you exactly when we'll release new products but I will say we have a very robust product line for 2011.

componenttext: Looking at, I mean it appears most of your business lines are fully optimized at this point. I guess I'd like to focus on the one that doesn't appear to be, the Information Intelligence Group, the old Documentum. headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. First of all, when we think of the hybrid cloud, one big phenomenon today is big data and your big data is going to come in a couple of different forms. It's going to come in the structured form and that's obviously where our Greenplum
componenttext: A couple of things. First of all, when we think of the hybrid cloud, one big phenomenon today is big data and your big data is going to come in a couple of different forms. It's going to come in the structured form and that's obviously where our Greenplum and the DCA that we just announced are important. And it's also going to come in the unstructured form, again, which is why Documentum is still a very important part of the overall strategy. Now within the IIG business, there's a couple of things happening underneath the surface, That business is transitioning from a large enterprise license type business to a smaller application-dependent business so we're moving from the traditional ELA to the kind of smaller xCP application origin rollouts. So underneath the surface you've seen that churn occur and that's why you're seeing the top line relatively flat but strategically it still has a great role in the crowd strategy.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: David's right. There's a lot of moving pieces there and we are in the transition due to our XCP strategy which will make Documentum platform a lot more lively, a lot more SaaS-enabled. And as we get through that transition, we expect we'll see better grow
componenttext: David's right. There's a lot of moving pieces there and we are in the transition due to our XCP strategy which will make Documentum platform a lot more lively, a lot more SaaS-enabled. And as we get through that transition, we expect we'll see better growth.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ittai Kidron from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Ittai Kidron from Oppenheimer.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question for David. With regards to the gross margin in your core EMC business, 55.5% this quarter, I can't even remember the last time you've got such high gross margin and with some of your larger competitors making a lot of acquisitions and trying to
componenttext: A question for David. With regards to the gross margin in your core EMC business, 55.5% this quarter, I can't even remember the last time you've got such high gross margin and with some of your larger competitors making a lot of acquisitions and trying to accumulate a lot of assets after years of non-activity in your area. How should we think about gross margins in your core business going into next year? And also VMware provided some initial growth thoughts on 2011 last night, would you care to do the same with regards to your business?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all now, we're not going into 2011 at this point in time other than to reiterate my comments I said earlier that we are looking to execute our triple play over the long term. And so the next we'll be looking at double-digit revenue growth and dou
componenttext: First of all now, we're not going into 2011 at this point in time other than to reiterate my comments I said earlier that we are looking to execute our triple play over the long term. And so the next we'll be looking at double-digit revenue growth and double-digit earnings growth and those are the only kind of a, if you like, statement putting in the ground right now relative to 2011. Relative to gross margin, I mean yes, we have seen a nice expansion in the non-VMware side of the business. As I mentioned during the quarter what we're seeing is a mixed shift towards our higher gross margin product. So we're doing very well with things like our NAS products, like our VMAX, like our DD products and some of our stories, software and that makeshift is you're helping the margins grow sequentially. I would point out to you that gross margins, we equate that as an indicator of cap value you're providing to the customer. The more value you're providing per customer, the better gross margins are going to be within the business. So that's what's happening beneath the surface there.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Rajesh Ghai of ThinkEquity LLC.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: A number of your large competitors have announced indicated appliances for the cloud. I want to understand what your views were on this competitive activity and whether you believe your Vblock strategy was an adequate response.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think Vblock strategy was a response, I think we started it. Kind of the first integration of taking the Cloud OS VMware, the connectivity and network, the server and the storage and putting it together was pioneered by us. So I don't think we're
componenttext: I don't think Vblock strategy was a response, I think we started it. Kind of the first integration of taking the Cloud OS VMware, the connectivity and network, the server and the storage and putting it together was pioneered by us. So I don't think we're reacting at all, I think others are reacting to us. We, us in Cisco, we're not giving out numbers yet  but what I told you is true. We said -- what I told you, pretty aggressive compliant to Vblocks and I will repeat what I said, we are well above our plan that we set for ourselves both last quarter and this quarter and for the year. So it's going well.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on 3PAR was acquired by HP in midst of bidding war, how do you guys think probably the HP changes the landscape in high-end storage especially for VMAX, I guess given HB sales and services? And then secondly how do you think the EMC-Dell r
componenttext: Just a question on 3PAR was acquired by HP in midst of bidding war, how do you guys think probably the HP changes the landscape in high-end storage especially for VMAX, I guess given HB sales and services? And then secondly how do you think the EMC-Dell relationship goes further given their keen interest I think on all the storage assets versus reselling CLARiiON?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't really 3PAR changes the landscape at all. We've been -- 3PAR, its 10 years old, we've been competing with it for quite a while. From HP, will they make 3PAR successful, I'm sure they will. But I think what you're going to see there is in large sub
componenttext: I don't really 3PAR changes the landscape at all. We've been -- 3PAR, its 10 years old, we've been competing with it for quite a while. From HP, will they make 3PAR successful, I'm sure they will. But I think what you're going to see there is in large substitution for their high-end DBAs and for business that they previously funneled through Hitachi. So I really don't see that changing the landscape at all. As far as the Dell relationship, obviously, we took a step back as Dell went after 3PAR and obviously, cooled things off. We are again in discussions to see if we can do something more meaningful and lasting, both companies would like to do that but the key is it's got to be meaningful and it's got to be last thing for me to tell you that it's back on track. So I can't tell you that yet but I can tell you we are in serious discussions and there is intent on both parties to do that, but obviously 3PAR moving from Dell was a step back to the relationship.

componenttext: Bill, I'll start then I'm going to pass it over to Joe for the second part. In total storage, you're right, the Total Storage business was up 16%, same 23%, midtier 22%. Remember that in the Storage business, well first of all, those numbers I gave you for same and midyear are product-only numbers. In the Storage business there's also product and services, maintenance and professional services and also there are a number of other products in there, including some of the third-party products that we sell through like the connector switches and our select line. So that's the difference between the 16%, the 23% % and the 22%. And for updates on midtier I'm going to pass that over to Joe.

componenttext: Obviously we've said and I'll repeat it that we think we have a very, very competitive, very excited about it, a low-end product coming in Q1. We'll announce that in early Q1. It is on track, it is in beta now. It is doing very well, and again I'm very excited. So stay tuned, we'll announce that in Q1. It is the fastest-growing market in storage and again we're excited to -- we're very excited about the prospects of entering that market in a big way, in a big, big way.

componenttext: Mark, so on the run rate we mentioned that in the first quarter data domain and all other lines combined can reach the $1 billion run rate, which is ahead of plan. We said we'd get to that level in 2010. We got there in Q1. That continues to increase sequentially into Q2 and again into Q3. So we're not like going to break that out again once we got beyond our $1 billion run rate, but we are continuing to see sequential growth and obviously the run rates are now higher. In terms of cross selling, some nice opportunities I mentioned, for example, in my prepared comments where we'd cross-sold into a data domain account, a large CLARiiON project that's going to scale up to kind of like type scale, and of course there's good BRS opportunities into the EMC accounts. So the good news is when we look at BRS, A, it's opening new doors for us; and B, we're also able to increase our footprint inside of the year, the EMC accounts. So it's working both ways, it's certainly a win-win from that point of view.

componenttext: That's close, Jason. headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the three phases to get through cloud, can you just talk about what inning we're in, in Phase I rollouts? And as we move from Phase I to Phase II, do you think we get a pause because of either a hesitancy to move to mission-critical apps or ma
componenttext: In terms of the three phases to get through cloud, can you just talk about what inning we're in, in Phase I rollouts? And as we move from Phase I to Phase II, do you think we get a pause because of either a hesitancy to move to mission-critical apps or maybe because we have to digest before we start doing again or do you think this is a seamless transition between the two phases?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's pretty seamless. Customers are seeing phenomenal reliability. The VMware OS continues to get the highest marks in the industry for stability and high quality in their platform. And of course, with the advent of Halem servers, we've given you
componenttext: I think it's pretty seamless. Customers are seeing phenomenal reliability. The VMware OS continues to get the highest marks in the industry for stability and high quality in their platform. And of course, with the advent of Halem servers, we've given you that six to eight quarters in tremendous power, customers are seeing reliability, the capability and they are definitely, definitely moving to Phase II without a pause. And I think Phase II will be very successful.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, just to pick up on the comment, as I mentioned the requirements and the benefit the customers change from the phase. Phase I is really about consolidation cost reduction. Phase II, customers are looking for cost, they're actually looking to increas
componenttext: Jason, just to pick up on the comment, as I mentioned the requirements and the benefit the customers change from the phase. Phase I is really about consolidation cost reduction. Phase II, customers are looking for cost, they're actually looking to increase their SLAs as they virtualize, which requires a whole turn technology to drive optimization around those SLAs. So it really changes the game very much from a VMware point of view, but also from a storage point of view, the requirement in Phase II is very, very different. That's why I gave you some examples in my script, so that the ability to seamlessly bridge Phase I and Phase II, really set us apart.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: By the way, speaking from first-hand experience, our own IT shop, we have moved a substantial number of our mission-critical apps, as a matter of fact, all of our CRM apps to this world and we're seeing great opportunity, so we are clearly kind of drinking the Kool-Aid and getting a very good taste.

componenttext: Clearly on the storage side, the star of the show would be VMAX and our BRS Data Domain and Avamar products. And the other star of the show is our, NAS business. Our Celerra NAS businesses is also growing tremendously fast after that major competitor. So those are the stars of the show obviously, information security is incredibly important and you see the growth in our RSA Divisions business. So those are going great and our new entry in the Greenplum is showing a lot of progress and  a good pipeline. That's not going to be a major impact in Q, obviously because of its size. But still got great growth. So we have several areas that are, I would call, hot. And of course, you mentioned, on the DII side, but of course VMware continues to -- they raise their guidance also. So pretty good strength across major product lines and then of course in Q1 we're going to enter a new phase with our low end products. So we're in pretty good shape going forward, very good shape going forward.

componenttext: Well, obviously I didn't mention CLARiiON as a star, but it's holding its own. What we did do, which customers are loving, is I said as we did with our VMAX platform before, we have released a lot of the key software on the older platforms ahead of the new announcements. So Unisphere, FAST Cache, Fast v2, new compression technology, are being very well received by customers and that's having an effect. Obviously CLARiiON is also affected by Dell moving onto EqualLogic. CLARiiON had a lot to overcome, our new whole nuclear strategy, we think, is back on track and we're looking very forward to the future. So I think it'll continue to not be a star in Q4 but it'll probably and do okay.

componenttext: Keith, a few comments on free cash flow. First of all, I think the one metric that's leaked out that we look at on a quarter-by-quarter basis because of the ebbs and flows and timings of working capital investments even some CapEx build up, so I commented that free cash flow for the year so far is up 22%, year-to-date its over $400 million higher than our non-GAAP net income. Looking forward to Q4 and the year, looking forward to 2011, we continue to strive to have our free cash flow be higher than our non-GAAP net income.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So again, thank you for joining us, we very much appreciate it. And in closing, I want to reiterate that we are executing well, our strategy for the private, public and hybrid cloud is solid and gaining traction. We have a product roadmap that is well aim
componenttext: So again, thank you for joining us, we very much appreciate it. And in closing, I want to reiterate that we are executing well, our strategy for the private, public and hybrid cloud is solid and gaining traction. We have a product roadmap that is well aimed and again, very exciting. And we have the go to market and alliance partners necessary to bring these innovative products to market, but most importantly we have 47,000-plus great people in EMC and VMware who believe in our vision and our future. So once again, thank you for joining us and we look forward to seeing you soon. Thank you very much. Bye-bye.

Sir, you may begin.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: With me, here at Hopkinson we have David Goulden, EMC Executive, Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results we released this morning to highlight some of EMC’s activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for
componenttext:
With me, here at Hopkinson we have David Goulden, EMC Executive, Vice President and CFO. David will provide a few comments about the results we released this morning to highlight some of EMC’s activities this quarter and discuss our updated outlook for the rest of 2010. Joe will then spend some time discussing his few of what is happening in the market, EMC’s execution of strategy and how EMC is positioned to help customers on the journey to the Cloud. After the prepared remarks, we will then open up the lines to take your questions. I would like to point out that we will be referring to non-GAAP numbers in today’s presentation unless otherwise indicated. The reconciliation of our non-GAAP comments to our GAAP results can be found in the disclosure today in our press release, supplemental schedule and the slides that accompany our presentation. 
All of these are available for download within the investor relations section of EMC.com. 
As always, we have provided detailed financial tables in our news release and on our corporate website. These include a lot of financial detail so we do encourage you to take a look at them. The call this morning will contain forward-looking statements and information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ can be found in the EMC filings with the US Securities and Exchange Commission and lastly I will note that an archive of today’s presentation will be available following the call. With that, it is now my pleasure to introduce David Goulden. David?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone and thanks for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another great quarter. We achieved record revenues of over $4.2 billion up 20%. Record Q3 non-GAAP net income of $649 million up 35%. Non-GAAP EP
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone and thanks for joining us today. I'm very pleased to report that EMC had another great quarter. We achieved record revenues of over $4.2 billion up 20%. Record Q3 non-GAAP net income of $649 million up 35%. Non-GAAP EPS of $0.30 up 30%. Record year-to-date free cash flow of $2.2 billion up 22% and non-GAAP operating margin of 21.5% of 80 basis points sequentially. 
We continue to execute on triple play with strong double-digit growth in storage security and virtualization, it's clear we continue to gain share in these key areas of the market, areas where we're already the market leader. With the announcements of VMware View 4.5, storage efficiency technologies like Fast B2, Fast cash and the acquisition of Greenplum it's clear we're investing for the future but more importantly these investments are bearing fruit and with non-GAAP gross and operating margins up 40,80 basis points respectively quarter on quarter we continue to improve profitability. We expect to continue this triple play over the long term because of how well we position ourselves to capitalize on the fundamental shift of Cloud computing. 
Now let me start by taking a few minutes to discuss what's driving our good results. The industry generally agrees that the shift to cloud architectures is no longer a question of if but when. The answer is it's happening now albeit at different speeds for different companies but all companies go through the same three phases to transform their traditional physical infrastructures to true cloud architectures and to take full advantage of the ability to offer IT as a service. Phase I is the virtualization of IT owned applications which also requires simple, efficient VM integrate storage.
Phase II is a virtualization of business critical applications. This is where SLA's around performance, availability, workload availability, recoverability and security really matter. Phase III realizes the full benefit of Cloud by taking advantages of Phases I and II together with IT automation, provisioning and chargeback to offer IT infrastructure as a service for the entire enterprise. It's at this phase that you have an elastic cloud of compute networking storage and resources and are also seamlessly drawing on compatible public cloud services where it makes sense. 
So, let’s look at what EMC offers for each one of these phases. The first phase typically tends to involves small deployments. Typically, it involves the IT departments virtualizing applications they own and manage. For these implementations, which require virtualization, and simple and efficient storage, EMC has VMware's vSphere and our unified storage products. With the majority of customers currently in this first phase our unified storage frontlines has grown rapidly and others are benefiting from this trend in the mid tier as well. Where we're really distinguishing ourselves in this phase is with efficiency technologies like SSC's and Fast Cash as well as with tight integration with VMware. For example, one well know online brokerage firm in the quarter selected EMC's unified storage in large part because of the fast cash. It's an ability to accelerate performance to address unexpected workload spikes, could not be matched by either of the other two vendors competing for this deal. 
In the second phase were virtualization extends to business critical applications SLA has become very important. In fact, customers are telling us they want ?? after they virtualize. Also, if customers selected to deploy business critical applications on enterprise storage for high SLA's in the physical world they're not going to deploy them on mid tier as they virtualize. In the second phase customers look to technologies from VMware like ?? apps speed and vSphere storage and network IO control to help control performance ?? of the applications storage and network levels. Likewise, they demand that their storage infrastructure extend these capabilities and support these SLA's. For example, EMC's fast works for storage IO control to deliver industry leading distributed resource scheduling for storage making enterprise apps perform 2 1/2 times better for the same cost. 
Customers also look to things like VMAX, VFlex duplication and security to meet these SLA deeper in the infrastructure. In Phase I a ray based snap on replicate is suitable for backup but in Phase II tight integration of high performance backup like EMC's Avamar with Vstorage API's and with the sensor provides much higher service levels. For example in Q3, a large manufacturing customer who wanted to reduce space and power consumption in a data sensor and at the same time virtualize as servers and desktops selected VMAX. 
We won another deal at a well-known global cosmetics company. In this case, the customer is expanding its VMware implementation and will use active active VM teleportation with VFlex to raise availability and federate across data sensors at distance. These are great examples of a sophisticated enterprise class technology required in this phase and in these cases, it happened to be technology our competitors could not match. In fact, in Phase II implementations larger competitors tend not to have all of their three best ?? technology and our mid tier competitors don't have the portfolio to reproved a full solution.
Phase III is when you really get to IT as a service. This involves things like integrate stacks, management up and down from physical to virtual and usage monitoring, all of which EMC offers. Our vSolution enables hybrid clouds with Vblocks. Our UIM, Unified Infrastructure Manager offers across domain provisioning, change and configuration managements. VCloud director offers self-provisioning of virtual machines in a multi?? environment and VPLEX facilitates seamless data mobility between private clouds and external providers. Illustrating this, a very large pharmaceutical company this quarter decided it was taking them too long to provision their virtual machines and turned to EMC. Now as an implement to, they're moving forward with Vblock, VMAX, UM and will use VPLEX for an active active datacenter architecture. What these examples demonstrate is that there does not tend to be any one typical cloud deal. Company’s infrastructure requirements are as varied as the companies themselves. This is why it's very important for them to have a broad and deep range of products' and services and as each company develops, its cloud infrastructure roadmap EMC can meet their needs through every phase from the departmental to enterprise wide from Tier 0 to the backup of an archive. 
Now a common question in the investor community is whose storage works best in virtualized environments? We think the best way to find out is to go ask customers which vendor they trust. As you can see from the results of these surveys, which come from separate sources, EMC consistently rises to the top when it comes to providing infrastructure for virtualized environments. Now there is one smaller competitor that claims to have a lead in virtualized environments but the facts simply don't bear it up. Rather note it tends to be the bigger, more established companies with broader offerings that come in behind EMC. Customers realize that the journey to a cloud infrastructure can be complex requiring a broad range of process services. As a result, they go with companies like EMC that can provide more. 
Public cloud providers are also building an infrastructure on EMC for a number of reasons. With virtualization, being the foundation for public cloud service VMware is key. With the vast amounts of data being stored and managed by public cloud provider’s scalability is critical. For example VMAX’s X86-based scale architecture offers this at pedabyte scale. With multi ? securities critical and the ability to attest to that security is just as important particularly for a public cloud provider. RSA's cloud security solution offers this accountability. As enterprise customers need data mobility for true, seamless, hybrid cloud and VPLEX enables the advance federation of resources into and out of the enterprise. 
This quarter we announced that several service providers are taking advantage of these technologies to offering public cloud services to their clients and this number continues to ramp. Joe will give you more color on some of these winds in his comments. The various examples I referenced are just a few of the deals we closed in Q3 with customers looking to start or continue to build out their cloud infrastructures both private and public. Our Q3 cloud winds stand verticals including government, healthcare, media, manufacturing, energy, services and academia and all of our frontline across VMware, security and storage including high-end and mid tier ? and ?.
Now I've given you a sense of what’s behind our strong results lets look at the numbers in more detail. Revenue in the quarter grew 20% to $4.2 billion in Q3. The increase in value customers received from our products and services is driving improvements to our business with non-GAAP gross margin of 60.5% up 40 basis points sequentially. This improvement was driven primarily by higher storage prop' margins thanks to the faster growth of our higher storage margin products. Ongoing operating improvements helped drive non-GAAP operating margins of 21.5% up 80 basis points sequentially and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.30 up from $0.28 last quarter and from $0.23 a year ago. Free cash flow is strong and year-to-date was $2.2 billion of 22% and $427 million greater than on non-GAAP income for the same period. We ended the quarter with $10.5 billion in cash, of this a total of $6.2 billion was held in the U.S. with reminder overseas. We spent $500 million on acquisitions in the quarter and $283 million buying back 15 million shares of EMC stock bringing us to $800 million on EMC share reproaches so far this year. We still expect to spend $1 billion on EMC stock by the end of the year. In addition, EMC spent $92 million buying VMware shares and VMware spent $131 million on VMware shares.
Looking at VMware’s pivotal role as a cloud data operating system of the future we feel strongly that these relatively small purchases to maintain our ownership level are an excellent long-term investment. Now looking at our geographies we saw a balanced double-digit growth around the world with strongest growth in our brickell 13 emerging markets. Joe will provide some more color here. The negative impact of currency on a year-over-year revenue growth was 60 basis points. Assuming rates stay at September 30 levels there should not be impact on currency on our full revenue results. 
Now turning to a few details about our various products and services, overall storage related revenues grew 16% with or without acquisition affects. We believe that we continue to gain shares in key segments of the storage markets. We are the number one storage due in large part to our technology leadership and this is what continues to define us today. We are the leader in the most important technologies in ? infrastructure. For example we were the first to introduce SSD's in enterprise storage and the automated ? software to leverages. The ability to ?? solid state and spinning drives leads to enormous performance and efficiency in improvements. We unveiled the ? technology almost three years ago and we're clearly benefiting from our leadership here in both high end and mid tier storage systems. 
This past quarter we continue to reap the benefits of our innovation as our symmetric part revenues were up a robust 23%. The VMAX architecture leverages standard X86 processing is highly scalable in terms of both performance and capacity and includes advanced high valued functionality like virtual provisioning and fast and as these capabilities which are driving our gains not only in the traditional high end deployments but also in large consolidation plays, private cloud infrastructures and increasingly public cloud environments. I think that the success in brand tradition of symmetric leads many to think just in terms of traditional clients storage and of course we continue to set the pace there. However, I would encourage you to think more broadly regarding how this new architecture has been designed to be ideally suited for the new information requirements of virtual infrastructures and cloud environments. It's this combination of our existing leadership position and the rapid penetration of these new cloud focused environments that's driving our strong results. 
A great example of this success is a Q3 win at a major global healthcare company. In this deal VMAX's virtual provisioning and fast with the ability to tier to drives were key features as these enabled the customer to increase utilization, simplify their environment and reduce CapEx and OpEx. In this case where the customer was deploying VMware, our competitor required three times the amount of hardware to perform equivalently to two VMAX engines. This is a clear example of how VMAX is winning in large consolidations. In this case the customer wanted the storage system that could support 2500 virtual machines growing to 6,000. In fact VMAX has proved itself to be so cost effective and flexible that in many instances customers have consolidated multiple mid tier storage platforms onto one VMAX. This is happening with both EMC and competitive mid tier storage platforms. 
As a couple of proof points we swept the floor of a mid tier competitors products with the VMAX at the global healthcare customer I just mentioned and also in another win of one of the world's leading media and entertainment companies. As customers are moving towards the cloud, EMC is best able to help them along every step of the journey and these are just two more examples. Our mid tier storage business continued to show good growth again in Q3 increasing 22% year-on-year. The software capabilities we announced last quarter for our client and Solaris platforms Unisphere, Fast V2, Fast Cash and Block Compression for primary storage are being embraced by customers. The percentage of systems shipping with ? in the mid tier continues to increase helped in part by the availability of Fast V2 and Fast Cash. These features were definitely a factor in several of the deals we won this quarter including where we beat out a mid tier competitor in a well-known West Coast university. In addition, we won a project to remove an incumbents mid tier products and we also beat two other vendors at a well-known U.S. based retailer based upon the strength of our VMware integration and significantly better capacity utilization. 
Another key benefit of the breadth and depth of EMC's business is that we have a leadership position in some of the hottest areas of technology today. These technologies and products act as wonderful door openers for EMC. This was the case in a recent government project where we leveraged data domains relationships to highlight client capabilities in our VMware environments. Client integration with VMware was a deciding factor in the purchase of several client systems as initial footprints in a deployment that will eventually scale to several pedebytes. That's in addition to the large data domain purchases happening in this quarter. This is just one great example of the synergy and success of our model. 
Our backup recovery systems business continues to grown at a high pace. We expect VRS's extraordinary growth opportunities to play out for a long time. This will clearly lead to more success for VRS as a clear leader in the space but it will also drive additional opportunities for EMC to help their customers in other ways. As we announced last week we've added a new division and a whole new set of opportunities to our portfolio. Greenplum, which we announced in July, is a foundation of our new data computing products division. It's first new products that EMC Greenplum data computing appliance offers the industries best priced performance ratio, three times more scalability and up to four times ? calls of competitive systems and data input speed of up to five times that of our competitors. 
Our DCA integrates database, compute and storage into an enterprise class. Each ? system that can meet pedabyte scale big data requirements. We are very excited to pursue this incremental market opportunity by offering yet another leading edge solution to customers as they increasingly seek the best analytical tools to derive business values from the massive volumes of data. Our RSA security revenue growth accelerated in Q3 22% year-on-year. Our GRC and NFIM products did well as customers need a way to marriage their multitude of discreet security devices. The combination of these capabilities enables customers to have an easy to use governance layer that can oversee a marriage other security products throughout their environments. As security and compliance become increasingly important to all customers as more infrastructures move towards the cloud this unique governance and marriage layer is a key differentiator and enabler in the market place. This was the reason we won an important security operations ? project at a very large management services customer this quarter. Revenue from our informational intelligence group was relatively flat against last year's Q3. 
The XEP platform continues to be very popular and IAG1 did a number of significant new customers during the quarter. Clearly the rollouts of virtual infrastructures and the build out of private and public clouds drove a strong growth of VMware in the quarter up 46%.   
The  (inaudible) around VMworld with over 17,000 attendees is a great example of the impact VMware has on the industry. At VMworld we made a number of announcements including vCloud Director, VMware View 4.5, vShield and Vfabric. We also made a number of announcements around how other EMC products are being integrated with VMware including Unified Infrastructure Manager Version II which when deployed with vCloud Director and vBlocks creates what's essentially a vCloud in a box. 
Other announcements include an EMC storage infrastructure with secure authentication which when combined with View 4.5 that the storage efficiency record of $38 per client the best in the market due to tight integration of all these various technologies. We also announced a strong VMware cloud security and compliance solution, another industry first that will help ease the security concerns of customers as they move towards the cloud. Because socialization is the foundation of cloud computing a key to success with VMware is bringing the virtual infrastructure and info infrastructure together and while we encourage others to work with VMware we work harder than anyone else to integrate the virtual and information infrastructures. With over 60 different integration points now between EMC and VMware including support for all the VMware API's we lead in VMware integration. 
Recognizing the difference such tight integration makes in performance a global medical technology company purchased both client and Solaris systems in the quarter. It was a combination of the VM plug-ins, unified architectures and features like Fast Cash all for one vendor that drove this deal for us. 
Our results this quarter and for the last several are great indicators of the strength of our strategy and business model. The move to cloud is underway. All of IT is moving in this direction and while customers are moving they're spending towards these new architectures at various speeds the tidal wave of change is definitely real. We are leading in the hottest areas of the move to the cloud and we have the broadest portfolio across all the key customer requirements to virtualization, storage to security information governance and while we cannot control all the economy or IT spending we believe that we will Certainly continue to grow and gain share due to our leadership position in this rapidly growing opportunity. 
So, looking at the environment the opportunity ahead, our unique competitive position and the strength of our strategy and model we are once again raising our expectation2 for 2010. We now expect to achieve $16.9 billion in revenue, non-GAAP operating margins of 21 to 22% and non-GAAP EPS of $1.25. This reflects revenue growth of 20% and EPS growth of 39%, a very robust growth and even better leverage. As you can see strong growth in leverage and investments have been the standard for us since 2004 and with the results and outlook we reported today it's clear we're continuing on this trajectory but what's most exciting is that the fundamental shift the cloud architectures is only in the early stages and we believe we are better suited than anyone else to capitalize on this trend as it unfolds over the next several years. We fully expect that the triple play of shared growth, investment for the future and financial leverage we're delivering this year can be maintained over the long term. 
So in summary our strategies clear, the business and operating model are in place, our investments continue to pay off and the cloud opportunities are very big. As a result we expect to continue to deliver double-digit revenue and double-digit earnings growth for the next few years. I'll now turn the call over to Joe who'll provide some more color on the quarter and what we see through the end of the year. Joe?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David and a warm welcome to everyone attending today's conference call. As always, thank  you for your interest in EMC. As Tony said, I am currently in Beijing and thus actively participating in today's earning call from approximately 6,000 miles
componenttext:
Thanks, David and a warm welcome to everyone attending today's conference call. As always, thank  you for your interest in EMC. As Tony said, I am currently in Beijing and thus actively participating in today's earning call from approximately 6,000 miles away from my colleagues but I trust the marvels of communication technology will make the mechanics of this call appear seamless. 
Overall, I was very pleased with our performance in Q3. In fact, our top line revenue was the best in EMC's history as we posted solid growth on both the year-on-year sequential basis. I am also proud to report that we continue to create leverage in our P&L while investing in the future. To this end in Q3 we added approximately 1700 professionals to consolidate at EMC in the areas of Sales, emerging high growth markets, R&D and VMware. Our goal is to develop more innovative products and maintain strong growth and most importantly we established EMC and VMware as clear thought leaders with substantial amenum in private, public and hybrid cloud computing. We firmly believe cloud computing which enables IT as a service is the next big  wave that is shaping the information technology landscape. 
Our success in Q3 would not have been possible without the hard work and dedication of the 47,000 people of EMC and VMware around the world. I want to thank them for their leadership and congratulate them on their accomplishments. I would now like to make a few comments on a global economy and more importantly our view on IT spending trends. 
On the economic front, on a consolidated global basis we continue to see a slow recovery albeit with a few bumps in the road. Pretty much in line with what we've been saying all year and looking forward we expect this trend to continue. Closer to home in IT spending terms we are seeing really strong and rapid growing and emerging geographies. Moderate growth in the U.S. and Japan, most of Europe albeit with a bit of choppiness in a few countries and solid growth in countries such as Australia, Canada, Mexico and South Africa. Additionally across all markets the very good news is that the demand for virtualization, information storage, information protection and information security and governance are areas where EMC/VMware as the leader are growing considerably faster than the IT average. This is evidenced by the fact that in Q3 we grew on a year-on-year basis 21% in the U.S., 28% in APJ, 22% in constant currency, 14% in Europe, 19% in constant currency and approximately 30% in emerging markets. This bounced geographic growth demonstrates that we are focused on IT markets that are growing much faster than the IT market as a whole and more importantly we are clearly taking share. 
Additionally what drove this demand is the ever-continuing growth of information and the innovative uses of this information by our customers as they drive for higher and higher levels of productivity while meeting the mandate for risk mitigation and inherence to proper governance and compliance policies. What adds to our confidence in our future is the thought leaderhip, innovations and strong product roadmap we have in a new big wave of IT cloud computing. It is our firm believe that cloud computing will transform enterprised IT shops as the customers migrate their IT data centers into private clouds. This transformation will also happen in a surge provider community as they build out an expansive number of very large enterprise class public clouds. 
Additionally the actualization of private and public cloud computing will provide our customers a massive benefit namely the ability to run applications more flexibly with a lot more automation and a significantly lower cost while ensuring that the intended policies and service levels are adhered to. But even lower costs and more flexibility can be achieved as customers take advantage of both private and public cloud computing by federating or operating their various application loads between their own private clouds and the public clouds of their chosen service provider partners. We call this cloud implementation the hybrid cloud. I assure you the vast majority of our R&D budgets, our acquisitions, our go-to-market motions and the build out of our partner ecosystem is aimed at leading and winning in this game changing hybrid prod opportunity. The importance of having a world-class partner ecosystem cannot be overstated. I firmly believe no one IT company could possibly possess al the IT resources to go it alone and very importantly every single customer I speak with wants, in fact demands, best of breed and choice. 
To this end our partnership with Cisco is deepening and our VC coalition is gaining significant momentum in the market. As proof I am again pleased to report that our Vback sales are well ahead of plan. Our partnership with such integrators such as Incenter, CSC, Cap Gemini, WeePro, TCS, Deloit and others continues to grow strategically and tactically and last on the surge provider front we are building a number of very deep alliances with many of the leading Telco’s and service providers around the world. In Q3 we announced partnerships with the following companies: Branch Telecoms Orange Business Services, Cintels Alpha West, Swelty Telecom, Cable and Wireless and Terramark and you can expect many more announcements over the coming weeks and months.
In summary, EMC is executing well in today's IT market. We have a great product and technology portfolio and a go-to-market prowess to capture the opportunity that the private and public hybrid cloud-computing wave offers. Thus, I reaffirm our belief that we can achieve double-digit growth rates over the long term and to help you better understand why we are so confident in our future we will host an investor and analyst day in Q1. I'd now like to turn it back to Tony to moderate today's portion of the Q&A portion of today's call.

As always, I would like to keep some surprises so we don’t, I don’t want to tell you exactly when we’ll release new products but I will say we have a very robust product line for 2011.

Thank you.

componenttextpreview: Okay, Brian. Sure. A couple of things. First of all when we think of the hybrid cloud, one of the things we ? is big data and you know big data is going to come in a couple of different forms. It’s going to come in the structured form and that’s obvio
componenttext: Okay, Brian. Sure. A couple of things. First of all when we think of the hybrid cloud, one of the things we ? is big data and you know big data is going to come in a couple of different forms. It’s going to come in the structured form and that’s obviously where Greenplum and the DCA that we just announced having problems and it’s all going to come in the unstructured form again which is why Documentums is all post and past of the overall strategy. Now in the IIG business there’s a couple of things happening under the surface. That business is transitioning from a large enterprise, license type business to a smaller application dependent business so we’re moving from the traditional PLA to the kind of smaller XTP application rollout so underneath the surface you’re seeing that ? so that’s why you’re seeing the ? relatively flat but strategically it’s the great roll in the cloud strategy.
