componenttext: Thanks. A question for David and first of all again, congratulations on the numbers. With regards to the gross margin in your core EMC business, 55.5% this quarter. I can’t even remember the last time you got such high gross margins and with some of your larger competitors making a lot of acquisitions and trying to accumulate a lot of assets after years of non-activity in your area? How should we think about gross margins in your core business going into next year and also VMware provided some initial growth (inaudible) at 2011. Last night would you care to do the same in regards to your business?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, no. We’re not going into 2011 at this point of time other than to reiterate my comments I said earlier that we’re looking to execute a triple play over the long term and certainly next year we’ll be looking at double-digit revenu
componenttext: Well, first of all, no. We’re not going into 2011 at this point of time other than to reiterate my comments I said earlier that we’re looking to execute a triple play over the long term and certainly next year we’ll be looking at double-digit revenue growth and double-digit earnings growth and those are the only if you’d like to put a stake in the ground right now relative to 2011. Relative to gross margins, yes we have seen nice expansion in the non VMware side business but as I mentioned during the quarter what we’ll be seeing is a mixed shift towards our higher gross margin products so we’re doing very well with things like our Nass Box, VMAX, like our DD Products and some of our storage software and the makeshift is helping the margins grow sequentially. I would point out to you that gross margins we equate that as an indicator of the value we’re providing to the customer and the more value we’re providing to the customer the better gross margins are  going to be with the business so that’s what’s happening beneath the surface there.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks. Thanks for the good question. So, a number of your large competitors have announced integrated appliances for the cloud. I want to understand what your views were on this particular activity and you believe the vBlock strategy was an adequate
componenttext: Yes, thanks. Thanks for the good question. So, a number of your large competitors have announced integrated appliances for the cloud. I want to understand what your views were on this particular activity and you believe the vBlock strategy was an adequate response?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don’t think vBlock strategy was a response. I think we started it. Kind of the first integration of taking the cloud OS/VM where the connectivity and network, the server and the storage and putting it together was pioneered by us so I don’t
componenttext: Well, I don’t think vBlock strategy was a response. I think we started it. Kind of the first integration of taking the cloud OS/VM where the connectivity and network, the server and the storage and putting it together was pioneered by us so I don’t think we’re reacting at all. I think others are reacting to us. We’re, us and Cisco, we’re not giving out numbers yet but what I’m told is true our, we set what I thought was a pretty aggressive plan for Reeboks and I repeat what I said, we are well above our plan that we set for ourselves both last quarter and this quarter and for the year so it’s going well.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Next question please.
componenttext: Thank you. Next question please.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets. Sir, your line is open.
componenttext: Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets. Sir, your line is open.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning and thanks for taking my questions. Just a question around your, 3Par was acquired by HP amidst a bidding war. How do you guys think Par versus HP changes the landscape (inaudible) especially given HP’s sales and services and second
componenttext: Thanks. Good morning and thanks for taking my questions. Just a question around your, 3Par was acquired by HP amidst a bidding war. How do you guys think Par versus HP changes the landscape (inaudible) especially given HP’s sales and services and secondly how to you think the EMC Dell relationship goes further given their key interest in owning all the storage assets, which is reselling CLARiiON?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think the 3Par changes the landscape at all. We’ve been, 3Par is 10 years old. We’ve been competing with it for quite a while. For HP, will they make 3Par more successful? I ‘m sure they will. I think what you’re going to see there in la
componenttext: I don’t think the 3Par changes the landscape at all. We’ve been, 3Par is 10 years old. We’ve been competing with it for quite a while. For HP, will they make 3Par more successful? I ‘m sure they will. I think what you’re going to see there in large substitution for their high end DBA’s and for business that they previously funneled through Hitachi so I really don’t see that changing the landscape at all. As far as the Dell relationship obviously we took a setback as Dell went after 3Par and obviously cooled things off. We are again in discussions to see if we can do something more meaningful and lasting. Both companies would like to do that but the key is it’s got to be meaningful and it’s got to be the last thing for me to tell you that it’s back on track so I can’t tell you that yet but I can tell you we’re in serious discussions and there is intent on both parties to do that but obviously 3Par move to Dell was a setback to the relationship.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, next question please.
componenttext: Thanks, next question please.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Our next question, William Choi of Jefferies & Company. Sir, your line is open.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. Need a quick clarification at first. Storage grew 16% . You said (inaudible) up 23, mid tier up 22% so what was in storage was below 16% and then the question is really if you could talk about the low end products you guys have talked about
componenttext: Okay, thanks. Need a quick clarification at first. Storage grew 16% . You said (inaudible) up 23, mid tier up 22% so what was in storage was below 16% and then the question is really if you could talk about the low end products you guys have talked about bringing that out in Q1? What would be kind of the margin in revenue ramp and profile of this? I would imagine these things would certainly have higher software integration to them and related to that if you could update us on how you are doing with channel push there? How many partners you have been able to add and what kind of metrics we could talk about? Thanks.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Bill. I’ll start that and I’m going to pass it over to Joe for the second part so, in terms of storage you are right. The total storage business was up 16%, SIM 23, mid to 22. Remember that in the storage business, well first of all those number
componenttext: Okay, Bill. I’ll start that and I’m going to pass it over to Joe for the second part so, in terms of storage you are right. The total storage business was up 16%, SIM 23, mid to 22. Remember that in the storage business, well first of all those numbers that I gave you for SIM are mid to a product only numbers. In the storage business there’s also products and services and there’s maintenance and professional services. Also there are a number of others products in there including some of the high products that we sell through the Connectix switches of our select line so that’s the difference between the 16 and the 23 and the 22 and for updates to mid tier, I’m going to pass that over to Joe.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, I’ve said and I’ll repeat it that we think we have a very, very competitive, very excited about it. A low end product coming in Q1. We’ll announce that in early Q1. It is on track. It is in beta now. It is doing very well and again I’m
componenttext: Obviously, I’ve said and I’ll repeat it that we think we have a very, very competitive, very excited about it. A low end product coming in Q1. We’ll announce that in early Q1. It is on track. It is in beta now. It is doing very well and again I’m very excited so stay tuned and we’ll announce that in Q1. It is the fastest growing market in storage and again we’re excited to be, we’re very excited about the prospects of entering that market in a big way, in a big, big way.

componenttext: Thanks, David. Question please?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Mark, so on the run rate we mentioned that in the first quarter data domain and Avamar lines combined reach the billion-dollar run rate, which was ahead of plan. We said we’d get to that level in 2010. We got there in Q1 and that’s continued to
componenttext: Great. Mark, so on the run rate we mentioned that in the first quarter data domain and Avamar lines combined reach the billion-dollar run rate, which was ahead of plan. We said we’d get to that level in 2010. We got there in Q1 and that’s continued to increase sequentially to Q2 and again into Q3 so we’re not going to break that out again once we got beyond our billion dollar run rates but we are continuing to see sequential growths and obviously the run rates now higher. In terms of cross selling’s some nice opportunities. I mentioned for example in my prepared comments that we were cross sold into a data domain account, a large CLARiiON project that’s going to scale up to pedabyte type scale and of course there’s good (inaudible) opportunities to the EMC account. So the good news is we will look at (inaudible), a: it’s opening new doors for us b: we’re also able to increase our footprint inside of the year, the EMC account so it’s working both ways. It’s certainly a win-win from that point of view.

componenttext: Thank you very much. The question is on the implied sequential growth guidance for the top line, for the core business for the initial infrastructure. It’s around 14% if my math is right. That seems slightly stronger than seasonal so given your comments on the economy being sort of in a slow recovery I was wondering if you could add any color on why we think that’s going to be as strong as the implied guidance suggests?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Yes. 5-year average or something like 13%. This implies around 14% so I think it’s a little bit better than the historical?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Yeah, Joe. Jason’s talking excluding the VMware just to clarify his comments.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know, it’s close Jason. Basically what we’re doing is like we do all the time. We get bottoms of forecasts with a little bit of management wisdom hopefully on those forecasts and we’ve been pretty accurate through the year and this is where we
componenttext: You know, it’s close Jason. Basically what we’re doing is like we do all the time. We get bottoms of forecasts with a little bit of management wisdom hopefully on those forecasts and we’ve been pretty accurate through the year and this is where we’re coming up and so we’re coming to you as we see it so we don’t see the market falling down. We think there’s good opportunity out there for IT and especially in the areas we are, virtualization, storage, information protection, information securities. Those areas are hot and I suspect they will remain hot for the foreseeable future.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks. In terms of the three phases to get true cloud, can you talk about what inning we’re in  Phase I rollouts and as we move from Phase I to Phase II do you think we get a pause because of either a hesitancy to move to mission critical apps or m
componenttext: Hi, thanks. In terms of the three phases to get true cloud, can you talk about what inning we’re in  Phase I rollouts and as we move from Phase I to Phase II do you think we get a pause because of either a hesitancy to move to mission critical apps or maybe because we have to digest before we start consuming again or do you think this is a seamless transition between the two phases? Thanks.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s pretty seamless. Customers are seeing phenomenal reliability. The VMware continues to get the highest marks in the industry for stability and high quality in their platform and of course with the advent of the Helium servers we’ve given
componenttext:
I think it’s pretty seamless. Customers are seeing phenomenal reliability. The VMware 
continues to get the highest marks in the industry for stability and high quality in their platform and of course with the advent of the Helium servers we’ve given you that six to eight cores and tremendous power our customers have seen the reliability, the capability and they’re definitely, definitely moving to Phase II without a pause and I think Phase II will be very successful.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Jason just to pick up on it. As I mentioned the requirements and the benefits because the change from this phase is. Phase I is really about consolidation cost reduction. Phase II customers are looking for costs but they’re actually looking to incre
componenttext: And Jason just to pick up on it. As I mentioned the requirements and the benefits because the change from this phase is. Phase I is really about consolidation cost reduction. Phase II customers are looking for costs but they’re actually looking to increases their SLA’s as they virtualize which requires a whole set of technology to drive optimization around those SLA’s so it really changes the game very much from a VMware point of view but also a storage point of view, the requirements of Phase II are very, very different. That’s why I gave you some examples in my script because the ability to seamlessly reach Phases I and Phases II really sets us apart.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: By the way, speaking from first hand experience, our own IT shop. We had moved a substantial number of our mission critical apps, as a matter of fact all of our CRM apps from, to this world and we’re seeing great opportunities so we’re clearly drinkin
componenttext: By the way, speaking from first hand experience, our own IT shop. We had moved a substantial number of our mission critical apps, as a matter of fact all of our CRM apps from, to this world and we’re seeing great opportunities so we’re clearly drinking the cool aid and getting a very good taste.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Ben Reitzes of Barclays Capital. Sir, you may ask your question.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I want to focus a little bit more on the fourth quarter guidance. Clearly, the guide up versus the street expectation for the fourth quarter end earnings. I just was wondering. Joe, you said you did a bottoms up forecast but what is going better than
componenttext: Yes. I want to focus a little bit more on the fourth quarter guidance. Clearly, the guide up versus the street expectation for the fourth quarter end earnings. I just was wondering. Joe, you said you did a bottoms up forecast but what is going better than expected and included in that guidance is symmetric number looking pretty strong versus the expectations made? What are we missing potentially that had you raise guidance that’s better than expected? It seems like a pretty strong outlook? Thanks.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you know clearly on the storage side. The stars of the show would be VMAX and our VRS beta domain and Avamar products and the other stars show it is our Nass business, our Solaris Nass business is also growing tremendously fast. Faster than our majo
componenttext: Well, you know clearly on the storage side. The stars of the show would be VMAX and our VRS beta domain and Avamar products and the other stars show it is our Nass business, our Solaris Nass business is also growing tremendously fast. Faster than our major competitors so those would be the stars of the show obviously the information security is incredibly important and you can see the growth in our sales division business so those are going great and our new entry into Greenplum is showing a lot of progress and a good pipeline. That’s not going to be a major impact because of it’s size but still has great growth. We have several areas that I would hot and of course you mentioned that you wanted the II side but of course the VMware continues to raise their guidance also so pretty good strength for us, major project lines and of course we’ve got some, in Q1 we’re going to enter a new phase with our low end products so we’re in pretty good shape going forward, in very good shape going forward.

componenttext: Thanks. Next question please?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on the quarter. One of the concerns during Q3 was if customers are waiting for the unified CLARiiON and Solaris anticipated next year. Can you comment on what you saw on the CLARiiON product line and what to expect there? Thanks.
componenttext: Congratulations on the quarter. One of the concerns during Q3 was if customers are waiting for the unified CLARiiON and Solaris anticipated next year. Can you comment on what you saw on the CLARiiON product line and what to expect there? Thanks.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously I didn’t mention CLARiiON as a star but it’s holding it’s own. What we did do that customers are loving. As I said we’re, as we did with our VMAX platform and before, we have released a lot of the key software on the older platform
componenttext: Well, obviously I didn’t mention CLARiiON as a star but it’s holding it’s own. What we did do that customers are loving. As I said we’re, as we did with our VMAX platform and before, we have released a lot of the key software on the older platforms ahead of the new announcements so Unisphere, Fast Cash, Fast V2, new compression technology are being very well received by customers and that’s having an effect. Obviously, CLARiiON is obviously affected by Dell moving onto Equilogix so CLARiiON had a lot to overcome. Our new hope this year, strategy we think is back on track and we’re looking very forward to the future so I think it will continue to not be a star in Q4 but it’ll plod along and do okay.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks. Next question please?
componenttext: Great. Thanks. Next question please?

componenttextpreview: Okay, I was going to ask about why it has grown less than some of the other geographies but also since you mentioned it that your largest, that your competitor in the Nad area that you’re growing faster than them? I think in their hardware area last qua
componenttext: Okay, I was going to ask about why it has grown less than some of the other geographies but also since you mentioned it that your largest, that your competitor in the Nad area that you’re growing faster than them? I think in their hardware area last quarter they grew 50% year-over-year last quarter. Maybe you could give us some comparable numbers to also take a look at your numbers in the mid tier storage space area for you?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, think of it like this. I’m not going to give you new numbers but I understand their growth rate and I said that our, if you looked at our Solaris alone it grew faster and I say that again. So obviously our Solaris is aimed at the higher, higher en
componenttext: Well, think of it like this. I’m not going to give you new numbers but I understand their growth rate and I said that our, if you looked at our Solaris alone it grew faster and I say that again. So obviously our Solaris is aimed at the higher, higher end and that’s a good space to be and we’re going to do a lot of expansion as I answered to the first question however where they’re growing extremely fast is an area we’re not in, which is the low end which I told you we started addressing in early Q1 so that’s kind of how, that’s kind of a macro statement around that.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Nu, just to pick up on your question about Europe. As Joe mentioned in his comments if you look at Europe in constant currency you’ve actually got 19% so where we did have a currency headwind, I mentioned in my script it’s about 60 basis poin
componenttext: And then Nu, just to pick up on your question about Europe. As Joe mentioned in his comments if you look at Europe in constant currency you’ve actually got 19% so where we did have a currency headwind, I mentioned in my script it’s about 60 basis points for the quarter. Basically all our headwind was in Europe but 19% constant currencies pretty good growth.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right. We have time for one more question and then Joe will have a few closing comments.
componenttext: All right. We have time for one more question and then Joe will have a few closing comments.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Our last question, Keith Bachman  of BMO Capital Markets. Sir, your line is open.

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thank you. A couple for you David, if I could? Could you talk about a little bit about cash flow, free cash flow as you think about Q4 specifically what are the objectives that you have and you mentioned 11 double-digit revenue and earnings growth? Ho
componenttext: Hi, thank you. A couple for you David, if I could? Could you talk about a little bit about cash flow, free cash flow as you think about Q4 specifically what are the objectives that you have and you mentioned 11 double-digit revenue and earnings growth? How should we be thinking about free cash flow, particularly since it’s on the consolidated basis. It’s slowed down a little bit this quarter in terms of the growth rate?

headline: EMC Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Keith a few comments on free cash flow. I think it’s, the one metric that’s least helpful to look at on a quarter by quarter basis because of the timings and capital investments and CapEx buildup so I comment that free cash flow for the year so f
componenttext:
Yes, Keith a few comments on free cash flow. I think it’s, the one metric that’s least helpful to look at on a quarter by quarter basis because of the timings and capital investments and CapEx buildup so I comment that free cash flow for the year so far is up 22% . Year-to-date it’s over $400 million higher than our non-GAAP net income. We’re looking forward to a Q4 in the year and looking forward to 2011 and we continue to strive to have our free cash flow be higher than our non-GAAP net income. 
So again, thank you for joining us. We very much appreciate it and in closing I want to reiterate that we are executing well. Our strategy for the private, public and hybrid cloud is solid and gaining traction. We have a product rollback that is well aimed and again very exciting and we have the go-to-market and the last part is necessary to bring these innovative products to market but most importantly we have 47,000 plus great people in EMC and VMware that believe in our vision and our future. So, once again thank you fro joining us and we look forward seeing to seeing you in the future, seeing you soon. Thank you very much. Bye, Bye.
